reviewText: This is a great movie for adults. Great story, great acting, it's funny, and it's entertaining. If you're an ADULT and can't handle vulgar language and nudity, crawl back under your rock and hide from reality. Seriously, what sheltered existence does an adult live that they can't handle a movie based on a true story. It's reality!!!  should they leave out real events because they might offend someone. Should we censor reality. If you can't handle swear words, nudity, sex and drugs you shouldn't watch this movie or ever leave your house. This movie tells the story of greed and it needs to be told! People who say it glorifies this lifestyle missed the point of the entire story. The story really displays the seven deadly sins. If this movie made you angry, disgusted, disturbed, sick........then Scorsese did his job. I highly recommend this movie, especially to younger adults in the workforce who want success- it has great lessons in it.

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street, 2013 filmThis is an X-rated film with some “redeeming social value”. It starts with an advertisement for Stratton Oakmont (how did they pick that name?). Next a man boasts of his material wealth and possessions. He is a heavy drug user. Where does his wealth come from ? He started working at 22. They call people to get them to “invest” (buying pieces of paper with real money). [Is that behavior believable? Fleecing the lambs? Will you learn from this?] Who will you invest with? [Will you read about this in your local newspaper?] The Stock Market crash of October 1987 was the worst since 1929. Jordan Belfort looks for a new job - in Long Island. They sell “penny stocks”, an unregulated business, where the broker or salesman makes a 50% commission! [Have you ever received a telephone call from somebody like this?] Jordan’s sales pitch impresses the others. [What kind of character do they have?] Jordan recruits a neighbor, who explains his personal life. Does he have the right stuff?Jordan starts his own business to sell stocks to the middle class. The poor don’t have money, the rich are smart enough to turn him down. He recruits friends and operates out of a two-bay garage at first. He will now target the wealthy. First the blue chips, then the penny stocks. They show examples of selling over the telephone. [“Beware of friendly strangers who want to sell you something” is still true.] Does this group act like a bunch of lunatics? Guilty consciences? ‘Forbes’ magazine interviews Jordan and does a “hatchet job” on his firm. [How many people read ‘Forbes’ magazine?] This brings in more salesmen! Can you believe all this? Jordan hires his father (for Security). Can you believe their office parties? Drugs and drinking? Jordan is attracted to a new woman (she designs lingerie too). They have similar interests. His wife finds out. “Who are you?” Their butler brings his friends over. Who stole his money? The SEC checks their records. Their firm creates IPOs to swindle more money. Was it legal? No, but who was checking their records? Jordan marries Noami in the Bahamas. She gets a yacht. Next a huge estate on Long Island. [“The Great Gatsby”?] Then there are arguments in the morning.A man cleans fish bowls and attracts attention. Who owns “Steve Madden”, the shoe designer? [What did they produce in this country?] Stratton Oakmont will call people to talk them into buying pieces of paper, stock certificates. “Start dialing!” The FBI is interested in his firm. Jordan tells what Wall Street is doing with “collateralized debt obligations” and Internet stock. [Remember?] He mentions Goldman [Sachs], Lehman [Brothers] and Merrill Lynch. [All went bankrupt years later because of their mismanagement.] Watch Jordan try to sell this FBI agent! It doesn’t work. Jordan travels to Switzerland with a bag of cash. A drug problem? We learn about the banking laws of Switzerland. Jordan needs someone to front for him. How can they safeguard their cash? [Where there’s a will there’s a way.] An argument draws the attention of the police. Jordan and Doug do quaaludes; these have a delayed effect! Who has a drug reaction? [Call 911.] Who drove Jordan’s car?Can he make a deal with the SEC? He leaves the firm, “the land of opportunity”. Jordan is barred from the securities business (after five years). But he won’t go. The Feds send subpoenas then interrogate. “I don’t remember.” Aunt Emma died! What about her money? There is a storm at sea! [Has his luck changed?] There is a long list of charges against Jordan and the others. Jordan is offered a deal if he cooperates. Naomi will divorce him and take the children. He overreacts. Jordan will cooperate with the Feds. The FBI raid their headquarters. Many are convicted. Jordan got three years in Nevada. “Sell me this pen.” [How would you do it?]This is a sleazy and shocking movie, and not just for the language. You will see scenes that won’t be shown on broadcast TV. Was it a deserved flop? Aside from the scenes and language, it also runs on too long for its message. I feel sorry for all those taken in by these swindlers, but they should not have trusted a voice on the telephone. Has our society conditioned people to trust all advertising? Do many of these characters seem quite “odd”? Was it just in this movie?
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's easy to be shocked by "The Wolf of Wall Street." In fact, that's almost of the point of the film.One scene best illustrates the excesses of the film: Leonard DiCaprio, as the titular fraudulent Wolf, Jordon Belfort, is on his yacht, surrounded by a lobster lunch, several prostitutes and his next dose of cocaine,when he receives a call from his more clean-cut friend and business partner, warning him that a prominent client is selling his shares. It appears to be a contrast between the indulgent Belfort and a straight-laced foil until an instant later, Belfort's partner snorts a line of coke off his company desk ... and then runs back to snort a second one.This latest film from Martin Scorsese tells the tale of Jordon Belfort, a real-life New York stockbroker who rose to--and fell from--the excesses of riches, fame, sex and drugs. The shock and awe it stirs in audiences isn't necessarily to moralize and decry, but it isn't to praise either, which separates the film from most modern blockbusters.Belfort's illegal dealings take him from a penny-stock postition to his own firm, which eventually earns him almost a million a week. He constantly spends money on his addictive lifestyle, whether he has it or not.Throughout the film, the benefits of cheating and lying are tempered by the detriments. Both of Belfort's marriages sour. He's left scrambling to cover up his illegal activities in the wake, eventually getting more or less what he deserves for the activities his own father rightly and frequently labels "obscene."toastyWhat's really obscene is how often this actor toasts people.A three-hour run time doesn't hurt the pacing, and the strong performances--notably from DiCaprio and Jonah Hill, as his right-hand man--ensure that the film is gripping. The excesses of the story are embodied well by the stylized film, especially by the catchy and eclectic soundtrack during a huge storm at sea.The film even sucks the audience in on a meta level, as Belfort's machinations jump from a narration to a fourth-wall-breaking dialogue at the camera to a scene where his private thoughts are heard. The "rise and fall" story is common: everyone knows what's coming as Belfort brags, but that knowledge only builds the suspense.I've seen too many films praising crude behavior (read: anything based on a Mark Millar comic book) and too many films moralizing against it (read: the entire Christian film industry). It's disarming to see one that manages to do neither.The movie portrays Belfort's accomplishments as impressive, which they undoubtedly are. But it neither judges nor praises the man's obvious flaws, an accomplishment that is undoubtedly the film's most impressive.There are two main ways to leave the theater--with the blood racing through your veins, high on the adrenaline rush Scorcese so graphically put you through. Or depressed and disgusted with the pure greed and massive debauchery fest; a rat race of gain by greedy, callous rascals who already have more than everything. The film is crafted to be compelling: the audience is not just left to make up their minds themselves; they are forced to.Those of you who shy away from three hours of drug-and-sex fueled debacle should of course avoid this film. To the few dozen of you left, "The Wolf of Wall Street" can give you perhaps the most interesting perspective on an entertaining biography: a perspective with no moral agenda.
summary: A gripping film that makes gives the audience as many excesses as the Wolf himself

reviewText: When I first saw previews for this film, I thought it looked fairlydecent. From the quick-fire clips it seemed like this would be a funnymovie with plenty of serious sides with a good-natured sprinkling ofsex appeal (i.e women in skimpy lingerie or even perhaps topless).Within the first fifteen to thirty minutes of watching it, I came torealize just how incredibly wrong I was. Now, I can appreciateutilizing sex and drugs to make your point in a movie, such as Scorsesedid with Good Fellas and Casino, but what he did with this movie was golight years beyond overboard. I don't think it's any kind of anexaggeration to say that 3/4 of this movie is about absolutely nothingother than doing extremely copious amounts of drugs, acting like abunch of lunatics from an insane asylum, and having sex with anythingthat possessed the right biology. Oh, and of course, let's not forgetthe fact that the male leads are completely disrespectful anddisgusting to every single woman that enters their lives, includingtheir wives. Someone mentioned in an earlier review that this movie wasreminiscent of the ancient Roman orgies, but I honestly think theRomans would have far better decorum than this film. All it seemed todo was showcase the absolute worst kind of sociopaths society has tooffer without them being psychopathic serial killers. They even comeclose to doing that when the lead character decides it's a grand ideato snort a half a ziploc bag full of cocaine, put his four-year-olddaughter in the front seat of his car, and go screaming out of thegarage in reverse before slamming into a brick light post. Let me justsay that thankfully the people who made this film did not depict thelittle girl being injured despite what looks to be an incrediblypainful whiplash. If they had, I would have simply shut the movie offand never watched it again, regardless of how it might have ended.Let me just say this movie has no redeeming qualities to it. The sheervolume of quite graphic full-frontal nudity, sex, and drug use wouldprobably be enough to make even the raunchiest frat boy look at hisbuddy and ask, "Is this all there is with this thing?" The fact thatthis movie received so many accolades, award nominations, and evenwins, makes me truly despise how pathetic of a turn our society hasmade. To glorify this kind of completely insanity, to make heroes outof complete sociopaths and psychopaths, to say that everything they didis just fine because it's entertaining is all the more reason for me tojustifiably feel that the way our society currently operates needs toend.Do not throw your money away to even rent this "film" and become yet another one of Belfort's victims by giving him even more money to spend on exactly what is portrayed in the film (the man is still collecting royalties on both the film and the book, both of which were based on his life). My suggestion is you boycott it, and suggest others do the same. I don't know if I want to see another DeCaprio or Scorsese film after this one.

reviewText: Are there really people out there that live outside the envelope, that try to create a world under their own rules with no morality, no sense of right and wrong?  For most of us these are alien people but if they exist, you wonder what in the world is really going on and it could make you mad as heck.  DiCaprio's character is in no way one you ever feel sympathy for, he  and is not intended to be, He lives in world of his own creation and even as you know there will be those trying to bring him down, you might wonder if perhaps ordinary living is a waste of time and if maybe the other side is a better way to live.  Part of the reason I don't give the film a higher rating is that it is a disturbing, maybe too close to a sleazy reality I don't like to think about.  Perhaps that makes it a good film and my personal bias is working. Judge for yourself but don't expect to find the answers spoon fed to you.
summary: Bizarre...are there people out there really like this?

reviewText: This movie has struck a nerve in millions of people, and many of them have reacted negatively to it. In my opinion it is a mistake to rate a movie negatively because one disapproves of the BEHAVIOR of the characters. Well, this movie is all about the downward spiral of a team of stock brokers whose wild success in the market drives them to drugs, sex, debauchery, dirty language, and the like. Can this theme be presented in a well-made movie, or does the nature of the theme PREVENT the director and the actors from ever presenting it in a good movie? Well, this is a masterpiece of a movie! The acting is superb all the way through by all characters. Plot is intricate and moves fast. It presents a realistic view of what can happen to some people when they strike it rich, like the characters here. Special mention goes to DiCaprio: incredible acting over a wide range of situations. Two negative points, though. (1) This is really a movie for adults. There are sex scenes and there is female full frontal nudity. (2) Three hours long. Geez, I could hardly get up from the couch. Overall, 5 Stars. Incredible film!
summary: Greed & Raunch Themes Brilliantly Presented. A Masterpiece!

reviewText: I probably would have skipped over this one but I thought if Leonardo di Caprio starred in it, I'd give it a shot. reviewText: A biopic directed by Martin Scorsese about the rise and fall of one Jordan Belfort, a Wall Street stock broker who founded in the 1980s a brokerage firm that centered on selling penny stocks using high pressure tactics to small investors. He was indicted for fraud in 1998 and was sentenced for a relatively lenient 22 months in prison. The amoral, drug addicted Belfort is played by Leonardo Di Caprio (this is his fifth film for Scorsese); Jonah Hill is Belfort's main sidekick, Donnie. The Australian actress Margot Robbie is great as the blond bombshell - dumb model - trophy second wife of Belfort. Rob Reiner has an unnecessary extended cameo as Belfort's father. Though the subject matter is certainly interesting and the acting is fine, this film, despite its undeniable brio, is also quite unpleasant with its three hour non stop show of drug use and sordid sex. The movie is very repetitive: we see sex, drug use, a joke involving oral sex, sex, drug use, etc. Moreover, the movie has no characters one can sympathize – everybody is extremely unpleasant (well, maybe with the exception of the FBI agent played by Kyle Chandler, but he appears in the screen for only a little time). Jean Dujardin (the silent movie star from The Artist) has a nice cameo as a venal, corrupt Swiss banker.
summary: Well acted and with an interesting subject matter, but too long, repetitive and unpleasant
Title: N/A

reviewText: Exploitation is something that happens a lot in movies.  Bodies are exploited.  Heroics are exploited.  The audience is exploited.  We sit back and indulge in reckless behavior from the safety of a theater seat and allow the exploitation to envelop us, knowing that we are free from the harmful effects of said exploitation because ‘it’s only a movie’.  The question that comes up then is, when is this theatrical exploitation dangerous to the audience?  When is too far, too far?  Where is the line that has to be drawn and when is enough, enough?  Is enough ever enough?  Is there such a thing as ‘too far’?Wouldn’t ‘too far’ constitute a breach in our freedom of speech and our ability to create ‘art’?Personally, I’ve asked myself this question very few times.  At the end of the day, I don’t feel that there should be such a thing as ‘too far’ because it tears at the very fabric of our societies lust for art.  If we handicap our artists, what are we left with?  In all honesty, sometimes we have to wade through the things we can’t stand to be able to enjoy the gems we cherish so much.Handicap one, handicap all.But, the conversation of exploitation can be focused on another facet of film.  All too often we think of exploitation in a purely carnal light, and in that sense it can be rampant, but twice this year I’ve seen films that shine that exploitative light in another direction.  Sure, the carnality of it all is still very prevalent, but it isn’t the sole focal point, at least not how you’d expect.  No, I’m not talking about the exploitative nature of ‘Spring Breakers’ bounty of flesh and debauchery, although ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’ is pretty much on par with that film as far as flesh and debauchery are concerned (and maybe even more so) but I’m talking about a deeper, more provocative exploitation; the exploitation of moral deprivation.  I saw this also in the critically acclaimed documentary ‘The Act of Killing’, and I see it here; a film that shines a light on the immoral center of human beings and dares to exploit it, creating within it a sense of glorification that can be off-putting to say the least.While I have voiced my clear concerns for the way that ‘The Act of Killing’ presented it’s points, I have to say that ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’ was not nearly as offensive in tone.  This is partly a good thing and also party because of the film’s own failings, but I’ll get to that in a minute.First, the hoopla surrounding this film had a lot to do with the fact that Jordan Belfort ruined the lives of MANY people and then, even after being arrested, wound up serving nowhere near the time he was initially supposed to serve and wound up writing a best-selling novel, and a lot of people felt that adapting that novel was giving him unfair publicity and thus lining his pockets with money he wasn’t entitled too.  I’m not going to form an opinion on this.  Movies are made about unsavory characters all the time.  We, the public, tend to gravitate towards stories about ordinary people doing terrible things because we feel this connection to it somehow.  There is humanity in imperfection, and we can relate or at least form an assertive opinion, one way or the other.Bottom line is, Jordan Belfort’s story, no matter how hurtful to those he victimized, is interesting.But then came all the reviews claiming that this film was glorifying Jordan’s actions and basically exploiting his moral deprivation, making him this horrible person we can root for because his life was just so much fun.  I don’t see this at all.  Yes, this is shot like a black comedy and it is VERY explicit with all the so-called ‘fun’ aspects of Jordan’s life, but it never glorifies anything.  In fact, the entire film basically makes Jordan Belfort look like a gigantic loser.  While he starts off a young man with ambition and morals, he is corrupted by the men in his profession and by the greed that engulfs those in the position to be greedy and he winds up becoming a loathsome creature.  Yes, he is having a good time, but I never once watching his actions and thought ‘I wish that was me’.  He looked like a buffoon.  He was a rich buffoon (and God in heaven knows I wanted all his money), but his actions were repulsive.The corruption that circled his life was never once shielded from our eyes.And yes, the plight of the victims is avoided entirely here, and I can see the criticism there.  It is in that vein that my main complaint comes (or at least they are associated).There was something missing.While all of the debauchery surely took up a lot of space on the screen (and a lot of film), I’m not quite sure Martin Scorsese’s points were clear enough.  This is where I feel that the film’s failings.  You see, I wasn’t too keen on the way that ‘The Act of Killing’ presented its points and yet, at least I felt like it had points to present.  Here, it doesn’t feel like there is a solid foundation for Scorsese’s tale.  As a story of one man’s worldwide deception, it is an exciting and hilarious romp, but as a moral character study, it is lacking the depth it needed.  It all feels somewhat devoid of a point, and while some will baulk at this and find clear moral center points in aspects of the film (Belfort’s last speech to his company where he turns his “goodbye” into an invigoration is quite telling to the nature of these people and the people that buy into their so-called ‘lives’) but at the end of the day there is an emptiness here that I feel like Scorsese should have been able to fill.Still, the film is a high-octane depiction of the effects of greed and how they can deteriorate an individual and the lives of the people around him, and how money cannot buy you happiness, even if you can afford to throw lobsters at people.The film is also anchored by two brilliant performances.  Both Leonardo DiCaprio and Jonah Hill handle the film’s toxic comedy with such ease that it gives the film an added layer of authenticity.  Despite the bounty of preposterous, the film always feels accessible and realistic because of their fearless performances.  They thrust themselves into every scene and create an air of atmosphere that serves as the tone for the entire film.  In fact, the entire cast is up to the task, and even the small cameo roles from the likes of Matthew McConaughey, Jean Dujardin and Joanna Lumley are remarkable and necessary.  And newcomer Margot Robbie is a STONE-COLD-FOX!Maybe the film should be faulted for being fun, but I can’t fault it for that since I never felt that the fun made the actions acceptable.  We are never once going to condone Belfort’s actions.  And while one may say “you are ok with this but have a problem with ‘The Act of Killing’?” and to them I say, genres are tricky things and for me, as a documentary, ‘The Act of Killing’ had more to live up to, because it is not merely viewed as a medium for entertainment.

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is a caricature of movies like Wall Street (1987) and Boiler Room (2000). It's so over-the-top that you will laugh your pants off at how ridiculous these people are. To sum this movie up in three words: drugs, hookers, and fraud.Watching Leonardo DiCaprio play this real life story onscreen reveals how charismatic, persuasive, and insane Jordan Belfort really was. The level of mob mentality at Stratton Oakmont must have rivaled Jim Jones and the People's Temple right before the Kool-Aid incident. Given the amount of coke, pills, orgies, and out-of-control salespeople onscreen, it's hard to imagine that this was based on a true story. But it is.This movie is just as much a cynical commentary on Wall Street stockbrokers and their lives of excess as it is a sad and often funny look into the downward spiral that accompanies rich druggies. At one point, Jordan swallows 4 to 5 Lemmon 714's, the strongest Quaalude ever created. After 90 minutes of no high, the expired drug triggers its time released properties all at once and unload on him like a dump truck full of bricks. Jordan crawls and rolls out of a country club like a demented cerebral palsy patient in a scene reminiscent of the Ether trip in Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas. It's moments like this that make The Wolf of Wall Street comic gold.In the end, the inevitable happens. Jordan Belfort is sent to Club Fed for the outrageous pump and dump scheme that was Stratton Oakmont. His trophy wife Naomi packs her bags, takes the kids, and heads for greener pastures. The real Jordan makes a brief cameo during the end of the movie as he introduces Leonardo DiCaprio's character to a packed room of seminar attendees looking to sharpen their sales skills. Overall, The Wolf of Wall Street is one epic portrayal of greed and its consequences.

reviewText: Scorsese clearly believes he can play it both ways with this movie. He wants to make a searing statement about corporate greed while at the same time giving a nudge and wink to the good ol' boys on Wall Street and their excessive, outrageous behaviour. Sorry, Mr Scorsese but you are far too enamoured with this man and his cronies to have the critical distance needed to make a worthwhile film. There's nothing "satirical" about this film. In the end it is merely a glorification of greed and excess, portrayed by cardboard characters going through the motions of a tedious, repetitive plot. After the shock value wears off in the first 20 minutes The Wolf of Wall Street is a "hollow spectacle" as the WSJ review so aptly stated.What makes it especially offensive is the fact that the world economy was brought to its knees by exactly the kind of reckless behaviour glorified in the film and yet there is barely any mention of Jordan Belfort's victims, many of them small-time investors who trusted him with their life savings (Scorsese said in an interview that he didn't want to take the focus off Belfort, which is a major cop-out that doesn't even make sense. How can you really understand this man's story without knowing how his actions impacted on others?). There is however a scene where Belfort points out how generous he was to a single mother who had nothing when she started working with him, but now holidays in the Bahamas. Is this Scorsese's idea of balance? The fact that he turned on his colleagues to avoid a jail sentence is also underplayed by showing him warning Donnie Azoff not to say anything incriminating while he is wearing a wire.Belfort suffers no serious consequences for his predatory, self-interest and this is emphasised at the end when his is shown playing tennis in his pleasant low-security prison. The straight-shooting FBI agent on the other hand who helps prosecute him is left to take the subway home with all of the "losers." The rapt audience hanging off Belfort's every word in the final scene shows that he is now profiting handsomely from his infamy. After blatantly glorifying this despicable man, Scorsese thinks he has the right to pull back at this point and lecture the audience on how manipulative he is to people desperate to make money, but you can't have your cake and eat it too, Mr Scorsese. The huge boost given to Belfort by the film will allow him to go on profiting and swindling people with impunity thanks to your fawning portrayal.The group of motley associates Belfort pulls together when he is starting his own company are straight out of central casting and their idiotic behaviour and celebration of "getting wasted" made me feel like I was watching The Hangover. How can you make a serious comment about society with such a bunch of caricatures? Scorsese repeatedly goes for the easy laughs and cheap gags, designed to make the audience feel affection for these characters, despite their debauchery and greed. This is especially true of Donnie Azoff. Don't even get me started on the portrayal of women.In the right hands The Wolf of Wall Street could have been a truly compelling story. As it stands though, based on the memoir of an egomaniac intent on white-washing his own culpability, it's nothing more than a piece of fluff, lacking in any kind of dramatic tension, irony or character development. The fact that it was nominated for an Oscar speaks volumes about the state of the film industry today. It's so heartening to see that there are almost as many one-star ratings for it on Amazon as five-star, showing that people are not as easily won over by this degrading spectacle as the so-called critics who have embraced it.

reviewText: Wildly misunderstood and harshly judged movie.  this is Scorsese's best since the departed (and my 2nd favorite of his movies)  get this movie if you enjoy great stories, compelling characters, and a solid hilarious crime/drama.  do not buy this if you are an obnoxious middle-aged woman who has nothing better to do other than complain about foul language and sexual content in movies. reviewText: When I heard that Martin Scorsese's new film would star Leonardo DiCaprio, I was overjoyed. Over the past decade, he has established himself as one of the most iconic actors of our generation and his performance in "The Wolf of Wall Street" furthers that even more. With a run time of over three hours, it packs a huge punch.The new movie centers on the true story of Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio), an up-and-coming stockbroker in Wall Street. Befriending Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill), he decides to open his own firm, recruiting several of his personal friends. Their firm, Stratton Oakmont, soon becomes a billion-dollar company. Selling stocks that they know will lose their client's money, their corruption and ongoing greed soon catches up to them.With plenty of its graphic moments that aren't fit for the kids, Scorsese holds nothing back, creating an interesting atmosphere and throwing you directly into this world. DiCaprio and Hill are an eccentric duo, and their performances pop off the screen. Rated R for sequences of strong sexual content, drug use and language, "The Wolf of Wall Street" is crazy good. It is now playing in theaters everywhere.

reviewText: I read the book and saw the movie. I will say, it's pretty much impossible not to love Dicaprio. The real Jordan Belfort...not so much.The movie is fast paced and intriguing, though you don't quite get the scope of the horrible things Belfort did to people. In the movie he's more of an anti-hero. In real life he was just a bad person who didn't care who's life he ruined to get ahead. You find yourself on Dicaprio's side, because you like him. But when I read the book, I got a different feeling altogether. I despised Belfort's arrogance and the way he swindled people without the blink of an eye. His right hand man, Danny Porush (played by Jonah hill, with a slight name change) was probably more despicable then Belfort in real life. But again, in the movie, I loved Jonah Hill, because the the actor himself is hilarious and impossible to dislike. Both men screwed over everyone by making a deal with the feds. People who did less, did more time. Doesn't seem right to me.The story is an intriguing one, and if you can handle the sexual content and strong language you will be intrigued by this crazy story. But just keep in mind Belfort and Porush were not people anyone should admire, and there was a much darker side to things we didn't quite see. But it's just a movie, after all.

reviewText: When I finally watched this movie, I had heard so much about how raunchy and over the top the movie was that I was expecting nudity and/or extreme drug use in every scene, but that wasn't the case.  Those things were there but not in the extremes that I was led to believe.  I really enjoyed watching this movie, and I am once again awed by the talent of Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio.  If the movie was over the top at times it was because Jordan Belforts life was.  This man was the prime example of the greed and excess that was Wall Street in the nineties.  He was not the only one who was commiting fraud and other white collar crimes, and was not the guiltiest, but he has been one of the more honest about it.  The sex and drug scenes can be startiling, but were a necessary part of the story.  I will admit that one scene with Leonardo and the Lemmon Qualudes had me laughing so hard I couldn't breathe.  I was also surprised by Jonah Hill and how good he was in this movie.  He might not just be a comedian but an actor too.  Overall I liked this movie, and will tell anyone who is thinking of watching it to form their own opinion and do not let the opinions of others influence your choice.
summary: Don't let the other reviews influence you too much

reviewText: Nice to see somebody had the foresight to save Quualudes across the decades, and these guys had them in spades. And coke. And anything else they could get their hands on. Curiously, no weed. What this film is is one version of the American insane asylum. It easily could have been called "The Id of New York." The satisfying of pleasure centers could not be more base without getting more twisted and perverse and probably dangerous, yet our wolf and his ilk have a moral coda and complete justification for their relentless hunt to separate others from their money. These are shlubs finally getting their grubby hands on the American dream, and we are taught in this country that capitalism is a good thing to be aspired to. So they aspire with everything they've got, and they need drugs and sex to not only tolerate the madness of their pursuit, but to fill up its vacuousness, its emptiness. These things are also the spoils of a rich person's depravity. "The Wolf of Wall Street" ranks among DiCaprio's best performances, and he appears to be growing mightily as an actor. He toggles tragically between the sordidness of his own unleashed id and the desire to be a good husband, father and provider. He is a motivator, a rationalizer, a fighter, a failure. He is many things balled up into one drugged-up and -out character, and he pulls it off with magnetic power. I am not sure if this is a good movie or not, but it's riveting and toward the end even funny. The only missteps are the extended improvs with Jonah Hill, which feel completely out of place and forced representations of mayhem. Hill has his moments, to be sure, as does Marty, with this cockamamie vision. A vision that says, our compass is spinning wildly out of control.

reviewText: I think the treatment of this film is very unfair.Yes, the film is vulgar, it is shocking, and it is offensive, but guess what......so are the characters.  They are greedy, morally reprehensible characters, but this film does not reward them.  In this film, they are the butt of the joke.  A very angry joke.  If you can't see that, and only see the cussing, the drug use, and the sex, then maybe this is not a film for you.  I found it wildly funny, and I for one am happy Mr. Belfort, while not dismissing the film, is unhappy with various ways in which he was depicted (even though he still tries to get publicity from it).  Unlike the system, this film does not let him off the hook.I do think it's fair to say this film should be NC 17 though.  How it got an R, I'll never know.  That being said, any ad or poster for this film clearly states the following: This movie is rated R for "sequences of strong sexual content, graphic nudity, drug use and language throughout, and for some violence." If you like angry, bitter satire, give it a shot.  If you are part of the easily offended, and can't tolerate any of the content listed above, then do us all a favor, and don't watch.  Don't even try. Don't put it on , only to take it out after an hour or less, and get on the website to write a review.  If you can't watch the whole film, don't write a review.  No one is brilliant enough to watch an hour or less of a 3 hour movie and completely judge it.Had to chime a review because there are tons of people out there who just don't get it.

reviewText: You know a satire is effective when it provokes such a caustic response from folks. Now, children should not see this movie, I agree, but you might also allow that neither should children (nor anyone, for that matter) be subjected to the harsh fiscal realities worsening every year in America at the hands of the greedy egotists on Wall St. That's the point of satire--to shock and disturb an audience for the purpose of real productive change. So, if you agree with those fairly obvious assertions, kindly step away from the mic when your more refined sensibilities are tortured, as they will be for any moral person seeing the movie. Then again, don't people ritualistically watch passion plays at Easter, and isn't that more awful to ingest. Yet, one might endure it for the feeling of gaining a greater understanding of Christ's divinity.In the media and online, or I guess anywhere that idiots can take over, there will always be the addressing of sensationalism blown through trumpets loud for all to be stupefied and distracted, but I urge true lovers of cinema and satire to spend the shortest three hours you'll sit through all year watching Scorsese's latest high-water mark "Wolf of Wall Street". Maybe we can embrace this satire as reportage, it is, after all, based on a man's biography, and finally mobilize as a culture to drive out these punk cokeheads from the positions of power they currently enjoy in our economy. "Wolf" is intended to function as that type of catalyst, so get your satire right. When irony, hyperbole and inversion function so prominently in a piece, don't try to access the work as moralistic parable, which it is not. That's about as daft as complaining about Disney cartoons not being dark and violent enough.So, wifey and I give this nasty, overlong film a solid '5' stars. It has something to say, unlike almost everything else this year, and you might just feel cozy postering Jordan Balfour up as the new face of all you hate about 'Merica. I know I do.
summary: Leave yer panties at the door, ladies...

reviewText: Next to the real Jordan Belfort’s memoir of the same name, I wouldn’t be the least bit surprised if Martin Scorsese and screenwriter Terrence Winter (screenwriter for Scorsese’s hit television series Boardwalk Empire) turned to Motley Crue’s The Dirt for inspiration to film The Wolf of Wall Street.Yes, as far as Jordan Belfort’s lifestyle of decadence and debauchery are concerned, I’m dead serious: it comes that close. Recently, The Wolf of Wall Street won the title of being the non-commentary film with the record of having the most usage of the F word: next to, among other things, gay and lesbian sex. The list goes on and on. But, at least Scorsese and Winter are being honest. To the best of their knowledge, that is: many sources have confirmed that when Jordan Belfort wrote his two memoirs (The Wolf of Wall Street and Catching the Wolf of Wall Street), he told things from a slanted perspective: giving “glory” to himself by calling himself “The Wolf of Wall Street,” and simply writing out of bias, a.k.a. not making himself look like such a low-life scumbag. (When many of his fellow and former colleagues know him well enough to reveal that he was much more of a monster than he revealed himself to be.)So, with all of this being said, why have I given four stars to The Wolf of Wall Street?The reasoning is quite complex, to be honest. We all know—as one of my favorite authors has stated—that we value, in story, the conflict we avoid in life. Second, we all remember the fun we had watching Oliver Stone’s two Wall Street films: getting inside looks at Wall Street and her corruption, wrapped around adventures that we saw ensemble casts indulged in. That is, in its own beautiful, original way, the same present given to us by Martin Scorsese with The Wolf of Wall Street.Basing his film off of Jordan Belfort’s memoir by the same name, and shooting with over 90% accuracy (if you’ve never read the real Mr. Belfort’s book, you can find details online of the real and fictionalized events in his film), Scorsese primarily depicts the “pump and dump” scam that sent Jordan Belfort to prison, and the series of events that led up to Belfort’s arrest. We see every step of the scam, all the behind-the-scenes details, and how Jordan Belfort’s life fell apart in the midst of everything, most notably with his love life. If you are not a stock broker, you probably won’t understand much of what is going on, but you don’t have to. That, in my opinion, is what makes the suspense of The Wolf of Wall Street so solid. There’s plenty of comedy, courtesy of Jonah Hill, who also shows an admirable backbone for serious acting ***at the same exact time***. Combine diverse talents like Hill with diverse talents like Leonardo DiCaprio and Martin Scorsese (even if Scorsese does not show it very often, he certainly proved it with Hugo), and with The Wolf of Wall Street, you have a unique, admirable piece of artwork, aside from all of the profanity.An important note: I’ve heard many people say that they felt The Wolf of Wall Street glorified the lifestyle of Jordan Belfort and those who aided him in his fraud and debauchery. When I first entered the movie theater, I got the same impression. Towards the end of the film, however, Martin Scorsese goes full-blown in showing the consequences of the fraud and debauchery. In real life, Jordan Belfort did not get off scot-free…and he does not get off scot-free in his own film adaptation, either.Not for everyone, but if you enjoyed Oliver Stone’s Wall Street series and/or are a fan of Leonardo DiCaprio, Martin Scorsese, and their frequent collaborations, The Wolf of Wall Street is definitely for you.
summary: Entertaining and extreme? Martin Scorsese hits the mark-at a close miss.

reviewText: I knew a guy once who was a stockbroker.  Let's just say that he wasn't "ethically malleable" enough to handle it.  So, he quit that gig and went and sold some other garbage that's probably worth even less than stocks to other people who didn't need that garbage either.  Hey, taking other people's money is what makes the world go 'round.Of course, I'm being a little facetious, but there is some truth to the first paragraph.  In reality, how many jobs out there exist where employees are completely honest, even ethical, most of the time?  My experience:  almost none.  If you want to be ethical, become a nun and go join a convent; but just try to keep your grimy fingers out of the tithing plate.And this would be the position of Leonardo DiCaprio in "The Wolf of Wall Street."  For the life of me, I cannot understand how this guy hasn't yet won an Academy Award.  Maybe he doesn't have compromising pictures on any of the members?  Who knows?  But it is the case that the Academy likes politically-correct garbage from politically-correct actors for the most part, and Mr. DiCaprio seems to avoid those roles at all costs.  And to him I say, "Attaboy!  Do you want to work at McDonalds, or do you want to make some real money?"And he surely earned his money here, playing a character that would make Gordon Gekko blush.  Holy smokes.  Excess?  What's more than that?  Excess plus?  And that's what we get here with a character who, with any lesser acting talent, could have made this film go completely off the rails.  Somehow, Mr. DiCaprio makes you believe that a character such as this did really exist, which is a feat in itself.If you don't like films with nudity, this film's not for you.  If you don't like films with foul language, this film's not for you.  And if you don't like films that are really terrific, this film's not for you.  I'm going with a very strong recommendation for non-stop chaos that will make your jaw drop, when that jaw's not laughing hysterically the rest of the time.  And to the Academy?  Give Mr. DiCaprio his due already, won't you?  After all, he's made you lots of money himself so toss him an award already.

reviewText: I delayed seeing this movie because I'd heard such horrible things about it: that it glamorized the dirtiest sorts of financiers, that these monsters didn't pay for any of their crimes against salt-of-the-earth folks, that it was just one oversized, overzealous and overwrought bacchanal of drugs, hookers and sociopathy for the members of The Unholy Church of Our Lady of the One-Percent. Alas, the other night, I had one beer too many and was in the mood for something kind of greasy, so I threw caution to the wind and rented The Wolf Of Wall Street and, mea culpa, I really enjoyed it.The central focus of the film is the dubious "rise" of Jordan Belfort, king of the penny stock, and the merry band of heartless beasts he brings along for his wing-melting ride to the sun. Yeah, there's cussing, there's nudity, there's fraud, there's enough drug use to grate on the last nerve of a dyed-in-the-wool Hunter Thompson acolyte. And for half of the film's ample (perhaps excessive) three-hour running time, that's pretty much what you see. Jordan recruits this cur and that hellion...then he makes this deal and burns that little, old lady out of her pension...all so he might know the pleasure of wrecking a $300,000 sports car while getting road-head and snorting coke-powdered boogers into the depths of his brain.Only insofar as it appears that Belfort (DiCaprio) is having fun could one argue that Scorsese is making his life look sexy. I truly don't envy someone that drinks a bottle full of high-powered quaaludes before flying a helicopter wonkily away from a party filled with his peers: criminals and skanks, most of whom are sleeping in their own vomit. I don't see things like that and think "...ohh, the GLAMOUR!..." hence, I had a hell of a time seeing how this movie made Belfort's life of overpriced explosions that left craters behind his every step appealing, although some reviewers panned the movie heartily for just that.The other negative reviews come from those who were more offended at Belfort & Company's collective desire to all but anthropomorphize vice and become its favorite Porta-Potty. There aren't a mere one or two scenes of depravity, oh no. They are virtually beyond counting. Nevertheless, I find it rather bizarre that this is a griping point. It would be kinda like going to see a slasher film and whining afterward about all of the nasty murders and gore. Anyone who has even passing knowledge of social mores on Wall Street knows that s*** like this used to happen all of the time, and probably still does. This movie might be gross, it might be amoral or even immoral...most damning of all, though, I'm certain it's entirely on target. And I bet Scorsese was more concerned with being honest about his subject rather than with being nice to an audience. Wild guess.As the film crosses its halfway point, Belfort still parties like a lunatic and has tons-o-fun, however, it starts taking its toll and his destructiveness draws the attention and the ire of people who would like to see his non-stop orgy, funded by comparative innocents, get shut down permanently. And so begins Belfort's well-deserved and curiously moving (bravo to the acting chops of DiCaprio) fall back to Earth. And what a landing it is.This movie isn't flawless. It's not groundbreaking. But it's pretty damned good and likely very, very true. Hell, Matthew McConaughey's "Money Chant" alone is worth the price of admission. If you think your virgin eyes and ears can take it, give The Wolf Of Wall Street a whirl, and watch it all the way to the end. It's worth it.

reviewText: I have a lot to say, but little time to say it. I heard a lot of bad things about this film before I saw it--that it celebrates greed and vulgarity and so forth. But actually, it does exactly the opposite. Just as another Scorsese film, Goodfellas (which this film clearly echoes), does not ultimately celebrate Mob life, The Wolf of Wall Street does not celebrate greed and vulgarity. That's why it makes you squirm. You're not supposed to be admiring this guy. You're supposed to be disgusted by him. His jaw-dropping greed and ostentatious lifestyle reflect the character's values, not the filmmaker's. The filmmaker is making a point, here. When you see the main character snorting coke from some hooker's butt crack early in the film, Scorsese is pretty much spelling it out for you.
summary: An Excellent Look at the Face of Unbridled Greed

reviewText: i saw this film during awards season and i can see why it is doing well on that circuit.  This is a very black and darkly satiric look  at the horrible people who made tons of money illegally because of their practices on Wall Street. It is similar to the director's scathing look at mob guys in GOODFELLAS.  Both films were biographies of very bad guys, GOODFELLAS of mob guy Henry Hill who went into witness protection and WOLF OF WALL STREET of Jordan Belford whose crimes were all financial instead of murder. Ray Liotta was the lead in GOODFELLAS and Leonardo DiCaprio is the lead in WOLF. It helps to know that the director was a victim of one of these wall street sharks so that has presumably influenced his artistic choices in making this film.Unlike GOODFELLAS, on the awards circuit WOLF is being primarily seen as a comedy and especially DiCaprio's performance. He has already won the Golden Globe for best actor in a comedy for WOLF. Now he is up for the Oscar with it although comedic roles rarely win at the Oscars.Although initially very tough to watch (because I hated every single person), the movie gradually worked its magic on me and by the midpoint I was indeed laughing.  I would have never taken a bet that this movie could make me laugh had I not made it to the mid point. But DiCaprio positively revels in this role and is willing to do whatever is necessary to develop the role to its fullest extent. There is one scene where he is so high on qualludes that he has to crawl to his car from his country club's lobby.  That crawl to the car is just genius. Also, his attempt to get to a Swiss bank using his own yacht on the high seas during a major storm becomes utter bedlam.Basically, what it gets down to, is whether you are a Martin Scorsese fan or not.  If you have loved all of his films, as I have, then strap yourself into your seat, and get ready for some leading edge cinema, as per usual.
summary: scorsese and dicaprio collaboration up for most major film awards as per usual

reviewText: Disclaimer: I turned off after hour two, planning to resume later but never did...This film at 3 hours long could have been much more sophisticated with better character development. The first two hours were essentially like watching a National Lampoons movie about a frat house, except the characters are rich and the acting is better.Main character played by DiCaprio starts out a "good guy". Rather than exploiting the 3-hours to show a gradual evolution from straight-laced over-achiever to maniacal, sex- and drug-obsessed white collar criminal, the film simply jettisons the character from the former to the latter, so the audience doesn't get a chance to feel bad for him, or to fondly remember what he used to be, or to think of him as the product of his environment, instead he's just another punk who's gotten rich by stepping on other people.I think the director wants us to like or at least pity this character, but it's hard to when he is so one-dimensional.Also it seemed to also be trying to mix in a mob theme at times but this was inconsistent. There were times when I felt like I was watching a present-day Casino or Good Fellas, but it was missing the substance that both those films had, and the conflict of simultaneously liking and despising the characters.So why, might you ask, am I giving this film 3-stars? For one, I didn't watch the last hour and will give it the benefit of the doubt that it would have regained my interest at some point. Two, acting was very good all around. Three, it made me chuckle multiple times. Four, it didn't try to be politically correct.
summary: Too long, poor character development, but solid acting all around

reviewText: Derivative of two better films -- Goodfellas and Boiler Room -- The Wolf of Wall Street disappointed.  DiCaprio is charming as Jordan Belfort, a drug addicted super salesman.  Jonah Hill is sometimes funny as his vice-pres sidekick.  But the film doesn't dig very deeply into Jordan's character or the business that he dominates.  We simply see him as a super motivator for his sales force, and leap to him making tens of millions.  We don't get a sense of how he really does it.  As for the excesses, it's done better in other films; even the quaalude scene wasn't original.  Albert Brooks did a much funnier quaalude scene in Modern Romance.  It was a sloppy film, with many 'easy' scenes of DiCaprio over-acting.  Given the filmmaker's talent -- and the talent of the cast -- this movie gets a 'D' from me.
summary: Goodfellas meets Boiler Room -- (and it isn't good)

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is a great movie about the excess of securities fraud and corruption on Wall Street in the 1990s. The Wolf of Wall Street is a 2013 black comedy directed by Martin Scorsese, based on the autobiography of Jordan Belfort's memoir of the same name.The screenplay was written by Terence Winter (Boardwalk Empire creator). The film stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Jordan Belfort also features Jonah Hill, Margot Robbie, Matthew McConaughey, Kyle Chandler, Rob Reiner, Jon Favreau, and Jean Dujardin. It is the fifth collaboration between Scorsese and DiCaprio, and the second between Scorsese and Winter following Boardwalk Empire. The movie shows that excesses of Money. Power. Women. and Drugs. I really enjoyed this movie and would definitely recommend it to others.Thank you for reading my review.
summary: The Wolf of Wall Street is a great movie about the excess of securities fraud and corruption that took place on Wall Street

reviewText: Unfortunately, Wolf is scripted in the same first person narrative fashion as Goodfellas, Casino and other much better films by Martin. Unlike the others, however, Wolf fails to get a strong story underlying the classic overhead shots and close pans that are Marty's trademarks.  I believe this is the reason that the Academy members objected so vehemently to their private showing of this film: it is drugs and lewd content without so much as a wire coat hanger to hang it upon.  Never is there any tension, never is there a build up to a crescendo.  The faint glimmer of hope for the movie, when the Feds catch on to Jordan, comes at ninety minutes into this bloated fish, and sure enough, the impact is no more than a popcorn fart in a bottle.It lacks the background (e.g Henry Hill as a boy in Goodfellas) on which to hinge a story.  Even Jordan's father (Rob Reiner) is forgettable, not a strong anti-Jordan to Jordan's over-the-top behavior.  Any tension--from Jordan's father, from the Feds earlier in the movie, from his colleagues at the firm--would have added much to the film.  In fact, his only "pushback" is from his second wife, and that comes two hours into this fat cow of a movie, and that only lasts two scenes (the last ever screw scene and the kidnapping scene).  How lamentable that this tableau of Jordan Belforte is not more movingly filmed.  Some would argue, it is what it is, it's a true story.  Well, true stories can be told in many ways, and if this was the only option, this film should have been passed on by an experienced director like Martin Scorsese.Acting alone cannot save a movie.  Leonardo is over the top, wonderful here, as he typically is.  However, he is not given a story to show character change, and thus is stunted in his portrayal by a script like a lasso.The behavior here has consequences that are meaningless, and thus, there is no movie.  A stronger story, with more ominous repercussions, told in a more closely edited manner, would have made this movie into a solid "B", rather than the "D" grade movie that it has turned out to be.  Of course, it is getting mixed reviews online, not only here but elsewhere, and will age poorly in the pantheon of Scorsese movies.  Even the lamentable Casino, because the acting was strong and the story was at least rudimentary, will fare better than Wolf in the years ahead, and that's saying a lot because Casino is awful (watch it again if one has a better recollection of it, and disappointment will reign in-- highly disappointing).Wolf:  A misstep for a great director, and in territory that is his bread-and-butter, the first person narrative of criminals.  Let's all, fans of Marty, pray that he will scribe, along with Pileggi (now 80) one final mob movie, with DeNiro (now 73) and Pesce and Liotta and the rest of the gang, showing aging mobsters still running the show (like Uncle Juni in Sopranos).  Time is running out--please, strong story.  Thanks!Wolf of Wall Street deserves the cutting reviews that it is receiving.Pass.

reviewText: I watched this atrociously powerful movie in two nights, after my wife quit after five minutes, unable to hear the f.. word sprinkled into the dialogue two out of five times. I am used to Scorsese since the times of "Taxi Driver" for paranoia, and "GoodFellas" for bloody messes and foul language. He most often delivers repulsive characters, bordering on insanity, who climb or attempt to climb the ladder of success, by means foul or fair (mostly foul), leaving in their wake a stream of crimes, and a string of victims in their destructive paths. Almost all of them are climbers, in fantasy or action. They posses a drive that catapults them to "fame," but finally they are done-in by their self-inflicted wounds. Jordan Belfort is one of them, but in terms of performance, Leonardo DiCaprio is ultimately the man who delivers for Scorsese. "No-holds-barred" performance--he does everything: cheats, forms a company with drug addicts, has sex worth of ten men (not that his cohorts are far behind), spends illogically, has the quick wit to avoid traps, but not the will or intelligence to quit when he ahead, as Rob Reiner, his dad, tells him. He divorces an average first wife, marries a smashing-looking ex-model, but lets his excesses and misguided self-confidence be the traps through which a clever fed finally throws the nets of justice around him. He ends up with a 36-months sentence, escapes the country, and goes to New Zealand, starting from scratch. No moral to it, says Scorsese in the "Extras" (a running commentary would be embarrassing); and let the viewer draw his own conclusion, DiCaprio intones, evidently pleased with his fifth collaboration with the famous director. In the movie he likens himself  to Ahab (in the f.... Moby Dick), mentions "Greek tragedy," when things go badly--while Scorsese mentions that he intended to make "An American 'Caligula,'" the notoriously repulsive "epic" by Tinto Bras in 1979, in which cruelty and sex and Bob Guccione's Penthouse pets participate. The comparisons end here, however. Scorsese's movie a tough, relentless expose of American greed and ambition with ill-gotten gains, and his work, keeping the analogies, can be compared to the pioneering "Huck Finn" of Mark Twain, and the the King and Duke, the immortal con-men that sent the standards for fleecing the nave. Moral lesson? Take it or leaving it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jordan goes through a very long winded rundown of how wealthy he is at the start of "The Wolf of Wall Street" that begins as a voiceover and evolves into a breaking-the-4th-wall sequence where the main character of the film talks to the audience; a sequence that Martin Scorsese has become notorious for. It's something that will be revisited over and over again throughout the film that usually results in Jordan cutting himself short and jumping to broader terms because according to the film's writers, "you don't give a f--- anyway.” As you realize that drugs, alcohol, and sex will take a priority over absolutely everything else in the film, Jordan does finally get to something more worthwhile when he introduces the concept of surviving on Wall Street and how an individual goes about doing that.This is around the time Matthew McConaughey comes in and while he only has a few brief scenes he's still able to leave quite an impression on the audience. McConaughey is engaging, especially in his one lengthened scene with DiCaprio in the restaurant. Their conversation about stock brokers not knowing what they're doing and the importance of masturbating and cocaine in the industry sets the film off on a high note. Jonah Hill is almost androgynous in his role as Donnie. With his wide overbite, massive glasses, terrible fashion sense, and openness of being married to his first cousin, Hill has this Pat from "Saturday Night Live" aura about him. Hill's chemistry with the rest of the cast and his on-screen presence is as engrossing as he was in "Moneyball."Stratton Oakmont is just a madhouse; a circus full of nothing but drunken tomfoolery, unclean orgies, and forgotten drugs. The Jordan Belfort character is built up as big as humanly possible, so that his fall from grace makes that much more of an impact. Scorsese seems to circle around these films that have protagonists that flourish because of their demons and their flaws while having these skeletons in their closets that they're convinced no one will ever find because they believe themselves to be invincible. These characters attempt to keep their secrets under lock and key at first, but they eventually become more cocky and egotistical until those secrets are discovered and they crash and burn because of them.Jordan Belfort has "Scarface" syndrome in the sense that he basically thinks he's this untouchable God that can get away with anything before finally being busted and never bouncing back. The highlight of the film is the cerebral palsy stage of the Lemmon 714 drug Jordan and Donnie take. Their scuffle afterward is incredible for all of the wrong reasons and is followed by a demonstration of why we have cordless phones today. The film does tend to drag in places and is fairly obnoxious the majority of the time, but actually feels somewhat sincere once Jordan is forced to step away from the company he created.The film follows this very familiar story structure. It's as if Scorsese stripped all of the mafia elements out of "Goodfellas," threw in some material about Wall Street, altered the script and cast a bit, and added a “Casino” amount of vulgarity and called it a day. It's basically broken down like this; a warped character having a dream or desire, that character slowly rising to the top, becoming overconfident while being hunted by the authorities, and then that character spiraling down from a man-made heaven. The only difference is that female characters aren't quite as intolerable in "The Wolf of Wall Street." In fact, the women are quite mellow for a Scorsese film."The Wolf of Wall Street" is a testosterone fueled, hallucinogenic fever dream driven by verbose dialogue, sweaty prostitute sex, and snorting cocaine from an unsuspecting rectum. Its plethora of similarities to "Goodfellas" weighs the film down rather than giving it a boost.

reviewText: Director Martin Scorsese’s ongoing collaboration with actor Leonardo DiCaprio has yielded highly entertaining, prestigious films (The Departed, The Aviator).  Their latest venture is the true, astonishing tale of Wall Street crook Jordan Belfort whose appetites for money, sex and drugs are a detailed observation on greed and temptation.An eager, young executive, Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio), experiences the Wall Street disaster of 1987 which wipes out investors and costs him a job.  Anxious to bounce back, he discovers the art of selling unregulated penny stocks and starts his own brokerage.  Soon he is making a lot of money often at the expense of low income earners but also wealthy clients, and with the help of some cronies including new follower, Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill), begins to expand exponentially into a major force in the financial world.  The emotional stress and pressure heighten his need for women, sex, drugs and then drugs upon drugs.  As his excessive lifestyle spirals out of control, the FBI and Securities and Exchange Commission begin investigating his company’s illegal activities that signals the beginning of the end.DiCaprio (Inception) gives his all as the out-of-control executive whose wealth is surpassed only by his defiance and greed.  It is interesting to contrast his younger, innocent broker with his later, drug addicted shark.  With maniacal fervor, he inspires and rallies a company’s corporate culture.  You are mesmerized by his bold, flamboyant salesman and yet, you look for any semblance of redeeming qualities.  In a sense, Jordan is a metaphor for our corporate society’s love of money and its ultimate corruption.Hill (Moneyball) really shows a good range as Belfort’s second in command.  Can this be the same Jonah Hill who had a supporting role in Knocked Up?  Matthew McConaughey has a memorable supporting role as a mentor to Belfort, and their scene together at a rooftop restaurant where McConaughey shows a ritual of self motivation is a hoot.Margot Robbie is well cast as the beautiful woman who captures Jordan’s heart and more.  Rob Reiner has an amusing supporting role as Jordan’s dad who sees the company as a sinking ship.  In fact two other directors, Jon Favreau and Spike Jonze, have bit parts or cameos.  Playing an FBI agent, Kyle Chandler, who has become the go-to actor for government types, is a good foil in his scenes with Jordan aboard a yacht.There are some memorable vignettes such as the outrageous attempts to smuggle millions in cash to Europe, the crazy office parties, and an especially hilariously pathetic attempt by Jordan to drive home at the same moment he has a very bad drug reaction.  When the justice system corners him, Jordan faces a decision not unlike the protagonist in Prince of the City. You know how this is going to go down, and when it does, it is an astonishing reversal of fortune.At three hours, it is constantly engaging and well paced from start to finish courtesy of veteran editor Thelma Schoonmaker.  The sweeping camera shots and rapid cuts show Scorsese at the top of his craft.  He tells much of the film through DiCaprio as narrator and voiceover.  In fact much of this film will remind you of the style and structure of his Good Fellas and Casino, and the ending recalls another Scorsese classic, The King of Comedy.Make no mistake, despite excellent performances and a strong narrative, this film has scenes that are bordering on NC17; some scenes are so over the top in suggestiveness and explicitness that it would be hard to believe if it wasn’t true.  The film’s depictions may lead some to question the filmmakers’ intent, but Scorsese, without passing judgment, wanted to honestly show greed and power at its worst in the boardroom and the bedroom.  Consider The Wolf of Wall Street as a supremely effective, cautionary tale of abuse of wealth at a time when such behavior flourished unchecked.  You might not like the passengers on this flight, but it is a fascinating ride.
summary: The Temptations of THE WOLF OF WALL STREET

reviewText: Its a good thing Scorcese decided to utilize heavy doses of humor in this depiction of a wall street trader gone rogue.  The allegedly true story is so bombastic, so over the top and the protagonist's acts so devoid of human decency that to not do so would have been obscene.  DeCaprio and an inspired cast dive in with focused abandon and make a lively and engaging film that will leave you roaring with nary a hint of guilt.  The blu ray transfer is as sharp and shimmering as an investor's giddy dreams.  I loved this movie in the theaters and love it even more on blu ray.  This is one of the top 5 movies of the past year along with, American Hustler, Dallas Buyers Club, 12 years a slave, and Philomens.

reviewText: It's a movie about excess.  Excessive everything: running time (a minute-hand shy of 3 hours); casting (Leonardo DiCaprio giving a career-best performance, Jonah Hill taking a massive pay cut to work with Scorsese); sex, drugs, rock 'n roll, midget tossing.  Everything.It's the story of Jordan Belfort, a Wall Street mogul who rises from practically nothing to practically everything, by means of scams and illicit deals.  He marries, he cheats, he pops pills and snorts drugs.  Endlessly.  Throw in a bunch of one-liners, a magnificent cameo by Matthew McConaughey, and all the guilty pleasures moral people would never dream of indulging in, and you have some of the most disturbing, yet thrilling, three hours of your life.  It all comes complete with the usual Scorsese trappings: an Oscar-worthy lead performance (seriously, DiCaprio goes all-out; it's a performance you don't usually see from an A-lister); terrific supporting roles (Hill, Jon Bernthal, Rob Reiner, Kyle Chandler, Jon Favreau, Shea Whigham, Jean Dujardin, and Margot Robbie, who makes an entrance that left quite a few jaws on the floor...oh, and she's a pretty good actress, too); back-and-forth dialogue from an award-worthy script (from Terence Winter, containing the most f-bombs in Hollywood history); and a story so incredibly disturbing and uncomfortably hilarious, you'll have trouble believing it's true.THE WOLF OF WALL STREET isn't a film for everyone.  Not hardly.  And there's a question of where Scorsese and company's sympathies lie; for sure, Belfort is never portrayed sympathetically.  Yet, as the man himself gets a cameo near the end, it leaves you wondering if Scorsese isn't commenting that, yes, normal people would like a shot at this lifestyle.  I personally disagree with that (money would be good, 'ludes not so much), but there's no doubt that Scorsese is making a valid point.  WOLF is, at its core, a great film; a study in excess, featuring stellar performances, a witty script, and a heart (albeit a little black) that is more or less in the right place...except when it isn't. Think WALL STREET by the way of a Charlie Sheen bachelor party. In other words: definitely an experience.
summary: A textbook example of over-the-top grandiosity

reviewText: The Wolf Of Wall Streeet runs 180 minutes and one minute of this film is worth more than the thousands of minutes some waste on films that Mark Whalberg turns out, Stallone vomits, or on tame outer space fictions like Gravity, which runs abut 87 minutes and this is way too long.Leonardo Di Caprio's character is shaped by his greed for Wall Street wealth the illegal way. He drinks and does drugs too much and has a lust for women that is disturbing, as his wife demonstrates in her powerful resistance to his indifference to his adultries. He is loud, and so are his alies in this odyssey that moves irrevocably toward a tragic/ comedic stint laced with the death-like face he shows over and over as the film progresses. His overdose scene is sheer brilanc as Scorsese shoews the transformation through De Caprio's face of what is going on inside his mind...very little, as the captalistic system grabs hold of him.The whole film reminded me of Faust, the philosopher who sells his soul to Satan for a life of ease and longevity and shallowness, and dies unwise, imprisoned by his own surrender to mediocrity and infantile ideas about God and death. The film suggests the beginning, middle, and end of a life morally and spiritually dead. The Wolf is dumb, to be sure, but he knows enough about basic survival to fool the so-called intelligent investors who believe in his charm, flattery, lack of wisdom, as we find out in the longevity of his existence as the wolf. He's never really caught, and one of the ways he survives is through language that others are too repressed, too fearful of the discovery that their own self descriptions as humans may summed up in the "F" word used with great purpose here, about 500 times.Scorsese 's understanding of the world we inhabit through the deadly sins others commit, makes him unique and I haven't even touched on the fabulous camera work here, the brilliant editing by Ms. Schoonmaker and the score.When is the last time you sat in front of the TV for three hours or more and came away with only a yawn.  Not here.Scorsese has to make a better statement about life than the dramas TV offers with random shots, bad acting, and endless commercials.See this great film, and if  some people are shocked by the frankness, watch an episode of Days of Our Lives, where priests are sleeping around, one incident all caught on "tape" for a Catholic wedding. All for shock and no content.I think Leonardo di Caprio and Martin Scorsese have more to say and to reveal to us about ourselves, which we resist and resist knowing. Life is not essentially entertaining. It is the so-called postive light at the end of the tunnel that is really an on-coming train. Scorsese is on that train and in front of it too.

reviewText: [This review is written for those who have seen the movie, so proceed with caution]Say what you want about Jordan Belfort, he managed to sell Martin Scorsese on making a 3-hour epic of his Wall Street "career".  The kid's clearly still got it.  I put "career" in scare-quotes because it's hard to call it that, since all he seems to do in terms of actual work is "pump up" the sales associates of his penny-stock firm with he-man chest-thumping speeches screamed through a microphone.  (The internets inform me that he now earns his living as a motivational speaker -- no surprise there.)  One wonders how any work got done at Stratton Oakmont between the midget-tossing, the parades of strippers, the Quaaludes, the blow, the designer martinis, the nasally trophy wives, the yachts, helicopters, and sushi lunches, but presumably some work did get done.  It would have been nice to see some of it.  Even in boiler rooms someone's gotta make the coffee.  We are introduced to a group of DiCaprio's initial partners, but aside from Jonah Hill, Scorsese loses interest in them.  Eventually we find ourselves back in familiar Scorsesian territory -- "Goodfellas" and "Casino" territory, in fact.  There's the violent break-up with the screaming wife.  There's the king-of-the-world excess (if Leo will pardon such a titanic pun) followed by destruction brought on by hubris.  There's the ratting-out of amigos, followed by lonely and pathetic exile.  We've been here with Scorsese before, and it's getting a little tiresome.  "The Departed" was fresh and exciting; "The Wolf of Wall Street" is an old man coasting, I fear.But even so, it's still a good time.  Scorsese, even if he's plagiarizing himself, at least spares us some sob-story sidebar about one of the innocent fish defrauded by Belfort's pump-and-dumps.  A more conventional director would do this, so that we could "see" all the damage that a scumbag like Belfort causes people in the Real World.  There was a movie released about 15 years ago called "Boiler Room", loosely based on Belfort's operation, that did just that.  Thankfully, Scorsese thinks we're smarter than that and therefore don't require all the moral edification.  Even better, we're spared detailed explanations of what exactly DiCaprio's doing that constitutes criminal fraud.  We get an in-depth history of Quaaludes, but learn hardly anything of how boiler-rooms actually operate.  DiCaprio begins one fourth-wall-breaking monologue defining an IPO, but then he stops and says, "You're really not following what I'm saying, are you?  That's all right, it doesn't matter."  Indeed it doesn't -- why fill up a movie with tedium?  Instead, Scorsese fills up his 3-hour canvas with debauchery on a Caligula-size scale, replete with "No Boinking" signs (with appropriately drawn stick figures with a red line drawn through them) nailed to the office walls, long discussions about midgets and what they're capable of, an endless cavalcade of bouncing bosoms and bottoms, and a kaleidoscope of chemical abuse.  And why?  Because such stuff is more fun to film.  This is entertainment, folks.  If you want to, you can find the edges beyond DiCaprio's wild circle; Scorsese plants a few things out there in the perimeter.  Take note of FBI agent Kyle Chandler's subway ride home, for example.  But Scorsese's not in a lecturing mood; he's like a naughty pixie here, tweaking people's noses.  An outraged review below mine wondered how many times the "F word" was used -- well, I can tell you: 569 times.  (No, I didn't count -- Wikipedia, my friends.)  He goes as far as he can with simulated sex, because he got total control of the picture after Warners dropped it and his name guaranteed an "R", rather than an "NC-17", rating, no matter what was in it.  If you got it, flaunt it!  In terms of actual direction, Scorsese has a ball directing DiCaprio and Hill in the grips of a Quaalude overdose that will become a classic clip -- best scene in the movie.  He's clearly delighting in the opportunities that physical comedy affords, and that delight is infectious.  Other than that, he steps out of the way and lets DiCaprio do the work.Scorsese and DiCaprio have worked together five times now.  The actor does for the director what De Niro used to do, and it's finally starting to convince.  DiCaprio will turn 40 this year, and age, with its padding and crows-feet, makes such roles finally plausible for him.  (He was too young when he did "The Aviator".)  I was convinced throughout that he was CEO of a large company.  It's strange that the movie that depicts almost unending juvenile frat-boy behavior should be the one where Leonardo DiCaprio finally seems grown up.  3 out of 5.
