reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is a wild ride. The only thing I can compare it to is reading Hunter S Thompson’s Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.  The film is something of a comic version of Oliver Stone’s Wall Street, and Gordon Gecko is mentioned one by Jordan Belfort. Martin Scorsese’s film is a morality tale and along the way we are treated to endless scenes of drug abuse, prostitutes and enough foul language for three films. Scorsese film is more of a satire that Stone’s Wall Street with the simple pursuit of money, drugs and women.The movie follows Jordan Belfort (played to perfection by Leonardo DiCaprio) as he begins his career as a nave Wall Street stock broker and grows into a heartless manipulator, selling junk to his clients and fixing stocks to get rich.  The real Jordan Belfort, whose book the movie is based on, was an expert salesman, who is more than willing to teach others how to sell. Donnie Azoff (nicely played by Jonah Hill) is his first partner and quickly increases to include a motley group who follow whatever Belfort tells them to do. Soon, Belfort forms a brokerage company (with the prestigious name Stratton Oakmont) pushing penny stocks at first, then moving to mainstream stocks and even an IPO.Belfort is introduced to drugs in his first job by Mark Hanna (a small but great performance by Matthew McConaughey) who informs him that cocaine is part of the job requirement.  As the film progresses, everyone working for Belfort is on as many drugs as possible.  Quaaludes are given special notice as a drug of choice (known to users as panty droppers, as they made women horny as hell and guys the stamina to go all night). There is a comic scene where Belfort and Azoff overdose on the famously potent Lemon 714 Quaaludes where both can barely talk.Leonardo DiCaprio turns in a great performance as Jordan Belfort; his character carries the film, being onscreen for all but a few scenes. One of many memorable scenes is when Belfort is saying farewell to the members of Stratton Oakmont is very poignant and emotional. Jonah Hill is excellent as Belfort’s closest friend and associate, as he learns from his mentor and then turns against him when Belfort is caught by the Feds. Rob Reiner is excellent as Belfort’s father.  I had not seen Margot Robbie prior to Wolf, and was impressed by her performance as Belfort’s second wife.At just under three hours, The Wolf of Wall Street could have undergone some cutting. There are several scenes, such as the thieving butler Belfort employs, which did not add much to the story.  Some of the drug scenes could have been shortened or cut. Once the drug use of Belfort and his associates was established there wasn’t much need to keep plugging how stoned everyone was.Overall, The Wolf of Wall Street is fun to watch and a cautionary tale; a surprising film from Martin Scorsese in that it is a departure from his gritty films (Gangs of New York and The Departed).  Many people will be turned off by the orgy scenes and all too frequent use of the F-bomb. It is a noteworthy film for Mr. DiCaprio’s performance that crosses comedy, anger, despair and redemption.

reviewText: Martin Scorcese said, "I wanted to make a ferocious film".  And did he ever.  If it was all fictional it would be over the top.  Since it is based on a true story, we realize these characters do what they do  - - - because they can and because it expresses their power even more than their collective greed.  This is not a pre-school romp through Sesame Street.  It is a long, hard, dirty, sweaty, hilarious slog through Wall St.

reviewText: Matthew McConaughey has a few minutes on the screen during a lunch scene with Leonardo DiCaprio.  Seeing the actors act during this one scene is worth the rental.  McConaughey dominates the scene, but his success results in part from DiCaprio's reactions.  Two greats, at lunch, no music or background - just great acting.Leonardo DiCaprio certainly deserves top billing.  His soliloquies and speeches to his band of brokers are fantastic.  Once again, these moments which feature him are worth the rental.Jonah Hill was perfectly cast.  Just as DiCaprio was the perfect counterpart of McConaughey's lunch scene, Jonah Hill makes DiCaprio shine brighter.  No, he is not Tonto.  His role and acting contribute a great deal to the success of the movie.Finally, I think this movie deserves 5 stars.  However, the rating of the movie has to be approaching XXX.  Frequent, casual use of drugs, explicit sex, full frontal nudity, and lots of these ingredients are not only present, but featured.  You don't want to invite your friends from church, acquaintances going through drug rehab, or your 15-year old daughter or son to watch this flick.  No, I am not prudish, but I am sensitive to the feelings, beliefs, and sensitivities of others.

reviewText: First off, this film is well made. The acting and the sets are excellent. The money is on the screen, for sure. This is assuredly the film that Scorsesse set out to make, and he made it well.Unfortunately, it's also not a film that rewards the viewer. Ultimately, you get three hours of over-the-top reprehensible behavior by a group of primary characters, not a single one likable. The sex and drug use is as over-the-top and graphic as I've ever seen in a mainstream movie (read: non-NC17).You see bad men (and women) doing bad things.Unfortunately, what you don't see, and don't get, is any reason to invest in this film. There isn't a single major character that is depicted as tragically flawed. There's no redemption. There's no penance. The main character, Jordan Belfort (Leanardo DiCaprio) is portrayed as ignorant, ghastly, shallow, and corrupt to the core. And he's pretty much this way from the first time we see him on the screen. There's no arc to his character. As far as we know, he's not a good man corrupted by the wolves of Wall Street. And he's not a corrupt man redeemed by later heroic behavior or self reflection. He is simply a bad man whose bad deeds compound as he gets richer. The same comments pretty much apply to everyone else with significant screen time.As the movie progresses, one increasingly feels a sense that "I hate all these people, and the faster they go down, the better." But when they inevitably do, there's really no real payoff. Not in a single case. Again, we have no reason to believe that any of these people were ever good, or that when any of these pigs met their slaughter, any became good.If there's a message here, I guess it's this: "If you combine the lesser elements of society with unfathomable amounts of money, all paths lead to the most base types of behavior." Perhaps in the era of Justin Bieber there's even a universal parable in there somewhere. But without showing us why we should care, that's scant payoff for three hours of screen time.
summary: Gratuitously pornographic. But the real problem is the lack of any protagonist or tragedy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The hubris of The Wolf of Wall Street comes in two versions, the "hero"'s and the director's. Martin Scorsese can do no wrong, in his own mind. He can glue in scenes that have little or no bearing on the plot, because he thinks they're entertaining. He's right, but the result is a three hour epic with an hour and a half story. Meanwhile, there are no sympathetic characters to latch onto and root for. Everyone is a greedy, selfish and largely ignorant crook. They are gross, indecent drug addicted thieves. How nice.On the other hand, the film is in constant motion. Scenes swing back and forth before they go stale, there is constant action, pumped by the characters' excess cash, and all kinds of backdrops (Italy, Switzerland, Caribbean, Long Island) to keep your interest. And it's so far removed from civilized society you can't help but laugh. It is colorful, active, vile and violent. It's got love, hate, betrayal, loyalty and stupidity. Something for everyone, but clearly not for the whole family.The unfortunate result is disgust. You leave the theater ready to move to a desert island. Your fellow human beings are scum. The whole financial underpinning of the nation is a fraud. If you trust anyone, you're a fool. Have a nice day.Maybe Scorsese is on a morality trip and wants you feel revulsion. Maybe the hilarity of it all is the sugar that helps the medicine go down. Maybe.Scorsese made just excellent use of the potentially and usually dull office scenes. An absolute army of extras filled the trading floor, and their shenanigans while "working" are hysterical. It's all high school testosterone, from spitballs to tackles and fistfights. They stand on their desks. They walk on their hands. They tend their goldfish (until the boss swallows it live).The after hours parties fueled by the company's obscene profits are hugely noisy, colorful debaucheries, worthy of Caligula. A fraternity blowout of major proportions.And the performances are first rate. Everybody comes through for Scorsese. But the entire package leaves you empty, relieved it's over and specifically not longing for more.David Wineberg

reviewText: I haven't seen any of the Oscar contenders except this one and have enjoyed all of Martin Scorsese's movies for many years, so it's important to state these biases/preferences/limits at the start.Few artists define a place in their work as well as Scorsese has defined New York City. So many of his most important movies have NYC as their main or only setting. That's true of Wolf, of course. Going back to Who's that Knocking at my Door? and Mean Streets, running through Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, King of Comedy, After Hours, Goodfellas, and more, Scorsese is always right at home in NYC, the city where he was born and bred. When he returns to that turf, as he does here, it's an occasion to see what stays the same in the director's work and what changes.Now in his 70s, Scorsese brings the same energy to Wolf that he put into Mean Streets in his early 30s. But now there is an elegance and majesty to his filmmaking that contrasts nicely with the erratic and damaging behavior of his characters. Wolf has the sweep of an historical epic and the intimacy of a journalistic character study. The main character is, of course, Jordan Belfort, embodied by Leo DiCaprio in a virtuoso that deserves every rave its gotten.Belfort, like previous Scorsese protagonists, is a performer--compare him with Travis Bickle acting out in front of his mirror, Jake La Motta in the ring and in the dressing room and onstage, with Rupert Pupkin taking over the set of Jerry Lewis' show, with Jesus stumbling through the Sermon on the Mount in Last Temptation. DiCaprio has been stellar in every movie he's done with Scorsese, but this is his best part and he makes the most of it.The rest of the cast cannot help but be in DiCaprio's shadow a bit, but they still turn in delicious performances. One person who hasn't gotten much attention is Kyle Chandler as the FBI agent who is as subtle as DiCaprio is over the top. The two make perfect foils for one another and Chandler delivers my favorite line of the movie--when he's grilling DiCaprio on the latter's yacht, and tells him that he's dealt with many douchebags in his line of work, but Jordan Belfort is different. The other crooks inherited douchebaggery from their fathers and grandfathers; according to Chandler, Jordan got that way all on his own.I don't classify the movie entirely as a comedy or as a drama. Most of all, it is a character study, a case study in context of another deep textured portrait of New York. Jordan Belfort represents the very best and very worst elements of our economic system. Scorsese and DiCaprio present Belfort as he presented himself, with no apologies or judgments. It is up to the audience to sort out their own conflicted feelings about this charismatic, hard-working, prosperous, back-stabbing, selfish, cruel criminal, as the movie makes it clear in its very last, perhaps most meaningful, image.
summary: Like Goodfellas, but with REAL criminals

reviewText: You are not going to get any more "mature" entertainment out of any film this year than seeing The Wolf of Wall Street!  This movie is such a rollercaoster ride of excess, debauchery and numerous of "Oh no!" moments which makes the film fly-by.  It is a rare thing to see a three hour movie these days and at the end...you feel that you only been watching the movie for only an hour and a half.  As you have probably read in previous reviews, this movie is about a group of guys who conned many people out of money using the stock market and other means.  They are not to be looked up at and some reviewers think that the main character's story doesn't deserve any screen time devoted to his criminal past.  But, it all comes down to the filmmaker wanting to tell a story of an interesting character or characters!  I had no idea who this guy was or what he was doing during the time that the movie was set.  If anything that the film did was that it showed very bad people doing very bad things and in the end, the party always dies.Couple of warnings:  This movie is graphic!  I counted at least 10 people, mostly elderly people, from the showing that I went to walking out of the movie early.  Making comments like..."I can't believe they showed that!" or "This movie is too much for me!"  I think they did not realize the graphic nature of the movie beforehand.  There is a lot of nudity and sex in this movie!  But, it needed it.  There is a lot of drug use in this movie...to which you almost feel like you are on drugs watching it.  But, it needed it.  Lots of vulgar language as well.  So if you get offended easily or if you are one of those "too long" complainers, it's probably best to wait and watch the "tv" edit of the film.  I really don't know how they are going to have a "tv friendly" version of this film.  It will probably be only an hour long...lol.It is one of Scorsese and Leo's best films!  Everyone in the movie was great as well!  I can't think of one bad actor in this movie.  Leo has a genious scene of physical comedy that should beat out any actor from winning any acting award this year, but he will probably get robbed again.  And Jonah Hill...he is just awesome in his role!Go and see the movie for yourselves and don't let any negative review on here dissuade you from enjoying a well crafted train wreck of characters that you don't care about, but will be totally entertained for three hours.If you don't mind lots of graphic material, than this is the movie for you.  I nominated this movie the best of 2013 because it doesn't take itself serious as other award nominated movies that have come out this past year.  The Wolf of Wall Street is one of those movies that you can watch over and over again.  Way to go Marty and Leo for another masterpiece!  For those of you calling for the movie to be edited down or it was too long, well, to each his own.  I wanted to watch more!

reviewText: I am a 79 year old woman, raised in a house in which even the word "damned" was forbidden.  I have been appalled at the overuse of the f-word in many movies, but here I applaud it.  Scorcese knows what he's doing!  The socially unaccepted vulgarities that make up much of the dialogue is part of the message of the movie.  It's theme is greed and arrogance, both anti-social traits.  The movie's point is clearly that those who devote their lives only to becoming fabulously rich, and to hell with everyone else are not intellligent or even interesting.  They only know how to buy status symbols like mansions, fancy cars, helicopters, and drugs. The only things they do or talk about, except for fleecing people, is sex and drugs. They have nothing else to fill their minds.  The cocaine gives them a false high, and their foul language is designed to put off everyone else except their money-grubbing "friends." Actually, they have no real friends, nor are their wives loving and devoted.  They are accomplices, not wives.  Like the men, the women do dugs and join in sex-fests such have never been portrayed in films. Orgies are every day occurrences.I found that the vulgar language was so a part of the characters' inner loathsome selves that it had to be there.  This movie makes you realize how vacuous life is when gettiing and buying, and using people are one's only goals. This movie is a morality tale. It should have been titled "Greed"--but a movie of that name has already been done, way back in the good old days.
summary: All here: the f-word, c-words,d-word and more

reviewText: Following a similar thematic path to WALL STREET or (for older filmgoers) OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY, THE WOLF OF WALL STREET tells the story of Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio), whose spectacular rise to financial power and subsequent fall offers an object lesson in Eighties greed and rapacity.  In terms of plot, Terence Winter's screenplay contains the usual clichés associated with movies of this type: the emphasis on conspicuous consumption, the wanton disregard of Belfort and his fellow-stockbrokers for the feelings of those around them; the brazen belief that the world is their oyster.  It is the kind of world in which Michael Douglas's Gordon Gekko would not seem out of place.  Visually speaking, Martin Scorsese's film is a treat: the cinematography by Rodrigo Prieto is stunning, with a series of fast cuts emphasizing the frenzied existence of those whose sole raison d'etre is the desire to make money.  On the other hand, THE WOLF OF WALL STREET is far too long; there are too many moments where the characters exchange dialogue without advancing the plot.  It is a genre film, to be sure, but one that could have benefited from a more rigorous directorial hand.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For myself, I have never trusted stock brokers & Wall Street goobers any more than I would lawyers or politicians.  This film crystalizes why that is the case.  I had never heard of Jordan Belfort < watching this film, and I hope he's not made into a mythical anti-hero due to this film.On the acting side, Leo is convincing as a fellow who thinks far to highly of himself (for his own good as well as the rest of the world).  However, the show stopper is Margot Robbie who plays the trophy wife who finally(!) sees beyond the glitz & glamour and begins to think for herself.  Margot is certainly beautiful & she reminds me a lot of Alice Eve.Ultimately, this movie is a cross betweenWall Street,National Lampoon's Animal HouseandBachelor Party [Blu-ray].  It is comically entertaining in a way that I wasn't expecting it to be ~ albeit in a stomach-churning sort of way.Presently, there is a contingent of Americans who are puzzled as to why a narcissistic, arrogant snake oil salesman from Wall Street was steamrolled in the 2012 presidential election.  The present story encapsulates the impetus for why so many people had such a distaste for Mitt Romney (myself included) which led to his rebuke on election night.  Belfort's disdain for "common folk" reminded me an awful lot of the Mittster's infamous 47% comment.Whether you want to pick up this DVD or not, there are two main takeaways, at least that I found.  One:  in the words of  C.S. Lewis, it is better to choose loss over shameful gain.  Two:  a junkie wearing an Armani suit is still a junkie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: An unapologetic celebration of mean-spirited excess and the depths of human greed. It's entertaining as hell, wildly indulgent and more off-the-wall than the craziest Jackass movie, but at the end of the day there really isn't much more to it than that. Leo DiCaprio is effective as the drug-powered, decadent master of ceremonies, even showing us a glimmer of internal conflict behind the hazy fog of those unfocused eyes, but his rare moments of shame are quickly washed away with all manner of intoxicants. The film's purpose is puzzling. Are we to pull for this loathsome figure, the very embodiment of the ugly American 1-percent stereotype? Shall we root for his comeuppance at the hands of the law? Merely observe, jealous but just, as he squanders our relatives' retirement funds on a perpetual hunt for fleeting ecstasy? In any case, we're in for disappointment. After an hour, the novelty of this lewd dash of A-list voyeurism begins to wear thin. At two, it's long overstayed its welcome. Thirty minutes later, it begins to deal with repercussions, but those too are impermanent and flimsy. I'm torn. On the one hand, it's a savory experience, looking over the shoulder of giants as they splurge on a lustful life of luxury. On the other... did we really do more than spin our wheels? A glittery, contemplative experience that misses its shot at excellence, I've decided, and one that really doesn't need to be half as long as it is.
summary: Big on Decadence, But Light on Meaning

reviewText: I like the movie, if only because it lets me understand the world better.That when I was told to be "professional", and to be nice and kind and be pleasant, be a "team player", to work hard to the point that I am a workaholic, to be an entrepreneur.  A lot of time, these words might be just there to have a better control of me and fulfill what they want.  Look at what people do, not what they say, no matter how beautiful they say it to be.This movie might be an opposite of the movie "The Pursuit Of Happyness".  That movie might be more like a "feel good movie" -- to fulfill the dream, etc, etc.  It was indeed true that when I get the calls from brokers or agents, I asked them, "what's the price/sales ratio of the company?" And he didn't even know what it is, and they stressed that, "you mean price/earning ratio?"  And a few hours, call me back with a number, and when I asked them, "what's the market cap of the company?" they responded with "what do you mean market cap?"  But he would always ask me to buy and buy, 3,500 shares?  good.  7,000 shares?  even better.  It also was the same at some stores where they almost try to force you into buying extended warranties on your computer.  Some even targeted a lady, saying that "a computer is such a delicate piece of electronics.  I will not let you out the door without buying an extended warranty as an assurance."  You think they push and push, for your own good?  Well, you go back to the store, and if they know you are not buying anything, they don't even bother talking to you for an extra 20 seconds.  But they act as if they have a good heart and watch out for you, exactly what I see how people are in the movie.

reviewText: This movie is based on true events and director Martin Scorsese obviously tried to use filming techniques employed in Goodfellas to bring this movie to life.  An example would be Decaprio narrating his criminal techniques concerning stock trading while in the film, just like Ray Liotta in Goodfellas narrating his gangster life while on the stand in court. However, even those techniques and parallels could not save the movie from a three star rating. The plot is solid, the theme one of outlandish greed and borderline criminal activity, and the acting very good.  Leonardo Decaprio worked hard on this film, but even his hard work could save this film from mediocrity. I think Scorsese tried too hard to parallel Goodfellas, and it did not work.  Goodfellas is an outstanding movie that brings one into the life of a gangster in a way that we can all visualize, but The Wolf fails in this regard.  Nevertheless, this movie should be on one's list because I had a business in Pennsylvania, and I can remember getting phone calls from brokers trying to sell me stocks over the phone. I presume it was these guys or similar companies.  Be prepared for sexually explicit scenes and debauchery.

reviewText: Yes, Virginia there is a point at which you get tired of watching actors cavort on screen bathed in greed and excess. Since the story seemed to have credence "based on true events" I did a little research nd came away with the same observation.I like DeCaprio's work and I thought he was superb in The Aviator and great in The Great Gatsby and Catch Me If You Can but there is a point where one's movie career seems to be somewhat "type-casted". I believe that Leonardo has arrived at that point. If you want a period piece you want Russell Crowe (Noah, Master and Commander, & Gladiator, etc) and if you want an actor that evokes "smarm" then DiCaprio seems to be your man. That is too bad because I really believe he can act - it just does not show in this film. One telltale of whether acting is required in a film is the level of voice-over audience guidance that the story-line requires to keep the audience engaged. There is so much in this piece that I was wondering whether it was trying to be a documentary of a weak-willed "Gecko". So, to wrap - enough "greed is good" lets get back to making movies with some sort of a story. If you want "smarmy" documentaries top watch "ENRON - The Smartest Guys In The Room".By the way, the real "wolf" is now doing the self-help "stick" as portrayed in the last clip of the film and exudes the "smarminess" still.

reviewText: The the multitude of other reviews have pretty much covered it, but here's what I'll say.- If you've seen "Boiler Room," you basically know the story - "pump and dump" stock scheme ensnares brokers and clients both. This is the story as told by the "Michael and/or Jim" characters from Boiler Room, rather than the story told by one of the brokers. It does not make for a more interesting story, as told by the guy at the top who had more drugs, hookers and excess than the rest. What Boiler Room had, but this movie lacks, is the story of the average people who were swindled out of their life savings by slick brokers who only cared about commissions. There is absolutely no perspective given in "Wolf of Wall Street" about the people who were victimized by Belfort and his lumpy minions, and I think the story is incomplete without that perspective.- Whoa, NELLY does this movie have a lot of naked people in it. Originally, I planned to see this in the theater with my parents - I am REALLY GLAD we decided against that idea as I would have been mortified, the entire time. WARNING to ALL sons and daughters, of any age, anywhere - this is not a movie to see with your parents, no matter how cool or open-minded they are. If you think Game of Thrones has a lot of nudity and sexual content? Watch this movie. It makes Game of Thrones look like Reading Rainbow.- I have to really question glorifying the activities and attitudes of a guy like Jordan Belfort, in a THREE HOUR movie. There are some really funny parts to the movie, to be sure. I really enjoyed the interactions between Leonardo DiCaprio and Jonah Hill - Hill is honestly just great in this movie, he gave a stellar performance. I really liked Rob Reiner as Belfort's dad. But overall, the movie doesn't really make it seem like being a drug and sex addict with no sense of morals, decency or responsibility is a bad thing. There's no real denoument in which Belfort gets any kind of comeuppance whatsoever, barring maybe one scene (involving his wife) towards the end of the movie. Also, as has been pointed out, the movie glosses over the fact that Belfort sold out ALL of his friends and almost all of his colleagues, sang like a canary, and bought his light sentence by rolling over for the feds. I think, for the sake of responsible storytelling, the movie could have covered that in greater depth.- Finally - this was WAY too much like Goodfellas. Come on - even DiCaprio's narration, at times, sounds almost exactly like Ray Liotta's voiceover narration in Goodfellas. It's like Scorsese just remade Goodfellas with an even more reprehensible main character, in a longer movie, with a LOT more naked people.I'm not going to say I didn't enjoy the movie; I did, or at least parts of it. There's some dialogue and a few scenes I'm still laughing about, as I remember them. I just don't think this is a masterpiece of cinema the way some of Scorsese's other movies have been. The depictions of debauchery really did overshadow the storytelling and character development. I felt several times that just as the movie was really getting somewhere, WHOOP - never mind that, let's cut to a scene with more naked people! And I don't mind naked people in movies/TV as a rule, but there is a line when nudity/sexuality crosses the line from interesting/artistic to egregious and unnecessary. And I think this movie crosses that line. It's not so much that I find the salaciousness disturbing or amoral or whatever, just that whatever story was in there couldn't get told because the movie was so focused on depicting excess. After the third or fourth naked party scene - okay. We get it already.It's worth a watch if you like DiCaprio - he's great in this. If you like Scorsese, you might be a little disappointed. If you need something you can watch with your mom - please, PLEASE pick something else. Your mom will thank you for it.
summary: Okay, but I liked it better as "Boiler Room"

reviewText: While some have opined this to be nothing more than a 'soft core porn movie' I am inclined to believe it does a good job of identifying the excesses and errors that occurred in a portion of the financial services industry.  Keep in mind, this was during a time of dramatic change on Wall Street, more technology available, more young people pouring in - many far more interested in scoring for themselves than in serving their clients.  This is the story of one individual that was excellent at fleecing the unsuspecting and he assembled a team that willingly supported his approach and the associated excesses of nearly unlimited wealth combined with human frailty.  And what is the moral of the story?  Caveat emptor.
summary: A Well Presented Story of Excess

reviewText: Martin Scorsese must have had a very bad dream when he decided to translate Jordan Belfort's book `The Wolf of Wall Street' to the screen. This is one of the loudest, crudest, foul-mouthed, misguided messes ever put on film - and it stretches to three hours (for those with a strong enough stomach to last through that much lying, stealing, crime, debauchery, all manner of substance abuse, and worse yet, the mean-spirited manner of treating gullible people who cannot afford to be scammed into poverty.Wikipedia has a bit a different stance: 'Jordan Ross Belfort is an American motivational speaker and former stockbroker. He was convicted of fraud crimes related to stock market manipulation and running a penny stock boiler room, for which he spent 22 months in prison.' In The Wolf of Wall Street Leonardo DiCaprio plays Belfort, a Long Island penny stockbroker who served 36 months in prison for defrauding investors in a massive 1990s securities scam that involved widespread corruption on Wall Street and in the corporate banking world, including shoe designer Steve Madden. But neither of those capsules prepares us for the outrageously humiliating debauchery of this film's presentation. It is noisy, unremittingly loud and crude, has a script that basically consists of expletives, and in the end makes us feel embarrassed to be a member of the human species. That the film won such acclaim and placed DiCaprio as an Oscar candidate and did so well financially tells us a lot about our current state of mind and taste. To this we've come? Grady Harp, March 14
summary: `The name of the game, moving the money from the client's pocket to your pocket.'

reviewText: I picked up the book and absolutely detested the protagonist so I was a little worried because people were loving the film. With the film, there is a change in certain events, some shown before others, the film sets its own pace. When this film starts for most of it, the viewer is dumbfounded by the amazing sense of humour, the rapid dialogues and its amusing pace. You can feel the director was controlling my eyes and where they land.Brief intro of the plot - A wealthy stock broker who has discovered formulas to earn very high commission on the sale of penny stocks. So of course he idolises money, he preaches what he has been preached earlier. He gets qualified and unqualified money hungry men sets them in a place and then teaches them everything he knows. He never screws with their pay checks and he doesnt look at any obstacles, he has a very optimistic hedonist point of view of the world. There is a lot of drugs and alcohol in the film but irrespective of where you belong, you will like what you see.What I liked -  Some 9 scenes in the film I found very funny. You like every single character, whether its Jonah Hill, the guy from walking dead, whether its Matthew McConaughey, the Vice Presidents, his wives, the kids, the cops. The sets are amazing and I think the overall editing is fantastic. BUT I COULDN'T help but feel Martin Scorsese took somewhat of a backseat in this film and forgot one or two of his own inhibitions in trying to bring the protagonist to the front. Leonardo is there in every scene, it looks like he is acting for the first time in his life, he is that riveting.I didn't dislike a single thing about the film. I didn't dislike the length.(Spoiler) My favourite scenes were always the ones where he is doing drugs. I loved the scene where he is paralysed on the ground.  I also think Matthew McConaughey's part was acted very well. Jonah Hill's introduction was hilarious.Overall -  I can tell for sure I will see this film at least once more in my life. It is so good it is worth owning.Happy to see Leonardo and Marty working so well together again. My favourite theatre movie watch since The Departed.
summary: So much better than the book.

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is is a very good movie by an amazing Director and some fine Actors with Jonna Hill and Leonardo DiCaprio.  The movie itself I agree with other reviewers how misunderstood it can be because of these elements first the overuse of bad language, second the overuse of drug scenes, third some nudity and sexual scene, and last the 3 hour length of the movie.  Speaking personality I am a huge fan of the Director this is the sixth movie in my collection of his,  I just got done watching the movie few minutes ago and I was amazed by the movie.  What I did was make a mental note to watch the movie with an open mind and that's what I did, I can see why Leo won the Golden Globe and Jonna was nominated for an award.  I still gave the movie a 4 star rating because I saw past all the other people thought of the movie and sat down and just enjoy myself.  If you really like the actors in this movie and can see past the language, drugs, so forth then buy this movie and enjoy it as much as I did because it is still one of Leo's best movies ever star in and another great hit by the Director.
summary: A very good movie by an amazing Director and some fine Actors

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: A surprising film indeed. What is it about?First of all it is about 45 minutes too long. The sex scenes and the orgies could have been cut short to a simple ellipse instead of a graphic depiction. That is one easy shortening that should have been used. Same thing with the drug scenes that are by far too numerous and too long. We got the message very fast that to succeed in Wall Street you have to be a sex addict, a drug-cocktail addict, an alcohol addict, a money addict, a money-lifting addict, a thief, a liar and a few other little things like that. We know that, we knew that and we have known it since at least American Psycho.So, what is the original message?It is simple. Anyone can succeed like that wolf in the USA in the most ruthless way possible with the most illegal and unethical means possible because the system is a filter-less abyss. There is no real filter to prevent these crimes and other offenses. There is no protection of any kind to prevent criminal minds to get into the business. The American system after 1987, date of the beginning of the wolf's career, is absolutely deregulated and it will be so till a very recent period, till a couple of years after the 2009 crisis. What's more most of those who are supposed to look after the various crimes committed in the financial field can be bought for a pittance, at times a little bit more, be they American, or Swiss, or whatever affiliation they have as for financial paradise.Yet the FBI cannot be bought up. They are incorruptible, which I doubt very much. But well we can always think there is an Eliot Ness in every FBI special agent.The worst part is that these people when they are caught will become, in their own interest, the most talkative monsters you can imagine. They will accept a deal at once. The principle is simple: "In Wall Street there is NO friend!" Partners, associates, colleagues, collaborators are ALL, all of them, nothing but competitors, enemies. As long as they can work as a pack they will, but as soon as the pack is under a real menace each one will go alone against the pack if necessary. A starving pack in the Rocky Mountains may die though if it comes to that the outcome will be ONE survivor and ONE survivor only. Wolves are cannibals in situations where survival is at stake.As for a meaning that is very light and very nave. "Lupus est homo homini, non homo, non quom qualis sit novit" (wolf is man to man, no man when he does not know who the other is). Erasmus (15th-16th centuries) quoted it from Plautus (3rd-2nd centuries BCE), the original author, and then Thomas Hobbes in the 17th century made it a central concept of his vision of humanity in his work Leviathan. Nothing new under the sun. This phrase "Man is wolf to man" has become a catch phrase with the Industrial Revolution and Marxism. Though capitalism, and any form of it, did not invent it. Gladiators were Romans. The Celts burnt their criminals. And the modern times invented a lot of such cruel treatment of human beings as slaves or as playthings for sadistic or didactic practices, even calling it the death sentence. A woman was recently raped in public by more than fifteen men in a village in eastern India on the order of the village elders because she refused to break off with a man, her lover, who was from another village that was sexually off limits for these elders. Maybe the saying does not apply to women?When we thus look at the film and wonder what makes it in anyway different, original, new, we have to say it is a brilliant cinematographic illustration of a common place idea and situation. The catch phrase of the film is that New Zealand has become the haven, paradise, refuge and shelter of all those criminals, financial, copyright or data all together and the same, where they can go on striving without any menace from the FBI. Australia is a second haven of the type and then Russia too is trying to set her feet in that juicy field. The juice is not only money, it is also a lot of blood.That last remark, the catch phrase, the final scene of the film is the most powerful argument for a shorter film, a film that could have been a lot shorter. "Sell me that pen" becomes very shallow and trite after three hours of ranting, raving, partying, raping, raging, and so many other off-normalcy attitudes, actions and principles.  The film is in itself an orgy of ever and endlessly repeating sequences: we are framed in a million images of exactly the same value and tinge and color and hue. What a shame! Scorsese could do better.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU
summary: A denser and shorter version would have been better

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is the Marmite of movies - you're either going to love it or hate it and there's probably no convincing you either way once you've made a decision. Panned by most of the people I know, I avoided it at the theater and then finally streamed the film when I had a whole three hours available - and it was once of the best three hours I've had with a film in a long time.The very beginning sets the tone: it's loud, vulgar and excessive. It's the Scorsese we know from Goodfellas and watching him bring truly unlikeable characters to life is one of his trademark directorial maneuvers. There are F-bombs galore, drugs, endless tracking shots, freeze frames, voiceovers, the mandatory great soundtrack and a feeling at the end of the film that we truly know the characters. It's his familiar story of a prideful, egotistical anti-hero slipping into an illegal world to live an indulgent life that ultimately becomes his undoing and here he executes spectacularly well.DiCaprio and HIll deliver some of their finest performances as the Quaalude-popping miscreants serving up darkly funny performances that balance the excess of this parallel world. You'll hate Wall Street all the more after viewing but it's hard to not to become enticed by their antics of running a financial frat house representing so many of the things that have gone wrong in their real life counterparts.There's no doubt this is a polarizing film and not one you'd want to watch with your in laws but as a slice of life where the volume is permanently set to 11, it's mesmerizing, funny, tragic and genuinely some of the year's best entertainment.
summary: One of the year's best films and DiCaprio shines again

reviewText: There are few directors that I have an undying respect for that have let me down as consistently and for as long as Martin Scorsese has. For the first decade or so of his career, he's made some of the best films EVER MADE (TAXI DRIVER, RAGING BULL, THE LAST TEMPTATION OF CHRIST, GOODFELLAS, MEAN STREETS, AFTER HOURS) and for the last twenty-three years, I don't believe the man has made a truly great film (THE DEPARTED was decent for what it was, but hardly Best Picture material). But suddenly, THE WOLF OF WALL STREET came around, and I felt like the past 23 years of his films, ranging from respectfully decent to tragically god-awful, had been just a bad dream, and with his three-hour character study of a young man coming from nothing with just an insatiable hunger to consume more in just a few years than a thousand people could consume in their collective lifetimes, Scorsese becomes an alchemist, transforming the most deporable human behavior into film gold.The film follows a few years in the life of real-life figure Jordan Belfort (DiCaprio), as he seeks his fortunes on Wall Street. He gets life advice in the form of an immoral senior trader at the first company he works for (gloriously personified by Matthew McConaghey) as he extolls the "virtues" of theft, greed, drugs and masturbation. He then starts his first big day on Wall Street on October 19th, 1987, aka Black Monday, where the stock market took its biggest fall since the 1929 crash. Out of work, he goes to work at a semi-legal brokerage house working out of a strip-mall that sells "penny stocks", which are stocks for extremely small companies with little to no net worth. He uses his slick salesmanship and gets a ridiculous 50% commission for everything he sells, which is something unheard of at the major firms. Then, he attracts those same people as well as the cousin-marrying schlub Donny (a glorious Jonah Hill), to join him in his own firm he calls Stratton-Oakmont (to give it that old money WASP-y flavor). His main salespeople are all weed dealers, because they know how to push their product. Stratton grows at a geometric rate as it continues selling the penny stocks and parlaying those sales into the established stocks, and suddenly, in his mid-twenties, he's making millions of dollars. He's also engorging himself on hookers, cocaine and his personal favorite drug, quaaludes like they're all going out of style. Despite being married, he attracts what he believes is the perfect woman for him, a former Miss Long Island, the beautiful Naomi (newcomer Margot Robbie), and soon leaves his wife for her. He buys mansions, huge yachts, expensive sportscars and even a helicopter. He even has an enforcer of sorts in his father Max (a BRILLIANT Rob Reiner), who tries to lead him on a smarter path, but Jordan believes himself invincible, even when he is confronted by FBI Agent Patrick Denham (Kyle Chandler) who has pretty much everything he needs to arrest Jordan for all of the many illegal things he's doing on a daily basis. Alas, the mighty must fall at some point, and a downward spiral of events threatens everything Jordan has built his life upon.This could have easily been a cautionary tale ala Oliver Stone's WALL STREET, which has a more cathartic ending, but that tale has already been told. Instead, Scorsese dares you to find these utterly disgusting and amoral characters sympathetic at points, and dares you even further to actually root for them. This seems to be the thesis of this film, and if Leonardo DiCaprio hadn't crafted the best performance of his career in this film, it would have been all for naught. As Belfort, DiCaprio is utterly magnetic and daringly seductive. He's not an evil man, nor are the people that surround him; he comes off as more of a charming rogue bucking the system rather than a Gordon Gekko-type whose every move drips with malevolence. This is not to say that Jordan is a good guy; he's a horrible human being, but the film allows you as the audience to make your judgments about him and his acolytes. While the film could be conceived as a drama, it lacks the necessary aforementioned catharsis to allow it to drift too far into drama and plays more as not only a vicious satire of the lifestyles of the money-obsessed 80's and early 90's, but also as high comedy. If you're not laughing a lot at the debauchery on display within the opening minutes of the film, THE WOLF OF WALL STREET is decidedly not a film for you. Much has also been made of the film's record-breaking use of the F-word in its many iterations (noun, verb, adjective, adverb, etc.), and again, if you find that word offensive, even when not used in astounding excess, this is not a film for your tastes.Much credit is to be given to screenwriter Terence Winter, who has also written several episodes of THE SOPRANOS and BOARDWALK EMPIRE, who gives each character, no matter how small, a very specific voice. And the myriad of performers who make small but important contributions such as Joanna Lumley, Jon Favreau, Jon Bernthal and a brilliant Jean Dujardin really round out the cast. Hill continues his upswing into more significant films (as long as I can forget about THIS IS THE END), and continues to prove that he's more than just a one-trick pony.Let us not forget Scorsese, who not only directs the film with verve, excitement, energy and precision, but lets most of his thematic necessities go for this film, which is unlike anything he's ever done. There's no examples of the Madonna/Whore complex; there's no heavy Catholic symbolism; I don't even think there's a Rolling Stones song in the soundtrack. And the three-hour run time of the film breezes by.THE WOLF OF WALL STREET is a startling revelation of a film from a director who I had believed had his best days behind him, but if nothing else, it proves that an old dog can learn new tricks, even if those tricks include an EPIC quaalude crawl.
summary: Scorsese and DiCaprio elevate debauchery, excess and greed to an art form.

reviewText: No doubt about it, this movie is probably the crudest I've seen in ages.  But the point of the movie was to tell the story of a man whose excesses brought him to ruin.  I think the director Martin Scorsese got that point across very well indeed.  Leonardo DiCaprio held nothing back in his protrayal of Jordan Belfort.  Jonah Hill's performance was also off the charts.  Watching the film was like watching a wreck on the highway: you really don't want to see the devastation, but you end up looking anyway.  And they are images you can never unsee again.  Bravo to Terence Winter for a great screenplay.  And kudos to my favorite NY actor, Johnnie Mae, for her turn as Jordan Belfort's nanny.  Johnnie Mae, yours was the only sane character in the film!
summary: If you've heard rumors that it's crude, you heard right.

reviewText: This tribal rite of passage shows the un-annointed how the rapacious "real" men of Wall Street behave when they smell blood. My biggest problem (and I have a couple) was my repugnance at watching the unbridled adolescent behavior of allegedly grown men who no longer have limits set by parents, teachers, police or good manners. By the way: there are 506 uses of the "F" bomb in this one.Martin Scorsese has worked successfully with Leonardo DiCaprio before ("Shutter Island" and "The Departed"). It's time for someone to have the courage to tell the biggest gorilla in the Hollywood jungle that he needs an EDITOR! This 180-minute film is too long by half. I easily could have edited some of those motivational talks, the drug sessions, the bacchanals and the orgies without damaging the story one iota. Bottom line: this is basically a 90-minute cautionary tale about drugs and power based on Jordan Belfort's autobiographical "The Wolf of Wall Street." The main points don't need to be hammered home with endless, repetitious (and boring) scenes.We see:* Matthew McConnaughey ("The Lincoln Lawyer") does a brief scene at the beginning that sets a standard for our hero to admire.* Leonardo DiCaprio ("J. Edgar") as Jordan Belfort, our titular "Wolf," who unflinchingly shows us the downside of drug use: the bloodshot eyes, the drooling, the crawling, the garbled speech and the repulsive behavior which evolve when there are no limits.* Jonah Hill ("Moneyball") is his sidekick, long on ambition and short on common sense.* Margot Robbie ("Love Actually") is our hero's second wife, gorgeous, smart and trying to make a life.* Jean Dujardin ("The Artist") is a French-speaking Swiss banker who holds American "scum" in contempt.* Joanna Lumley ("Absolutely Fabulous") is Aunt Emma, a Brit who is more than willing to help hide those ill-gotten gains in a Swiss bank.* Kyle Chandler ("Super Eight") is a tenacious FBI man who should not be underestimated.We are dealing with top-notch talent and a compelling story, but personally, I am going to a pleasant little dramedy later today to cleanse my palate. ...smile... Amazon will notify me when the DVD is available so I can tell my JayFlix.net folks.

reviewText: Love 2/3 of this film, the other 1/3 not so much...It goes on Forever!... Lots of over the top, over blown, over acted scenes....tons of f-words, and flipping of the bird...sex and LOTs of drugs, while some was definitely important to the overall story line, a lot of it could easily have been shortened or eliminated completely. I am certainly no prude but a lot of the stuff was just unnecessary.  Maybe that is what it takes to have box office success these days.There is actually a great story being told, but it appeared to me that Scorsese was more interested in letting his actors "show their chops" and beat a scene into the ground than really making a great film.  It is like every actor was guaranteed x number of minutes on screen, no matter how useless those minutes might be, and was allowed to go unrestrained to give "the performance or their lives"...For me the most impressive performances were actually those of Matthew McConaughey and Margo Robby.  Not only is Robby spectacular looking, I thought she was great in the roll and I look forward to seeing her in future movies.All in all I think this movie could have been so much better...
summary: Lots of over the top, over blown, over acted scenes....

reviewText: What’s it about?The spectacular rise and fall of unscrupulous, hard-partying New York stockbroker Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio). Based on Belfort’s memoir of the same name.What did I think?Belfort, his partner in white-collar crime (a brilliantly tubby-again Jonah Hill), and their boys club are utterly repulsive yet simultaneously make you feel like you need to get more, amid their constant daze of yachts, drugs and hookers.The film doesn't pull its punches on the more sinister, unhinged aspects of Belfort’s life either, as reality – and the law – starts to catch up with him. So many great performances round out this often uproarious picture, especially Australia’s Margot Robbie and a brief, hilarious turn from Matthew McConaughey. Desensitize your moral compass before viewing.
summary: The Wolf of Wall Street quick movie review

reviewText: Leonardo Dicaprio again eats the scenery (and the cast howls right alongside) in this brilliantly written and unexpectedly funny re-envisioning of a "Goodfellas"-cum-Wall St" parable, directed by always-intense mad genius Martin Scorsese. reviewText: Over the top raunchy, but this movie, based on the true life story of Jordan Belfort, had to be just that to capture the essence of who this guy was. Be warned, there is a lot of cursing, nudity and debasing sex scenes. It would've been hilariously funny had I not known just how true it all was. Regardless, suspending that knowledge, the movie was funny.After the movie was over, I researched Jordan Belfort a bit, as I do when a movie is even loosely based on truth. The guy only served 22 months in prison and hasn't paid back the money he owes in restitution. He is now a motivational speaker. When I don't understand is how anyone would give this guy a dime to speak. Is he a great salesman (aka con artist)? Absolutely - his history is out there for anyone to research prior to spending money for one of his seminars. I wouldn't trust a word from his mouth - all he is doing is teaching others how to be con artists.

reviewText: Do you have that friend who talks about horrible things he once did, things he should regret doing, but it always sounds like at least half of him is bragging about it?  Well this movie feels like 100% of him is bragging about it.It is clear from watching that the movie was written by Jordan Belfort, the Wolf himself.  Lots of reviewers talk about 'excess' in this movie, but again, the sublte undertone is Belfort saying "can you believe I did that!?"  His character doesn't ever seem to learn anything, or face much of a punishment for his actions.  Nor does the movie point out that there's injustice in Belfort's freedom.I wanted to give this movie 1 start, because I despised it so much, but the production value is high.  It's well directed, and engaging ... I just wish it had never been made.
summary: Well Made, but Please Dont Watch

reviewText: This is a good movie, it's not slow by any means, although I think 3 hour movies are a little self indulgent on the part of those creating it. It's like a 5 page resume. No more explanation required. People have brains and I think a lot of what people remember from movies is what they imagined rather than what they saw. I see this all the time when someone is describing a great scene and interjecting their "inferences" into it. The movie could have been shorter and wouldn't have lost much.But I digress. The move is great. But the over the top partying scenes are exaggerated. Even Def Leppard during their hayday when they had groupies giving them bj's under the stage during the drum solo couldn't aspire to the level of mayhem depicted in some of those scenes. I'm sure there was a lot of cheering and clapping when Jordan was giving speaches, and I'm sure there was a lot of cocaine floating around the office, but I just couldn't help but get the sense that the filmmaker was trying to embellish the partying and drunken debauchery just a bit to drive the point home. We get it. They made craploads of money and snorted a lot of cocaine.But aside from that, without knowing the actual story of Jordan Belfort, I can't say if anything else is over-embellished or just plain made up. It was a fun movie to watch. Leonardo is and will always be one of my favorite actors. But It's almost creepy how this movie and another of his latest movies - The Great Gatsby - both depict ridiculously over the top "party like there's a gun to your head" scenes. If I were Leo, I'd watch out for being associated with disingenuous tales.Jerry Boutotappdataworks.comjerryboutotmusic.com
summary: Wolf of Wall Street is good, but it's a little over exaggerated, so no five stars from me

reviewText: Nine Things about “The Wolf of Wall Street”1. This is a raunchy, foul-mouthed tale of American greed based on the memoirs of Jordan Belfort, a stockbroker convicted of market manipulation.2. I think this movie contains more drugs, sex, and swearing than all the other movies I saw this year put together. Of course it’s gratuitous – this guy’s whole lifestyle was gratuitous. So it works.3. This movie is also an acidly funny satire on Wall Street.4. Leonardo DiCaprio stars as Jordan, a money-hungry young man with more ambition than brains.5. Jordan hires his knucklehead weed dealer friends to start a small semi-legal stockbroker firm. As they get more successful, they get less legal.6. DiCaprio has always been an excellent actor – but this may be his best performance ever. And Jonah Hill is also great as the douchebag friend.7. Jordan’s schemes were complicated and hard to understand for us regular folk, but the movie does a good job of dumbing it down – mostly by telling us that all we need to know is that he’s doing really illegal things.8. The scene where Jordan overdoses on Quaaludes is a minor masterpiece of physical comedy and is one of the single best scenes of the year. I didn’t know DiCaprio had it in him.9. The movie is three hours long, so, like the stock market, this movie is an investment of your time. But it’s worth it.
summary: Needed another 4 star review.  Warning Should've been NC-17

reviewText: Leonardo DiCaprio here gives an outstanding performance as Jordan Belfort, the charismatic and shameless share promoter. Belfort graduates from plugging penny stocks to forming his own brokerage company called Stratton Oakmont. It's a great name which suggests solidity, continuity and oak lined paneling. A tradition of financial service to discerning clients. But it was all smoke and mirrors. Belfort essentially ran an illegal bucket shop operation.I had read the book "The Wolf of Wall Street" (written by Belfort) before so I knew what to expect from this tale of excess. Belfort was addicted to money, drugs and women. And in that order, though sometimes he indulges in all three at the one time. (You'll see how he does this in the film). Viewers will find it hard to believe that the film is tamer than the book. But it is so. DiCaprio himself has compared Belfort to a modern-day Caligula.There is a truly hilarious segment in this movie where Belfort takes a tad too many Quaaludes for comfort. I had read Belfort's account but was not prepared for DiCaprio's brilliant and hilarious onscreen portrayal of it. It's a great piece of situational comedy and would not be out of place in a Fawlty Towers episode. (In the real life incident, mercifully, there were no human causalties involved).This movie should not be compared with either of the "Wall Street" movies. "The Wolf of Wall Street" is more of a boisterous and venal hedonistic romp. It's all downhill though. Belfort clearly subscribes to the "Reality is due to a deficiency of good drugs" theory.DiCaprio's voiceovers remind me of that other excellent Scorsese film "Casino". There Pesci and DeNiro provide the narration from time to time. In "Casino" the mob guys fought with guns. In this movie Belfort's guys went to war with telephones. They are telephone terrorists with instructions to never to take "No!" for an answer. They are to stay on the line until "They either buy or die". Welcome to the world of telephone financial terrorism.The lovely Joanna Lumley makes a brief appearance in the film as one of Belfort's money couriers. Rob Reiner plays Belfort's father. Watch out for the cameo of Belfort himself. That's him playing the motivational speaker who introduces DiCaprio at the end.This film clocks in at practically 3 hours long. So, if going to the movies, catch the early performance.

reviewText: This movie is about greed and dishonesty of Wall Street stock brokers.  It is based on the book written by John Belfort about how he went from rags to riches by swindling people out of their life savings by selling penny stocks and IPOs of companies. He hired and trained a bunch of stock brokers, some of them had no training at all or were not licensed to sell stocks, and make 50% commissions.  It was fast and easy money for the fast talking salespeople and they made millions.  They made hundreds of millions as a matter of a fact.The movie was way too long and could have been edited a lot to a more reasonable size.  Some of the scenes were just silly and they drug on too long.  Did I say drugs?  Yep these ultra-rich stock brokers used the money to buy drugs, hookers, fast cars and massive yachts.While the movie is meant to be a bad comedy it is really sad that the real life person that committed these crimes served 22 months in jail for stealing over 200 million dollars.  The film makes it look like he was in a country club instead of prison as money can buy you anything.  Unfortunately it wasn't his money.I rated the film as a 3 star movie as it was too long and the acting was over the top.  The film included excessive foul language, sex and drugs.  If you want to see why you shouldn't trust a stock broker to churn you money then this film is an ideal lesson
summary: Greed and corruption of Wall Street brokers put on display!

reviewText: WOLF OF WALL STREET is about the perils of excess--money, power, drugs and narcissism.  It's also excessively long and could have been a great movie at just over 2 hours as the film makes its point early on and then just continues to pile on more escapades for the sake of showing them.There are great performances in the film; however, DiCaprio's is not one of them.  Of late, he's focused on playing larger than life cads who all need to be taught a lesson.  Between this, Gatsby and Howard Hughes, DiCaprio doesn't so much as create a character, but rather an archetype who may be handsome and charming on the outside, but is also a complete jerk to everyone around him.  Had DiCaprio went for a little nuance or was given some opportunity to show the inner conflict that contributed to his excessive behavior, I might have thought more of his work.  In my opinion, he's become more like Tom Cruise, merely delivering his lines with typical bravado and no depth.  He does get one moment that stands out, when he finally has his worst drug experience ever, but it's just a moment.Thankfully, Jonah Hill and many of the supporting cast get to do a lot more.  John Berenthal is great to watch, as are Margot Robbie and Kyle Chandler.  Scorsese still offers up his typical crisp direction and pacing; the problem is the film's script, which goes on longer than necessary to prove a point that self-indulgence and greed will lead to your eventual downfall.

reviewText: Martin Scorsese's marvelously entertaining "The Wolf of Wall Street" is one of those movies guaranteed to polarize viewers. It has been vilified as vulgar, sexist, obscene, immoral, disgusting, overly long, hedonistic and glorifying in its debauchery. Its controversial nature is evidence in its overall three star rating; some people love it and others hate it. Those that hate "Wolf of Wall Street" feel that the movie celebrates the life of crime while neglecting those who suffered from it.But those detractors have missed the point. "The Wolf of Wall Street" is supposed to be vulgar, long and hedonistic because that's how the characters are. Far from glorifying the corrupt lifestyle of a pawnbroker, Scorsese shows us just how sick and perverted it is. Scorsese isn't the kind of director that's going to have characters spew banal dialogue on how wrong it is for pawnbrokers to perform pump and dump scams; he just presents it. That's not moral irresponsibility; that's great film making. Why tell it when you can simply show it?Like many of Martin Scorsese's movies, the main characters in "The Wolf of Wall Street" are ambiguous antiheroes who are neither warm or likable (and any pawnbroker that screws over victims is hardly likable), but have a snake-like fascination about them that just grips your attention. Many of the actors, particularly Leonardo DiCaprio, Jonah Hill and Rob Reiner, are given the difficult task of making these repellent characters attractive and they succeed in spades. Hill is particularly outstanding as Donnie Azoff and the sequences where he is flashing his private parts, terrorizes an employee by eating his fish and then makes fun of an associate for sucker punching him demonstrate that there's more to Hill as an actor than many people believe. Also excellent is Kyle Chandler as the shrewd FBI agent out to bring Belfort down and there's a riveting sequence where on Belfort's yacht where he tries to bribe the agent into joining him.Equally noteworthy, however, is Matthew McConaughey's memorable cameo as the man who ultimately gives Belfort the tools to succeed by adopting sex and cocaine. His character appears for only a few minutes, but those are very pivotal minutes. Everybody who saw this movie knows what I'm talking about and if you don't, let me help you: "hoohuuum hoohuuummm hooo hooum hooo hoouuumm" (while pounding my chest).The movie, of course, is riotously funny, probably the funniest movie Scorsese has made since "After Hours", but it's a different kind of funny. What offended many viewers was that the film did not depict Stratton Oakmont customers having their lives destroyed by these materialistic pigs and they even felt the movie laughed at their misfortune. But the joke isn't on the victims; it's on the characters. Or to be more precise, the joke is on us, but the VENOM is on them for disregarding human life. There's a hilarious and disturbing sequence where Belfort suffers a cerebral palsy at the moment he finds out the FBI is tapping his house phone. Not only does he have a hard time getting to his car, but when he gets home, he struggles to grab his house phone and save a patron from choking on a snack. It's a frighteningly hilarious sequence because here's a guy who ripped off millions of dollars from investments and this is where he's spending it on. And anyone who had doubts that DiCaprio had a sense of humor should check this sequence out.At first glance, one expects a spiritual successor to Oliver Stone's more conventional "Wall Street", but if you expect a typical crime drama where the villain gets away or achieves redemption, you don't know Scorsese. This is the same filmmaker that showed us the seductive allure and fatal consequences of operating in a crime organization ("Mean Streets", "GoodFellas", "Casino"), paralleled cops and robbers as if they were two sides of the coin ("The Departed"), expressed the ugliness of sexual jealousy and machismo behavior ("Raging Bull") and showed how social media can turn psychopaths into heroes ("Taxi Driver") and even celebrities ("The King of Comedy"). Scorsese is both attracted and repulsed by these antiheroes and their dark side and it's no doubt he is every bit as disgusted by their actions as many of the people who hated this movie were."Wolf of Wall Street", far from immoral, is a very moral movie. It's clear that, by the end, Belfort still hasn't learn his lesson and continues to have a good life while everyone else he has scammed and betrayed is suffering to this very day. Instead, the moral journey is for us, to persuade us to not follow the lifestyle of these despicable, heartless deadheads who wallow and are destroyed by their own wretched excess and hubris. That's why "Wolf of Wall Street" demands to be seen and why the critics who assailed the film should watch it again to get the message.
summary: The detractors are wrong; this movie has something to say.

reviewText: Well!  Many aspects to comment on in this movie.  I wasn't sure what to expect and I admit, if this is really how wild it is in some circles of the Wall street crowd,  it's a wonder they can function.  But, yes, as many have stated, the acting is superb in this movie. The subject matter stung a lot for me, being one of the people sucked into buying penny stocks in the 90's thanks to reading glowing reports about the future of several fledgling companies, and not selling out in a timely manner and as a result loosing it all.  What stung even more was the statement in the movie that a 50% commission is made by the seller.  No idea if that is accurate, but I suspect it is.  This film shows the seedy, ugly underbelly of some Wall Street people.  And for that, I think it gets an A+.I wouldn't call this a comedy per say, but there are certainly funny parts  throughout the movie.  But to just call it a comedy is selling the whole story short.  It's much more than that.  So to all those who gave it one star, come on,  every movie can't be for the children or all proper language and no vulgarity.  That just isn't how life is,  especially relating to this particular subject matter. And not a movie for a wife to watch????  I'm the wife and I selected the movie and my husband was blown away by the movie as much as I was.  I like movies about Wall Street, it is simply a fascinating subject to me.  Leonardo DiCaprio has done nothing but improve over the years.  He is doing in this movie what he does best, and that is an explosive personality part, capable of great extremes of emotion, and a great wit and intellect.  Bravo!

reviewText: Just when I thought Martin Scorsese was starting to lose it in his old age, he gives us "The Wolf of Wall Street." And Martin has now found himself back in my good graces.Within the first few seconds of this movie I knew it was a winner because it immediately reminded me of "Goodfellas" and "Casino."The opening scene, which had me laughing instantly, freezes on Jordan's face as he begins to narrate, which is very reminiscent of Henry Hill from "Goodfellas."And that first scene, as wild and crazy as it is, pretty much sets the pace for the rest of the entire film.This movie is long, but it is non-stop fun, and non-stop debauchery.Drugs, sex, full frontal nudity (male and female), F-bombs dropping left and right....all of which is then followed up with more drugs and sex!Man, what a good time!Some of the scenes are so funny that you feel like you are watching a full-blown comedy. It's just so fascinating to think that this was actually somebody's life!I was originally a bit apprehensive about this movie because I knew Jonah Hill would be in it (another reason I felt Martin must be losing it!) and I am by no means a Jonah Hill fan. However, I was really surprised to find that I not only liked his performance, but his "Donny" was getting a good portion of all the laughs!I was never a big fan of Leonardo DiCaprio either, for that matter, but his performance in this movie was outstanding. After seeing this (as well as his performance as Calvin Candy in "Django Unchained") I have had a much different appreciation for the man and his talents.I'm not giving this the full 5 stars because there were a few flaws in my opinion. First, I didn't care very much for the music. Some of the songs were good choices, that added some fun to the scene, but a lot of others fell flat for me, or even seemed out of place and time. Secondly, I don't care for CGI, which is used in a few scenes (mainly involving the yacht and the helicopter). And thirdly, I wish it was longer, if you can believe that!I just didn't want the fun to end!I would DEFINITELY recommend this movie to anyone who might enjoy, and who can handle, some naughty, over-the-top, adult fun!

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is a little bit of a return to classic Scorsese, having more in common with Goodfellas and Casino then with his more recent cinematic achievements. It's a (corporate) crime epic of sorts, a cautionary tale about the American Dream and its pitfalls. The film, like Goodfellas, focuses on the seductive quality that a life of crime and wealth offers. A lot of people have mistaken this treatment as an endorsement of the behavior that is being portrayed, when it is merely an honest and candid insight into a side of America that no one really wants to aknowledge. Now the film could have ended up being a depressing look at a ruined life of crime or corruption, or a boring procedural on how stock fraud works. It is neither. Instead, Scorsese tells the story in the form of a dark comedy, with razor sharp writing and perfect comedic timing from his actors, all while maintaining a tense dramatic edge. The film is slickly edited, with aggressive and engaging storytelling that is typical of Scorsese. The soundtrack is excellent, and the performances are incredible across the board, with DiCaprio turning in his best work to date. For a three hour film on stock market fraud, it is ridiculously entertaining and fast paced. Its not for everyone; the easily offended should just stay away and not ruin it for those who aren't. This is one of the best films from an already accomplished director, and my personal favorite film of the year.As for the bluray package:The picture is pristine, showing off the film's excellent cinematography with clarity. Sometimes the skin tones of the actors appear a little oversaturated, but it won't bother those who don't nit-pick.The Audio is very good as well, though I won't pretend like I'm an audiophile. I could hear everything clearly.The Special features are very lacking, with only one video about the making of the film. Its informative, but more would have been nice.All in all, The Wolf of Wall Street is an excellent film, and it looks great on bluray. I saw it in the theater and have watched it twice this week, so it has high replay value and is worth the money if you're a fan of the film.

reviewText: Scorsese's most invigorating film since the golden age of Casino and Goodfellas. Like with many of Scorsese's crime epics, Wolf of Wall Street serves as an examination of greed and its intoxicating effect on people. It's a film about human nature which soberly reminds us that any one of us might have taken Belfort's same path had we been presented the same temptations, because like drugs or alcohol, Scorsese suggests that money too can be an addiction. DiCaprio is absolutely shattering, and Winter's screenplay sizzles with an energy that cannot be contained.

reviewText: I saw this just after viewing the Ken Burns series, The West.  This story of a sleazy stock broker is a natural followup to the insanity of the Gold Rush, of slavery, and the slaughter of Native Americans and the buffalo.  It is all one insanity.  I expected not to like this film at all.  It certainly filled me with disgust, but it was surprisingly engrossing to observe these men (for three hours, no less)  who were addicted to money, drugs, sex, and their own sense of invulnerability.  Like little boys, they really “got off” on an anarchic style of disrespect for all except money.  Based on the memoir of Jordan Belfort, the film is evidently not exaggerated.  I missed some sense of redemption somewhere, but it appears that none took nor has taken place.  Belfort spent some time in jail but now makes as much as $30,000 an evening as a motivational speaker.  I guess the reason we have not put more legal limits on men like Belfort is because John Steinbeck was right when he said, "Socialism never took root in America, because the poor see themselves not as an exploited proletariat but as temporarily embarrassed millionaires.”  God help us!
