reviewText: Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.Is it brilliance, or a cinematic disaster? Well, that all depends on who you ask. With Martin Scorsese in the director’s chair and Leonardo DiCaprio and Jonah Hill taking center stage, The Wolf of Wall Street looked to be the perfect set-up for something both memorable and mesmerizing. Unfortunately, after a great deal of time and effort, it failed on both accounts. The thing is it’s hard to like someone like Jordan Belfort, and Scorsese did a good job of making the audience hate him, but the journey through his life needed to be honest enough that it felt genuine, yet written well enough that it didn’t come off as boring. Scorsese was only able to check off one of these requirements, unfortunately, and the film suffers greatly because of it.The Wolf of Wall Street follows the life of Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio), an American stockbroker who was convicted of committing fraud through stock market manipulation. As a young man trying to make it big, Jordan gets hired at an established Wall Street firm, passes his Series 7 Exam, and gets his brokers license, only to lose his job after the stock market crashed in 1987. After befriending Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill) shortly after, the two decide to create their own firm, Stratton Oakmont. However, this firm gets its start in dealing with Penny stocks, and within no time becomes a billion dollar company that operates unconventionally, to say the least. From that point on the film becomes this huge blur of drugs, women, and legal troubles.Jordan likes doing cocaine. Jordan likes women. Jordan likes doing cocaine on women. We get it. He likes to get high, have casual sex with numerous females, and continue on with life as if all of this is normal. However, this is where The Wolf of Wall Street truly fails: it’s excruciatingly repetitive. Let me put it like this: if there were a person who went out of his or her way to see movies with nudity in them, they would think there was too much nudity in here. I’m not a prude or anything, but how much bush is too much bush? Now I’ve seen my fair share of films, but before seeing this, I was able to count on one hand how many times I’ve seen bush in a film. I managed to lose count after the first 90 minutes! As a result, I found it hard to root for Jordan towards the end after seeing him constantly cheat on both of his wives; Teresa Petrillo (Christin Milioti) and Naomi Lapaglia (Margot Robbie).Additionally, The Wolf of Wall Street is a long movie that begins to feel long one you reach its halfway mark. Scorsese has been known to produce long films, and this is in no way his longest, but it did begin to feel overwhelming in its final arc. Furthermore, as the film trudged on, the narrative began to lose most of its focus and consistency. Jordan’s offshore account is in jeopardy, his wife’s aunt died, he’s sailing through a storm, he’s in jail, he’s out of jail, he’s back in jail, his wife is leaving him, he tries to kidnap his kid; I felt like my head was going to explode. There is simply too much going on towards the end to make it balanced, and I think Scorsese began to realize this during the film’s production. There are stories that need to be made into movies, and there are stories that would be better off as a miniseries on television. The Wolf of Wall Street falls into the latter category.That’s not to say the film is all bad, though. On the contrary, The Wolf of Wall Street provided some of the funniest moments I’ve seen in any film of 2013. For example, there is a segment where both Jordan and Donnie take Lemmon Quaaludes, but because of their old age, they took longer to kick in than a regular Quaalude. Being ignorant of this knowledge, the two business partners decide to pop multiple pills in an attempt to feel the high. However, once they finally kick in, all hell breaks loose, and Jordan practically loses control of every muscle in his body. There was also a brief segment in the beginning when Jordan meets Mark Hanna (Mathew McConaughey), and Hanna informs him of the ins and outs of wall street, which leads to a funny, and improvised, bit from McConaughey. These comedic segments were some of the most memorable parts of the film, and it’s a shame there weren’t more of them.In addition, the performances from the entire cast were phenomenal. As ugly as Jordan is as a human being, DiCaprio managed to take the role head-on and provide one of his most convincing performances to date. He was this sex-crazed, drug-addicted, money-hungry sociopath, and he was relentless in his execution. He pulled no punches—except towards the end when he “hits” Naomi—and he truly made this person come to life for three hours. Then there was Jonah, who is quickly becoming one of the most versatile performers. Although Donnie’s character never felt like a huge importance in the grand scheme of things, Jonah was still as entertaining as ever. Milioti, Robbie, and McConaughey were really enjoyable as well, but they were kind of underutilized, in my opinion.Overall Score: 6.8/10 - It’s difficult to describe a film like The Wolf of Wall Street because it isn’t inherently bad, but it does nothing to captivate the audience. It’s so hell-bent on telling the story of Jordan Belfort that it forgets to be entertaining, it forgets to be engaging, and it forgets how to make the audience care. Sure, the film may be beautifully shot, and the performances were great, but the repetitious nature of drugs, partying, and women soon lost its luster after seeing the fourth pair of breasts. There’s always a limit to these cinematic elements, and Scorsese went way beyond it.

reviewText: I can't believe that someone actually wrote this story and lived it. The movie is profane but interesting. It is tempting to assume that there are more stories like this out there, and that's where all the money went. If so, our legal system failed miserably. The ending is too surprising not to be true. A jail sentence doesn't mean the same thing to the rich. At the very end, when he is conducting a seminar, he asks members of the audience to sell him a pen. Using his advice, I would have said "The pen is free. There will be a small shipping and handling charge".

reviewText: This not a film for children or teenagers.The main character is a greedy, ambivalent degenerate and this is his story told unflinchingly. If you want a film where the jerks and banksters of the world get their comeuppance this isn't it. This is the story of how it really goes down more often than not. It is also the story of how dangerous it is for the morally weak among us to be placed in positions of authority and how readily people in our society place them there because we want to get a ride on the gravy train. This story reminded me that the honest among us rarely get rich or rewarded and it's the characters just like this guy and his sycophants who do. People should watch this film because it may help them stop lying to themselves about how dishonest a lot of people are and how willing people are to be taken for a ride in the hopes of getting something for the price of setting aside their good sense. The main character took advantage of people by preying on their weaknesses but the people who he robbed made it easy by abandoning their judgement hoping for a few sheckles from heaven or "wherever".... This is a film for all the people who choose the personable, nice to be around, lying, incompetent types over the hardworking, honest ones who don't tell you what you want to hear. There is no difference between you and Mr. Belfort.... This film is your mirror and your wake up call....

reviewText: I watched the fifth academy award nominee for best picture this beautiful Easter Sunday morning. I have to say I was by far impressed by what I saw; this has got to be my second favorite (After Gravity) best picture nominee of the year. The film has been tagged with multiple controversies. Those controversies only made me want to see the film even more. For starters the film broke the record for most amount of uses of the f-word. Over 500 times it is said, in fact I think just about every character in the film says it at least once. Another thing is the film is 2 hours and 59 minutes long. That one there left me in a dozy, I mean that's 'King Kong' long, but the film never bores at all. Now, the film has been debated among viewers of whether or not it deserved the academy award nod, and I must full on say it definitely deserved it. It's 'Leonardo Decaprio' and 'Martin Scorsese' at their finest moments. My review of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'.'The Wolf of Wall Street' follows the aspiring, cunning, and bright young man, Jordan Belfort (Played by Leonardo Decaprio) as he cheats wall street itself selling worthless investment bonds to the rich to feed himself money, and money and money. Soon, he's so good; he can afford to throw money out into the open sea. Life is good for Belfort, he has a beautiful wife (Played by hottie, Margot Robbie), a nice ride (It's white, not red, as he clarifies early in the film), a gigantic mansion of a home, as well as two cute wonderful children, and loads of cash to spare. However when a cop (Played by the seemingly always type casted, Kyle Chandler) get's deep into his life, Belfort must stop his bachelor lifestyle, and quit his ways for good, but for him it's more easier said than done...This is a magnificent film from the magnificent 'Martin Scorsese'. While the film would seem to drag at the exhausted 3 hours, it doesn't. It always keeps your attention. Yes, do I feel some of the materiel would have best been served cut off. Sure! I feel Scorsese should have left some of the littler details off to the side, it sure would have stream lined the film a bit more, but it's still never the less entertaining.The script, in particular shines, it plays off the talent of the cast. For me, I felt the character of Jordan Belfort, was written just for 'Leonardo Decaprio', who's particularly absorbed into the materiel delightfully. The script has a few flaws in the seams. As I've already said, it get's distracted a bit with less important side plots, and it's very un-necessary. But the script does manage to supply some witty dialogue thrown around by Hill and Decaprio. It also supplies some solid character development of Belfort; you see his money seeking self from the beginning to the end, as he struggles with himself.The script also feeds us plenty of memorable scenes that we'll end up still chewing on beyond the films ending. In particular is the scene in which 'Matthew McConaughey ' starts randomly beating his chest. Another see's 'Leonardo Decaprio' crawling up to his stripper wife, who lay's her high heeled foot on his face, and playfully pushes him off.The cast portrays their roles perfectly. 'Leonardo Decaprio' coming off a wonderful role in 'The Great Gatsby' plays his part of a self centered, money hungry, playboy with style. He adds meat to his character and, performs each line, not as a line as an actual piece of word. 'Jonah Hill' also makes the most of his time, as Belfort best friend, and co-manager, Donnie Azoff. You felt the fact he really loved his part and put ump into Azoff.I feel the film didn't shine particularly in heart. The script does its best to make you feel something for Belfort toward the end, but you don't, you see him solely as a self centered jerk. A jerk is all he will be remembered as in my book. All the characters were unlikable, even if you tried to like them, you just couldn't. Hill tried his best to make his own character likable, but he too was just a jerk. When you know that at the end of the story the only character you end up relating to is the stripper wife of Belfort, you know there's something wrong.All and all, 'The Wolf of Wall Street' is a powerfully scripted, energetic, fun, and lead excellently by the performance of Leonardo Decaprio never becomes dull in its excessive 3 hour runtime. A 4/20/14'The Wolf of Wall Street' is rated R for strong sexual content, nudity, drug use, and language throughout as well as some violence. It's not appropriate for children.
summary: Sex, drugs, and three hours of pure fun!

reviewText: There are so many reviewers here on Amazon complaining about how lewd and crude the film is, obviously they are uninformed moviegoers as that is the general point of this film. Back in 2000 a movie called Boiler Room was released and loosely based on the story (although not as graphic) of Jordan Belfort. The Wolf of Wall Street is actually based of off Mr. Belfort's 'memoirs'.This is certainly filled with an incredible amount of foul language, drug abuse, sexual escapades and excessive greed. Scorsese really made a great film about the true story of a man who went out and got himself the American Dream It is the epic tale of relatively humble beginnings, the rise to power and the inevitable downfall of a man trying to get rich and everything that goes with it.

reviewText: Wolf on Wall street is based from the book on the true story of Jordan Belfort which details his rise to a wealthy stock-broker living the high life to his fall involving crime, corruption and the federal government.As a word of warning, this film hits you in the face right away with its sex, foul language and drug use and depraved behavior but does so in a way to show how bad these characters really are but this is definitely not a film for the faint of heart or for young children.  There almost isn't one scene that does have sex, drug use or some deviant behavior featured in it.  I can see the point of doing that in the film but I thought it was done a bit overly so by packing that into nearly all 3 hours of the film.  Sometimes so much so that it seemed to me that it almost got away from the point of the story and the main plot line that runs through it.DiCaprio does a good job at playing Belfort as he always does well playing eccentric characters in several films he has been in.  And once you filter all the crazy behavior that all the characters engage in, the plot is a good one with a message about the excesses of life and greed.Whether or not Belfort true tale is a bit of an exaggeration of his life or not, who knows, because as you know the old saying about those who write the history tend to write it from their view only.  Regardless of that, this movie is a crazy ride and even if half of it really happened, then wow.A decent story with a good cast, although at time gets muddled too much with the bad behavior and is a bit too long at 3 hours, but still worth watching. 3.5 stars
summary: A decent tale of corruption and greed 3.5 stars

reviewText: My husband thought this movie was hilarious, I thought this movie was trash. We do not have the same taste in movies. If you like movies about orgies, constant drug ingestion and following a bunch of Wall-Street sales hustlers who follow Jordan Belfort (the Wolf) around like a bunch of moronic, juvenile, seal-clapping sheep (with no opinions or thoughts of their own) that constantly party and shout in a state of debauchery, depravity and disgust, then this movie is for you.I was immediately offended in the opening scene and thought, oh no, it's going to be more of the same, which it was. Leonardo DiCaprio has certainly crashed from his strong, sentimental hero role in the Titanic to this role, which will only make you think less of him. I kept hoping he would be caught, but Belfort keeps resurfacing over and over in his pursuit of the almighty buck throughout the movie. The character, his friends and his wife were so greedy and superficial that you spend your time hoping he gets punishment but he never really did. Exploiting others for money and it's too bad, that this expensive movie was made for it will only lead to Jordan's Belfort ideas of himself of more self-aggrandizement.I watched Pierce Morgan's interview of him and you can see that all he did, he thought was just highly amusing, which it was not. I watched him, and after this watching this movie, I will now steer clear of financial investors if they are like this narcissistic person who you know, only wrote the book for the money and the power and the fame. The only part of this movie that did make me laugh was when he overdosed on qualudes and was driving his Lamborghini home from the country club. Then that turned gruesome when his best friend almost died choking on a hot dog.Shame on you, Martin Scorsese for spending so much money and time and energy directing this awful movie and I am glad it did not win any Academy Awards, as it did not deserve any. As far as Jordan Belfort, I do hope someone stops you (he does play a cameo of himself at the end of the movie presenting DiCaprio directing a sales presentation). Obviously, you are a person of no morals and you haven't learned any.One last thing, if you like hearing the "f" word over and over and over, then you will like this movie. Raunchy, the height of vulgarity, obscene and immature, and just downright stupid, besides the pointless sex scenes, this movie left a strong distaste for me of all the hackers that are out there trying to sell you something. (This could have been about Bernie Madoff.) Glad the Academy Awards passed this one by too. Maybe "wanna-be millionaires" would enjoy this, but I wouldn't recommend this as a way to learn how.Kelly CyrAuthor of "Supreme Love: A Battered Woman's True Story"
summary: Should of spent my time knitting instead of watching this garbage.

reviewText: "The Wolf Of Wall Street" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: This is the true story of the outlandish rise and non-stop pleasure-hunting descent of Jordan Belfort, the New York stockbroker who, along with his merry band of brokers, makes a gargantuan fortune by defrauding investors out of millions. Belfort transforms from a righteous young Wall Street newcomer to a thoroughly corrupted stock-pumper and IPO cowboy. Having quickly amassed an absurd fortune, Jordan pumps it back into an endless array of aphrodisiacs: women, Quaaludes, coke, cars, his supermodel wife and a legendary life of aspiration and acquisition without limits. But even as Belfort's company, Stratton Oakmont, soars sky-high into extremes of hedonistic gratification, the SEC and the FBI are zeroing in on his empire of excess.The cast led by Leonardo DiCaprio (also produced) (impressively putting everything on-screen, emotionally, in his Oscar-nominated performance as Jordan Belfort) & Jonah Hill (just as equally impressive in his Oscar-nominated performance as Donnie Azoff) is brilliant. The Oscar-nominated directing by Martin Scorsese (also produced) is brilliant. The Oscar-nominated screenplay (based on Jordan Belfort's book) by Terence Winter is brilliant.The cinematography by Rodrigo Prieto is brilliant. The film editing by Thelma Schoonmaker is brilliant. The casting by Ellen Lewis is brilliant. The production design by Bob Shaw is brilliant. The art direction by Chris Shriver is brilliant. The set decoration by Ellen Christiansen, set dressings by Patrice Canfield Longo, Teresa Kelly Canfield, Jamel Daniels, Damon Hahn, Christoph Heaps, Richard Hoppe, Brian Jones & Travis Wright is brilliant. The costume design by Sandy Powell is brilliant. The special effects supervised by Drew Jiritano is brilliant. The visual effects supervised by Eran Dinour, Joe Farrell, Mark O. Forker, Paul Graff, Edson Williams & Rob Legato, coordinated by Krysten Pollard & Tessa Roehl is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by G.A. Aguilar & Blaise Corrigan is brilliant. The music executive produced by Robbie Robertson is brilliant.This is an outrageous, outlandishly-crafted film that is over-the-top excess of debauchery that is, unforgettably brilliant. Leonardo DiCaprio & Martin Scorsese have teamed up again for the fifth time, to do, what could arguably said, to be, their most ambitious film yet. It is also among the best films that they have done ever, together or separately, even. The addition of Hill to the team is terrific and impressive, as he is able to match DiCaprio, step by step, in going over-the-top, emotionally, in terms of performance. Margot Robbie, who played Jordan's second wife, Naomi, is also an interesting find, as well, keeping in pace with both DiCaprio & Hill. This is one of the best films of 2013, rightfully so. This was also an impressive awards contender, being nominated for many awards and winning some awards, as well, too.
summary: "The Wolf Of Wall Street" is brilliant!

reviewText: Don't be fooled by the Oscar nominations and Scorsesee/Dicaprio pedigree, this movie is basically the latest entry in the drug/party comedy hall of fame. Wolf is less like Wall Street or Boiler Room - serious examinations of the evils of Big Finance - and more like Animal House or Van Wilder - gleeful celebrations of decadent hedonism. This film is replete with wall-to-wall sex and drugs, and is not only one of the dirtiest and raunchiest movies ever made, it's also one of the funniest. I'm not sure what necessarily constitutes an NC-17 rating, but this movie certainly toes the line. It's already infamous for dropping the most f-bombs ever, and I'm sure there's a few more records broken in its relentless nudity and substance abuse, oftentimes with both at the same time.DiCaprio deserves some sort of accolade for his brilliance. His comedic acting is like prime Jim Carrey, full or wild, rubbery physical comedy as he stumbles, dances and screams his way around the screen in a legendary performance. His sidekicks and cohorts are all similarly enjoyable as maniacs who are also permanently fried on a cocktail of narcotics.Sure, the movie hits some familiar dramatic notes to remind you that lying, stealing, greed and doping are bad. But its sermonizing is played to a bare minimum as the majority of the film is devoted to watching the filthy rich 1% having the time of their lives. While it all may be grossly immoral, it's highly enjoyable and seriously funny.
summary: This isn't really artistic cinema, it's a classic party movie

reviewText: This movie is not for the faint hearted. This 3-hour graphic portrayal of Jordan Belfort's unfettered degeneration into every form of excess imaginable leaves one gaping open mouthed.This is the fifth Scorsese/di Caprio collaboration and whereas I believe that Leonardo di Caprio is sometimes miscast, he is a consummate actor who is perfect in the lead role. Having snapped up a Golden Globe, he is looking good as an Oscar contender.There are enough other reviews outlining the plot itself, and some of the negative reviews are perplexing. They range from people who haven't even seen the movie, to those who were offended by it. There has been enough advance publicity and hype to know what to expect - if you are conservative, don't watch it! And if you have't watched it, don't review it on heresay.Yes, his lifestyle was abhorrent, but that's how it was, admittedly with a hefty portion of dramatic licence. In fact the movie is tame compared to Belfort's autobiography.  I had read the book, so I was curious to see how it would be interpreted on screen. Had I found the book offensive, I wouldn't have watched the movie.Overall, I thought it was great. It could have used tighter editing - certain scenes deteriorating from dead funny to plain silly, but compared to other overlong movies, it held my interest. It was over the top - the f-word was used over 500 times, but it is a movie about ego, self-indulgence, drugs, sex - you name it. Well done, Marty & Leo!

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: Martin Scorsese (Goodfellas, The Departed) is back in pure modern form. He takes the best of what he does with some signature camera work and mixes this film with a great script by Terrance Winter (Boardwalk Empire, The Sopranos) and some of the most incredible performances in this rather lengthy but completely compelling film called “The Wolf of Wall Street”. This is the unique story of the ups and down of a man who made his mark on Wall Street and then paid the price for it because he didn’t quite do it legally.Leonardo DeCaprio (Titanic, Inception) plays Jordon Belfort a wannabe player of Wall Street that not only proves to the big guns that he is not only capable of beating the big guys, but overpowering the Wall Street market to become the true leader of the pack in regards to Wall Street. Leonardo is amazing. His performance is sharp, funny, witty and often filled with the confusion and passion that is a man desperately getting everything he wants and learning the consequences of it. His luxurious life he eventually lives is sprinkled with drama, pain and heart-ache but mostly frustration at almost every turn.Jonah Hill (Moneyball, 21 Jump Street) pulls in another wonderful performance as the best friend of Leonardo who takes a chance and follows his business instincts and trusts Leonardo enough to ride this roller coaster with him.  Mathew McConaughey (Contact, Dallas Buyers Club) makes a short appearance and plays the senior stocker broker he first meets who teaches Leonardo the valuable lesson on making his mark on Wall Street, the one he eventually applies and does it his way. (Which happens to be illegal by the way.) Mathew is amazing to watch as he gives this very uniquely performed character a real sharp and yet creepy personality something you’ll not soon forget.Kyle Chandler (Zero Dark Thirty, Friday Night Lights) plays the FBI agent assigned to watch what seems to be Leonardo’s surprising rise to millionaire status and eventually figure out how and what he is doing. Kyle has some great scenes where he and Leonardo try and outwit each other.Rob Reiner (All In The Family, This Is Spinal Tap) plays Leonardo’s father and he is hysterical to watch and yet he has some more than parental guidance for his son but does it in some of the more memorable scenes you’ll ever see. Actor/Director Jon Favreau (Iron Man, Elf) even makes a fun character that also tries to guide Leonardo in the direction of righteousness, but to no avail.Joanna Lumley (Absolutely Fabulous, Late Bloomers) plays the aunt of his wife played wonderfully by Margot Robbie (Pan Am, About Time) and watching Joanna toy with Leonardo as the English royalty she it, is a pure delight in the film. She makes a very strange deal that changes the course of several actions in the film.It’s a fantastic movie and Leonardo’s best performance yet. It is so engaging that you really won’t notice the time flying by you. The overall performances and even when Leonardo breaks the fourth wall a couple times, it just makes sense and works well within the format of the movie. I loved it and yes there are a lot of “F” bombs and some sexual scenes, but they are not gratuitous and definitely move the story along in sync with characters and who they are.This is truly a great film and a roller coaster of events that are so well tied together it makes it easy to believe these events are actually based on things that really happened. Definitely a film that should not be missed and watched more than once because there is a lot packed in this one to be able to digest in one sitting. You go Marty!
summary: “You Must Cry “Wolf of Wall Street” Its Fantastic, Fast-Paced, Non-Stop Leonardo!”

reviewText: I saw this film in theaters and found it to be a mix of Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas and Boiler Room. It is based on Jordan Belfort's memoir of the same name and stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Belfort, a New York stockbroker who runs a firm that engages in securities fraud and corruption on Wall Street in the 1990s. In my opinion, the film is really about a wealthy man who has addictions so the Wall Street setting almost seems like a mere backdrop. There is plenty of sex, drugs, vulgar language, violence and even some incest in this film. Scorsese had to edit sexual content and nudity to avoid an NC-17 rating. It sets the record for the most uses of the f-word in a mainstream non-documentary film with over 500 uses of the word. The film received positive reviews from critics, but was also controversial for its "moral ambiguity, presence of drugs, and use of animals". It was a little more hardcore than I expected but audiences who love wild rides will enjoy it. You don't see many no holds barred movies like this anymore since R-Rated films are something of a rarity now.The audience loved the movie until the second half (it is 3 hours long) when the tone changed from happy-go-lucky to depressing as Leo's character spins out of control. Then everyone in the theater was silent as we saw cocaine and quaaludes being consumed in mass quantities. A happy balance is never achieved during the drug scenes because it seems to be glorifying substance use at times but then condemning drug abuse at other times. The film doesn't hold back showing the nasty effects of drugs and debauchery. Leo climbs into his car after a drug overdose and the results aren't pretty. The movie does convey how money, power and drugs can wreck your life. Though the film does generate some laughs I would deem the comedy as mostly the dark satire variety that leaves you feeling sorry about people who let their ambitions get out of control. The characters and plot could have been fleshed out a little more because most of the focus is on Leo. I prefer Oliver Stone's Wall Street but this film is worth viewing if you want a darker view of high finance.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What is it with Scorcese and narrative?  In Casino it was DeNiro and Pesci; in GoodFellas it was Ray Liotta.  Can't we figure out what is going on through dialogue and visuals?  Well, not in this case as there is precious little dialogue.  Can you imagine a "Casablanca" or a "Lawrence of Arabia" in which Rick or Lawrence narrate?  People just have long shouting matches.  You know, like Ray and his put upon wife in GFs and Stone and DeNiro in C.  HUGO was a great departure for Scorcese.  But this is simply a rehash, and not a very good one, of things he has done before.  Jonah Hill is nothing short of close to interesting and one never knows what draws Jordan to him nor what Hill's character brings to the table besides what look to be fluorescent teeth.  The wives are reduced to stereotypes - one the faithful woman behind the man giving sound advice when needed (and not needed) and the other the jealous harpy throwing drinks at Jordan's face.  It's not a far cry from Harry Hill's wife tracking down his girlfriend and then pointing a pistol at the sleeping Hill.  Even DiCaprio's wardrobe looks like it came off of the rack of Hill's mammoth clothes closet.  I kept thinking I've seen this scene before in "Wall Street" in ""Scarface" etc.  Excess was a theme in C and a a theme in GFs and now is a theme once again in WOWS.  And it can be argued that even Shakespeare wrote numerous plays with the same theme, he at least changed the focus or the perspective from one play to another.  I recently read a review of this film in the Guardian in which the reviewer raves that this is Scorcese's best film in twenty years - what he should have added is that it's not far from being the same film he made twenty years ago.  In the end, it is all flash and frills, bed hopping and snorting.  The film is about indulgence and indeed mirrors it.  Watch the last half hour of GoodFellas after watching this and you'll  applaud DeCaprio for his spot on imitation of Liotta.  Instead of being stuck in a land in which spaghetti sauce is ketchup, Jordan must demonstrate to nabobs the art of selling pens.  Nothing shocks here though one gets the feeling Leonardo and his mentor were looking for shock value.  One simply wonders who is guilty of the most indulgence - Marty or Jordan.  Stop resting on the laurels Marty - you're capable of better.  Or not.
summary: Did the whole thing better in Goodfellas and Casino

reviewText: Stock frauder Jordan Belfort lived the good life. His supply of money, drugs and pussy was seemingly endless. That is until he got busted by the FBI. His rise and fall is depicted here via Leonardo DiCaprio in yet another crime epic directed by Martin Scorsese. This one runs three hours long and manages to stay zippy all the way, an abundance of soft porn scenes help, but it never builds into a cohesive story. Tighter editing might’ve done the job; the Lemmon car and Monaco boat rides are particularly excessive; but even that’s doubtful. The Wolf Of Wall Street, while stimulating in its debauchery, runs along with all the incoherence and fleeting suspense of a movie that’s based on a true story.marcellee.com

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is a five stars movie because it is a great model of our capitalistic society, where money only governs a business, instead of the services rendered by the business. The fact that this is a true story makes the movie even more realistic. Today, the primary reason we create a business is not to provide services, but to get rich quickly. The Wolf of Wall Street is a perfect portrait of how our society is obsessed in earning money the faster and the easier way. This movie is recommended to all entrepreneurs and business students alike.
summary: The best movie of the year!

reviewText: The film attempts to tell the story of a penny stock hustler operating at the margins of the financial industry. But its really uninterested in those subjects. Its basically a film about the drug lifestyle told from the perspective of a drug addict. The film is so disinterested in the business it is covering that on multiple occasions it stops itself in the narration from giving explanations saying it would be "boring".They don't even properly explain what "pump and dump" is. They spend more time lecturing in extreme detail about the subtilties of Quaalude use than they spend explaining what was financially going on. Even though the film has next to nothing to do with "Wall Street", the filmmakers keep trying to push the message that its all the same thing. I dont think they managed to capture accurately most of what the scandals around Jordan Belfort were about. Years ago, "Boiler Room" (the film) actually did it better.To a degree, the film sometimes seems like its often actually telling the story of Martin Scorsese's drug-fueled lifestyle in the 1970s more than that of Jordan Belfort. The great flaw of the film is excess. Its a very long film and filled with sex scenes and drug scenes that quickly seem to have no particular point at all. The film could have been cut in half and been much better.Leonardo Di Caprio gives an unexceptional performance. The problem is that his character isn't much more than a one-dimensional sales hustler with no particular depth and sophisitication. His life is drugs and thats about it. The supporting cast is even less interesting because every character outside the lead is basically a sketch.The worst thing that could be said about the film is that its almost at the level of being a third-rate copy of earlier better films by the same director like Goodfellas and Casino. The film lacks a "human" core and an interesting story. Sex scenes, drug scenes and a degree of humor just can't carry it alone. They needed a script and a story but did not seem to have it.

reviewText: Okay, so, Martin Scorsese knows how to make a visually arresting film. This movie has all the hallmarks of great cinematography, great framing, snappy editing, and luscious attention to detail. If your eyes were mouths, they'd be crying drool. If that makes any sense.The problem -- and I'd say this is a problem that extends to a lot of movies these days -- is that so much time was spent on this film's superficial beauty that the actual story took a back seat to the sweaty, round, booty-liciousness of it all.This movie is about Jordan Belfort, a consummate salesman who gets involved with stock trades and discovers that he has both the slick patter and the complete lack of morals needed to bilk unwitting investors out of millions of their dollars. Thus begins his predictable decline into a world of sex, drugs, and rock and roll (of the "Money for Nothing" variety).Let me be clear: this is an entertaining film. However, the makers of the movie were nearly as gluttonous as its protagonist, and what could easily have been a tightly crafted ninety minutes turns into three hours of repetitive T&A; and coke-fueled manipulation, most of it making the same basic point, over and over and over and over again. And, hey, I like a nice, round booty just as much as the next guy, and I don't mind a few midget jokes, a few drug jokes, and a bit of anti-hero characterization here and there. But this movie is just packed to the gills with the stuff, to the point where you begin to wonder if Mr. Scorsese or Mr. DiCaprio needed to have nay-sayers on set to remind them that, no, not every single thing they do necessarily should make it to the screen, especially if it very closely resembles the last ten scenes they just filmed.The point being this: this isn't a terribly original film. It's a story about a young upstart that uses unscrupulous behavior to make it big at the expense of others and then realizes that his amoral behavior comes at the price of friendship, decency, and perhaps a human soul. It's an age-old story, and it's told with all the naked sumptuousness that draws audiences, but it's so enamored with it's own nipply beauty that it drags on for twice as long as it needs to. Wolves, as I've always understood them, eat quickly and thoroughly. This film, however, digests its story with the long, gluttonous patience of a snake.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Masterpiece. This film is nearly perfect in every way. With this film Scorcese becomes the greatest living American director. And I have to hand it to DiCaprio. He has matured into a flawless actor and now, as you'll see if you watch the film, a deft and subtle comedian.It's a wild ride to be sure, but it's fun and at times hilariously funny. Early in the film DiCaprio's character trains a bunch of buddies to "reel in" clients while he pantomimes reeling in a huge swordfish. The scene had me laughing out loud.The punch-line of the film is of course the sad truth that Wall Street is run by rich hedonistic frat boys who take great pleasure in stealing money from anyone dumb enough to give it over to them. Still, DiCaprio's character is intensely charismatic and intelligent if not ethical and he pokes fun at himself just enough to render him almost likable.Yes, there is a lot of sex and drug use. But that's really the point. Anyway, see the film.

reviewText: Initially, I originally thought that I was going to have to reluctantly postpone seeing The Wolf Of Wall Street for a few months due to the fact that it appeared to be unavailable in two of the theaters closest to where I live. This would have conflicted with my late night work schedule. Please know that I am thankful for my job, but was concerned that traveling too far  would have conflicted with getting to work on time. Fortunately, I spontaneously felt guided to look again yesterday morning and observed the movie location and time listings updated to show in 2 movie theaters closest to my personal residence (which would luckily give me enough time before work).  Luckily, I had the chance to see The Wolf of Wall Street this morning and it was very much worth giving up some of my sleep time to watch.  The following are some of the reasons why: Leonardo Di Caprio is one of my top seven favorite actors and he gave a brilliant performance as a man by the name of Jordan Belfort who uses his talents to help his employees and himself successfully profit from the stock market. However, one of the harbingers pointing to what is about to happen to his schemes is shown through the clue of how he basically brags to some of his employees the ways that they have profited at the expense of their clients, without expressing at least a little remorse to how he can change things around.  Additionally, a second clue is given when Belfort's father is shown going up to his son at work and warning him that what he is doing could create unintended results in his life. Margot Robbie also gives her best, as a beautiful wife who is also equally calculating in her own way and meets DiCaprio's Belfort character during a thriving peak of his life.  Jonah Hill and Matthew McConaughey are among some of the famous actors included in the film. The film does show one of the men from the Wall Street industry who may have indirectly impacted his way of thinking  in relation to dealing with clients. Additionally, the movie also showed how Belfort's notoriety caught the attention of Forbes magazine. I was familiar with some of the music played in the film due to purchasing the mp3 version of The Wolf of Wall Street Soundtrack. However, there were some good songs played in the movie that were not available on the soundtrack (such as by The Foo Fighters and Sir Mix-a-Lot).  There are also many other actors and actresses in the film that are going to appeal to various men and women watching The Wolf of Wall Street. The Wolf of Wall Street is a great film to watch for those who are fans of the work of Leonardo DiCaprio, Jonah Hill, Matthew McConaughey, Margot Robbie and/or are curious about the life of stockbroker Jordan Belfort.
summary: Days In The Life Of Jordan Belfort

reviewText: In "The Wolf of Wall Street," director Martin Scorsese and star Leonardo DiCaprio grab the audience by the scruff of the neck and shake it like a rottweiler shaking a kitten. When I saw the film, a lot of people walked out in the first hour, and I understood why: the endless, high-speed parade of dishonesty, drugs and depravity is VERY hard to take. But those of us who stuck out the film for its nearly three-hour running time were rewarded with the most brilliant, corrosive indictment ever of Wall Street scam artists. Jordan Belfort (DiCaprio) made Bernie Madoff look like Santa Claus, and Scorsese spares us no detail of the fathomless greed of Belfort and his cronies at the bogus trading firm of Stratton Oakmont.Scorsese is obviously fascinated by these swine, as he was by the mobsters of "Goodfellas." But being fascinated by them and admiring them are two different things. Belfort, his right-hand man Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill), and their associates are devilishly fun  to watch with their charm and chutzpah, but they are not likable or admirable for one second, and they are not meant to be. Scorsese, DiCaprio, Hill and the others let these self-aggrandizing jerks hang themselves with their own designer ties. The cast members seem to be having a blast making these characters as outrageously hateful as they possibly can, and the performances are extraordinary straight down the line. The best-acted scene I've seen this year comes in the middle of "The Wolf of Wall Street," between a smug Belfort and a canny FBI agent (Kyle Chandler) who is a lot smarter than Belfort--who measures a person's intelligence by the size of his bank account--gives him credit for."The Wolf of Wall Street" is a magnificently orchestrated train wreck of avarice, lust, and wasted lives. The muted, equivocal ending is far more disturbing than a standard-issue movie comeuppance would have been, and suggests strongly that the financial wreckage created by Belfort will continue and multiply, long past the foreseeable future.
summary: The wildest ride of any film in recent memory.

reviewText: Theatrical review.  There may be spoilers.Anytime Martin Scorsese makes a movie, film lovers line up to see what's poppin' this time around.  Rarely does he disappoint and "Wolf" is no exception.  In an award-worthy performance, Scorsese regular, Leonardo DiCaprio gives perhaps his greatest performance as Jordan Belfort, a real life self-made man who skirted the law selling penny stocks in the early 1990's.  Fired from his dream job of being a Wall Street broker after the market collapse of 1987, he fumbled around until he answered a want ad for a stock seller located in a strip center.  He quickly determined this was an easy, if shady, way to earn a living.  Commissions on penny stocks was 50% of the sale.Belfort was a great salesman and started his own company using the haughty title of Stratton Oakmont, recruiting friends with no experience as salesmen.  His first partner was a stranger he met in a café.  Donnie Azoff (excellent Jonah Hill) was just as crazy as Belfort, but without the charm and sales skills.  Still he had connections as did many of his core crew."Wolf" earns its `R' rating as Belfort's success is played out in unconventional ways.  Often, he would reward his staff (mostly men) with booze, drugs and women.  Not just strippers mind you but prostitutes.  He even had 3 classes of whores.  If memory serves they were blue chips, NASDAQ and pink sheets (penny stocks).After Jordan's first marriage fails, he marries Naomi Lapaglia (stunningly beautiful Margot Robbie) who he oogled and pursued after a chance meeting at a party.  The Australian Ms. Robbie, in her first big screen role, pulls off a convincing Queens accent as well as her clothes.  She's very good and very good to look at.There are many good scenes in the film including a lunch meeting between Belfort and his first boss, Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey again great in this brief appearance).  He gave Jordan some advice.  Drugs.  Another memorable scene takes place on Belfort's huge yacht which he named after Naomi.  Belfort had requested a meeting with the FBI after he discovered they had subpoenaed a list of attendees at his recent wedding.  Agent Denham (Kyle Chandler) was in charge of an investigation of fraud and comes to the boat.  Belfort pulls out the charm offensive and it appears Denham is lapping it up.  Belfort goes a bit overboard, however and makes some not-so-subtle hints of bribery.  It's a great piece of acting between the two and certainly a well written scene of which there are many.This movie doesn't pull many punches when it comes to debauchery, raunchiness and perversion so be aware.  There are many naked bodies (of both sexes) and piles of pills and crank.  It is also one of the most entertaining and funny movies I've seen this year.  The sets for the period look authentic and the soundtrack is a big plus.  The film runs 3 hours and while there was a scene or two that could have been shortened, the time went by quickly.  This is one of the best films of 2013.
summary: A satirical look at the king of Wall Street hedonism and one of the best films of the year

reviewText: ***There are spoilers contained in this review***"The Wolf of Wall Street" was a decent movie. I was throughly entertained, however, I was not engaged. To me, the story was weak. Actually, looking back, the movie did not have much of a story. The one thing about the movie I can remember was the sex. There was so much sex, I'm surprised this movie did not get an NC-17 rating. The women were mostly naked the entire time, and it felt like every other scene was some sort of copulation. One minute we are receiving exposition by Leo's character, the next Leo is giving it to some nameless actress. Seriously, I'm surprised the director, Martin Scorsese, did not show actual penetration.During my 3 hour long journey into "The Wold of Wall Street," which really was Hollywood's interpretation of Wall Street, I did not feel any sort of attachment to the characters. Many, if not most, were very two dimensional. Our the primary concerns for our "heroes" were sex and drugs. That was it. Towards the end, we began to see the main character pay more attention to his family, especially in a scene where his wife tries to take the children. However, at this point in the story, it did not feel organic. At 2.5 hours into the movie, any depiction of the main character caring about people seemed out of place. We spent the entire movie focusing on how big of scumbag this guy was, then towards the end, they try to redeem him. The only character I truly liked was the FBI Agent, but there was so little screen time that he often came across as a cold, unlikeable, stick-in-the-mud.If you want to watch a movie with a really rich story, look elsewhere. If you watch to see a porno, look elsewhere. If you want to see a movie that is the middle-ground between a decent story and porno, this might be a good movie for you.

reviewText: I gotta jump in here.  There are so many negative reviews here.  "It has no point."  "It goes on too long!"  "It's like porn."  These are some of the film's criticisms.  And it's funny: these criticisms say more about the people who were watching the film than it does about the film at all.  Okay, fair enough: WofWSt. is a very dirty film, not for the faint of heart.  It is a movie about behavior, like so many other Martin Scorsese pictures.  More to the point, it is about BAD behavior.  If Goodfellas was the original, and Casino the sequel...well, I say Wolf is the third in a trilogy of Bad Behavior Films by Scorsese.  The same criticisms were leveled against Goodfellas at the time of its release--it's excessive, it's glamorizes the lifestyle and sets a bad example,etc.--but is now considered one of the best American films made.  Wolf probably won't live up to that expectation because it's not a pioneer the way Goodfellas was, but it's a wild and intense and funny ride, nevertheless.And for those of you who say there is no point, I couldn't disagree more.  Perhaps read this excerpt from Matt Zoller Seit's review.  Wolf is not a political movie, but is summed up rather nicely here, if not slightly in political terms:"Men like Belfort (Dicaprio) represent us, even as they're robbing us blind. They're America, and on some level we must be OK with them representing America, otherwise we would have seen reforms in the late '80s or '90s or '00s that made it harder for men like Belfort to amass a fortune.... Belfort was never punished on a level befitting the magnitude of pain he inflicted. According to federal prosecutors, he failed to abide by the terms of his 2003 restitution agreement. He's a motivational speaker now, and if you read interviews with him, or his memoir, it's obvious that he's not really sorry about anything but getting caught. We laugh at the movie, but guys like Belfort will never stop laughing at us...""We enable them by reveling in their exploits or not paying close enough attention to their misdeeds, much less demanding reform of the laws they bend or ignore—laws that might have teeth if we hadn't allowed guys like Belfort... to legally bribe the United States legislative branch via... campaign financing. After a certain number of decades, we should ask if the nonstop enabling of addicts like Belfort doesn't mean that, in some sense, their enablers are addicted, too—that they (we) are part of a perpetual-motion wheel that just keeps turning and turning. In the end "Wolf" is not so much about one addict as it is about America's addiction to capitalist excess ..."

reviewText: Honestly, this is a big "hmmmm..."If you mash up Limitless with Wall Street you get this... and at 3hrs, it is a looong film. Broadly speaking, a biopic, we see the debauched and immoral lives of stock-traders from the end of the 80's through to the mid 90's. And of course, it is supposed to echo the nonsensical trading that went out before the current recession.The problem with this movie is that it suffers from exactly the same problem as Wall St and Limitless - the central character is a drug addled, amoral, criminal. There is no coverage on the effect that his action had (all the blue collar workers who lost their life savings), and it just seems to revel in its debauchery as a pale imitation of Scarface or Blow. I spent three hours wanting Di Caprio wanting him to get badly hurt.Did he? Not really - three years in jail and then a successful speaking career. Wholly dissatisfying.

reviewText: "The Wolf of Wall Street" is a drama and black comedy genre film, which brings to life much of the book written by Jordan Belfort.Notably, numerous names from the book were changed for the movie. Also, some events from the book were not included or were slightly altered, but the vast majority of the book was represented on screen.The narrative takes the viewer inside Belfort's world of high, reckless living, which was ruled by money and dissipation.With so many jaw dropping scenes the film running time of 179 minutes never drags as from start to finish the viewer witnesses a depraved ride, which was those years Belfort made Wall Street his own cash cow.Nicholas R.W. Henning - Australian Author

reviewText: This was overall a good movie.My brother told me that it was from the same person who created "Goodfellas." Since I liked that movie, I decided to give this one a try.This movie was organized in the same style that "Goodfellas" was, with the protagonist narrating in certain sections of the movie.I think that we can all easily identify with the premise of this film. Our human desire for power. The Wolf finds a way to get it by taking shortcuts and cutting corners. As in real life, there is always a balancing force and the Wolf turns more into a mouse that is being chased by the FBI.It is great entertainment. I didn't give it a perfect score because it did seem too long of a movie. I remember checking the bar on the screen that colors in as the movie progresses and it was barely halfway.The pros are that the actress that plays Leonardo's wife is "amazingly hot." There was something about her New York accent that just did it for me. I guess because she reminded me so much of a stripper that I once dated.Some parts of the film seemed redundant. The purchasing-of-hookers side kept getting re-introduced over and over, down to the 3 categories of hookers that they would get.Where "Goodfellas" felt somewhat more like a serious film to me, this one seemed comedic at times. I suppose because of actor Johan Hill who has been funny as hell in so many movies.This movie delivered in that I felt motivated after I watched it. It made me realize that life is like a game that we learn to play, but there are unseen rules, a karmic balancing act. We seek the roads that lead to quick wealth at the expense of others, and seemingly just as quickly we sink. There are unexpected surprises at every corner. You can go from giving your wife a huge yacht as a present one day, and end up living in a small, claustrophobic prison cell the next.If you have three hours to spare, this movie can definitely entertain.

reviewText: ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ was one of the best films of 2013 and also one of the most difficult to watch. The film is a portrait of the excesses of the corporate life on Wall Street as exemplified by the life of Jordan Belfort and chronicles his humble beginnings as a naive stockbroker and takes us through his transformation as an unrepentant corporate vulture. Almost none of the characters portrayed shows any ethics or morality except the FBI Agent Patrick Denham portrayed by Kyle Chandler who at the end of film is shown riding the subway alone in obvious discomfort while Jordan Belfort, after a short stay in a luxurious prison with tennis courts, continues with his ability to acquire wealth.It is not hard to understand the difficulty in watching this film as expressed by comments here on Amazon. Almost all of the cast are either crooks or unethical idiiots who win big. Greed is good and highly profitable in the world of ‘Wolf of Wall Street’. The mostly male brokers win great rewards. They accumulating money, property, and hot babes, consume drugs, and curse frequently, while those who play by the rules end up with very little, not even the satisfaction of beng recognized as behaving honorably. The behavior portrayed is alpha male behavior of the corporate world at its worst. Scorcese’s intention is to satirize the world of financial greed, which, by all reports, is not exaggerated in this film. A key scene repeated several times is the grunt and chest thumping scene. You could have taken this directly out of Ridley Scott’s “Gladiator’.  A large room of white shirted men grunt and pound their chests to a camera positioned at a point of view in front and above them as if they are saluting an unseen emperor sitting on a podium. These are the modern warriors of the corporate world. The viewer watching these scenes should feel uncomfortable but I suspect that many do not.The film begins with Jordan Belfort (Leonard diCaprio) portraying a likeable newbie stockbroker working for Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey).  Hanna advises Belfort to use sex and drugs to succeed in business. Hanna also demonstrates to Belfort many of the key ideas of behaving like an ‘alpha wolf’ such as chest pounding. Belfort soon loses his job but re-invents himself in the image of Hanna and succeeds in building a company that amasses millions by cheating the poorest of investors. Along the way, Belfort loses his wife, picks up a trophy wife, and make millions of dollars exploiting the poorest of investors. Belfort manages to escape justice by making deals with the authorities and turns on his fellow stockbrokers but then has an epiphany. He realizes that he must change his ways when he escapes sudden death when an aircraft blows up before his eyes.The plot is filled wth humorous satire and we often laugh at the screen portrayals of the main characters. We are also titulated by the sex, the drugs, Belforts successes,  and other excesses. It is an uncomfortable laugh for us, the viewer, that is mixed with our simultaneous admiration and attractiion to the terrible behavior we see before us on screen. Scorcese’s choice of picking diCaprio to play Belford was inspired. Audiences found him both likable and despicable at the same time. His cherub-like face and manner, like many TV huckster get-rich-quick spokesman, made him instantly appealing. Occassionaly, Belfort’s conscious finds its way out and peeks at us during the course of the film. However we are also shocked by his appalling treatment of his wives, and his excessive use of sex and drugs. He dresses well, has lots of sex with beautiful woman, and parties enough to put most of the rest of us into an early grave. His guilt sometimes is apparent in his glances. I beleive that it is the performance by diCaprio that parlty resulted in some professional critics, bothered by it, to criticize the film’s moral ambiguity.  I do not think that this ambiquity was accidental.Scorcese wants us to be seduced by the world of ‘Wolf of Wall Street’. The story of the film is told through the eyes of Jordan Belford.  Remember, the entire film is narrated by Belfort. This is his world. We are pushed to laugh at the antics on the screen even as we grimace with horror when we understand the criminality and bad behavior beneath it. We are pushed to admire this world of corporate greed, the world of the alpha male, and at the same time, feel guilty about our admiration. Some of us might actually get defensive if we see ourselves uncomfortably reflected in the characters in this drama. The victims of Belfort are hidden from us in the background. We are prompted to give little thought to the poor investors being scammed by Belfort.  This isn’t the story of the victims; this is the story of the winners. If this sounds familar, then you might remember Scorcese’s other film that is narrated by a criminal, ‘Goodfellas’. Scorcese uses the same technique here in plot narration. the difference is that whereas in ‘Goodfellas’ the story is about professional crimminals, ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ is about professional businessman. In ‘Goodfellas’ we see the story through the eyes of a life-long criminal, a killer. In  ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ we see the story through a white-collar criminal in the corrupt business world.FBI agent Patrick Denham is Belfort’s nemesis in the film.  Played by Kyle Chandler, Denham is the ethical and moral center of the film who devotes his life to bring Belfort to justice. We do not like Denham very much. He is portrayed in the film as a dull government policeman. Chandler’s unlikability is accented in the film by his droopy hangdog face and his permanent five-o’clock shadow. Denham is Belforts equal which is made clear in the confrontation between the two on the deck of Belfort’s yacht, one of the film’s  key scenes. A well dressed, well spoken Belfort is bested in a verbal duel with poorly dressed, dull agent Denham. A scene is also inserted at the end of the film in which Scorcese seems to be asking us who do we admire the most; successful Belfort or drab Denham?“Wolf of Wall Street’ was not my favorite of the ‘best’ films of 2013. I liked most of the others much better, especially ’12 Years a Slave’, ‘Gravity’, and ‘Dallas Buyer’s Club’. However it is an excellent film. One of Scorcese’s best. I have not commented much on the hard ‘R’ rating of this film or it’s length. I did not see this film in a theater which would have made seat time almost unbearable and I can understand that the hard ‘R’ nature of the film turned many people off, but I hope that that any readers of my comments here will understand my perspectives. I see ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ as a dismal portrayal of the Wall Street world of business just as ‘Goodfellas’ was a dismal portrayal of the world of organized crime.  We are supposed to see beyond the glitter of Jordan Belford’s life and see the worthlessness beneath. Perhaps this film refects the real world of American business too much and viewers recognize themselves in the film and feel badly and retreat into denial. I remember reading long ago that professional crimminals who saw ‘Goodfellas’ said that the characters were accurate portrayals and recognized themselves in the film.Fans of Scorcese will like this film despite it’s length. It is worth watching twice. Watch it and consider that the film is all about how you, the viewer, react to a critical portrayal of the American way of business.
summary: The Wolf in All of Us

reviewText: "The Wolf Of Robin Hood" (2013 release; 179 min.) brings the Hollywood interpretation of the memoirs by Wall Street stock broker and trader Jordan Belfort. As the movie opens, Belfort (played by Leonardo DiCaprio) is starting his career at a blue chip Wall Street firm. On his first day on the job, he is taken out to lunch by his boss (played by Matthew McConaughey, in a short (less than 10 min.) but memorable performance). Soon thereafter, Black Monday happens (Oct. 1987) and Belfort loses his job. It's not long before he finds a new job selling "penny stocks" in a low profile stockbroker firm on Long Island, and after he sees the money-winning ways of that, he and his buddy Donny (played by Jonah Hill) start their own firm called Stratton Oakmont, which soon becomes an upstart success (along with its hard-charging life style), to the chagrin of others on Wall Street. To tell you more of the plot might spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.Couple of comments: this is the fifth collaboration between DiCaprio and director Martin Scorsese, the previous one being 2010's Shutter Island. They are also co-producers of this movie. The  movie's 3 hour running time is, frankly, a bit of a challenge. In particular the first half of the movie is a bit too much repetitive (yes, we get it, these guys did a lot of sex and drugs). Things become far more interesting when things start going south for Belfort & Co. At one point, Forbes Magazine comes to do a profile, and upon its publication, Belfort is indignant of the less than flattering portrait, when the article terms him "like a twisted Robin Hood, he steals from the rich to give to himself". The last hour of the movie is when it all comes together for us, the neutral viewer, as we finally become emotionally invested in Belfort and those around him, as they are desperately trying to hang on and stay ahead of the feds. Not surprisingly, the acting performances are generally stellar, none more so than from DiCaprio, whom we see  deliver yet another winning dramatic role (the highlight being one of the 'pep talks' he gives to the Stratton brokers before the Steven Madden IPO, when he exclaims that "there is no nobility in poverty!". The other surprise is fairly newcomer Margot Robbie, an Australian actress, in the role of Naomi (Belfort's second wife). Also worth mentioning is the incredibly rich production, which is apparent in even the smallest details. Bottom line: having seen the trailer a couple of times in recent weeks, and knowing the quality of DiCaprio and Scorsese, I came into this with sky-high expectations. They were not met. No, this is not a 'poor' movie by any stretch, but neither is it the riveting "Wall Street is bad" drama that it could've been, although as already mentioned, the last hour thankfully makes up for this, at least partially.The movie opened here in Cincinnati for the Christmas holiday, and when we went to see it today in a late matinee, imagine my surprise how poorly attended this particular screening was (the movie theatre as a whole seemed to be bursting with people, but clearly they went elsewhere). Given the 3 hr. running time and the not always easy viewing, I would be surprised if this became a box office hit. That said, if you like DiCaprio or Scorsese, you'll still want to check this out, be it in the theatre, or on DVD/Blu-ray.
summary: 3.5 stars... "Like a twisted Robin Hood, he steals from the rich to give to himself"

reviewText: Nine Things about “The Wolf of Wall Street”1. This is a raunchy, foul-mouthed tale of American greed based on the memoirs of Jordan Belfort, a stockbroker convicted of market manipulation.2. I think this movie contains more drugs, sex, and swearing than all the other movies I saw this year put together. Of course it’s gratuitous – this guy’s whole lifestyle was gratuitous. So it works.3. This movie is also an acidly funny satire on Wall Street.4. Leonardo DiCaprio stars as Jordan, a money-hungry young man with more ambition than brains.5. Jordan hires his knucklehead weed dealer friends to start a small semi-legal stockbroker firm. As they get more successful, they get less legal.6. DiCaprio has always been an excellent actor – but this may be his best performance ever. And Jonah Hill is also great as the douchebag friend.7. Jordan’s schemes were complicated and hard to understand for us regular folk, but the movie does a good job of dumbing it down – mostly by telling us that all we need to know is that he’s doing really illegal things.8. The scene where Jordan overdoses on Quaaludes is a minor masterpiece of physical comedy and is one of the single best scenes of the year. I didn’t know DiCaprio had it in him.9. The movie is three hours long, so, like the stock market, this movie is an investment of your time. But it’s worth it.

reviewText: Martin Scorsese is an old generation filmmaker who uses vulgarity and believes that a movie should be longer than 85 minutes. It is about Jordan Belfort, a millionaire from the previous generation who believed that morality was a flexible thing that could be used to fit situations as they arise. However, The Wolf of Wall Street was released in 2013 for a generation that believes in a very specific, rigid definition of morality that mustn't ever be tainted. This is a good and bad thing, mostly bad if you're a white straight American male with more than a little bit of money like the main character of this film/book it was based on. Before anything must be said about the movie itself, it has to be addressed that people are outright refusing to separate the art from the artist, as people nowadays are apt to do. "It glorifies bad behavior! Capitalism is wrong! How dare that nice young man Leo do ___ or say ___!" If you watched a good third of this movie and came away with some of these thoughts, perhaps complaining about misogyny in a Rachel McAdams film is more your speed. This is a Martin Scorsese film. And man does it feel good to be able to say that again: "...from the director of Taxi Driver and Goodfellas, Martin Scorsese..."For the rest of us who wanted more than anything a return to good cinema, The Wolf of Wall Street is a sign that not all is lost in Hollywood. Expertly shot and cast with a smart script, equal parts topical and fantastical, based on a wild life either you'd never want to experience but can't look away from a car wreck or are seriously jealous of, complete with Scorsese's signatures - an absolutely terrific soundtrack, surprisingly good comedic performances from the leads, passionate Italian women yelling and hitting, and quotes you'll never get out of your head. If there's one thing Martin Scorsese's been able to do as a filmmaker that not a lot of other people can achieve, it's being able to tell a story in such a way that you want to know what happens next. Many other great movies rarely get that feeling just right: the feeling of being a kid, listening to an old man tell it like it used to be, and wanting to hear more because it genuinely interested you. People who gave this movie low ratings because of the unlikable characters obviously don't know what that feeling is like. Can you imagine hearing a war story and thinking "gee, I wish I was in Vietnam?" No. Does that make it a bad story? No.
summary: Great movie, made for the wrong generation.

reviewText: 'The Wolf Of Wall Street' is a film that is so darn long, you think it will never end. I understand it was cut by two hours from the original four. It could have been cut by at least another 30 minutes. It is one darned thing after another, but some of the action is so drawn out and repetitious that I lost interest at one point. The last 30 minutes picked up and carried the film.We meet Jordan Belfort on his first day on Wall Street. One of the traders, played by Matthew Mc Conaughey, takes him under his wing, and teaches him how to make millions. He also teaches him a crazy chest beating chant that Jordan Belfort carries with him throughout his life. He loses the job in the 1987 depression, but then starts up his own firm in Long Island and started making millions and millions of dollars. We are privy to his actions, his under the counter transactions, excessive lifestyle, booze, drugs and women. The Bacchanalian actions of the entire team are on display. Money, it seems, lends itself to every habit known to man.Leonardo DiCaprio plays Jordan Belfort to perfection. Jonah Hill plays Donnie Azoff, one of the more unlikable men in the group - that man was without a conscience. Rob Reiner as Belfort's father tries to help his son stay on the straight and narrow. Many characters in this film, and most are as bad as the next. This is an entertaining film, but again, much too long.The sex, violence and drugs are what occurred during this time in the 80's and 90's. If you do not like sex, drugs, rock'n'roll and four letter words, forget this film. It is not for you. Martin Scorsese directed this film, and it is a good one, good not great. This film was taken from the book written by Jordan Belfort, who is not a fan of the film. It depicts him as the greedy, unlikable man he is. He is now on the speaker's circuit after spending a short time in prison.This is an entertaining, if not too long film. Funny at times, but sad at others. Money really is the root of all evil.Recommended. prisrob 03-26-14

reviewText: Jordan Belfort: "I'm a former member of the middle class raised by two accountants in a tiny apartment in Bayside Queens. The year I turned 26 as the head of my own brokerage firm, I made 49 million dollars, which really pissed me off because it was three shy of a million a week." Believe it or not, Jordan Belfort is a real person and much of the depravity portrayed in this movie is factual. But real or fictional, Belfort is absolute pond scum in my book...and his is not a story that merits a film about him...especially a film by Martin Scorsese. I say shame on the production team which included Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio; shame on you Scorsese for directing this travesty; and shame on you DiCaprio for staring in it. If you added up the smut time; the profanity, nudity, sex and drug use - most of it gratuitous - it would likely account for 80% of this 179 minute film. I watched it to the bitter end to see this sleazeball get his due...but I hit the fast-forward button often. I can't recommend it to anyone for any reason...Academy Award nominations or no!!
summary: A story that didn't need to be told...a movie that shouldn't have been made!

reviewText: I can't remember the last time I've had as much fun at a movie as The Wolf of Wall Street since The Departed. In recent memory, only The Avengers comes to mind. But what makes The Wolf of Wall Street such a success is that it shows Martin Scorsese doing what he does best. He takes the tale of Jordan Belfort, an intelligent yet mischievous stockbroker who was very skilled at swindling stocks, manipulating the stockmmarket, and turns it into the cinematic equivalent of an injection of coke, meth, heroin, codeine, aderall and a number of uppers and downers- all at once. In other words, it's a crazy, wild ride. And if this were any other filmmaker, it wouldn't have turned out as well as it did, nor would I have been able to sit through it for two hours, let alone the three hours that The Wolf of Wall Street runs. But this is Scorsese, folks. His films are famous for effectively blending in substance and style in equal parts, and this film is no different at all.Perhaps the most memorable thing about The Wolf of Wall Street is, and face it, you saw this coming, Leo DiCaprio's performance. You probably already knew DiCaprio would give an amazing performance, but here he gives his best yet. He completely snaps into character and gives a bravura performance that's completely real. From the opening scenes alone, where he gives an almost Patrick Batemanesque introspective into his life and career, his cars, his home, his past time pleasures such as excessive drug use and drugged out chaos, sex with hookers and what have you, you're in the palm of his hand. The scenes where he talks to the camera about certain subjects is where you can see the amount of confidence he has bursting at the scenes. His David Tennant style delivery of his speeches to his staff at Stratton Oakmont just shows he was born to play this role. It's a tricky role to take on too, as his character is involved in tons of debauchrous situations; but the aforementioned confidence of DiCaprio is what keeps it believable.And in general, just how well the essence of the story is captured is unbelievable. The film runs a mammoth 3 hours, and is a lot to take in. However, it's so entertaining that you could sit and watch and be entertained if it ran an hour longer. In fact, I'm pretty amazed that they even fit this all in in three hours. A lot of things happen in the story, and they're all tremendous. In fact, direction wise, Scorsese's DNA is splashed all over this film too. The scene where Belfort is caught for his crimes mid-commercial filming is absolutely hilarious; the slow motion shots with narration about things such as how certain drugs work are charming, in a sort of filthy and debauchrous way too. There's funny scenes a- plenty, such as a long gag involving a high from an extreme drug made with lemon extract (how DiCaprio and Hill managed to hold it together in the face during these scenes is amazing, even). And the trademark "Scorsese timing", where scenes are swiftly paced and smartly blocked is on full display as well. So it goes to say that Scorsese has made yet another substantial and directorial masterpiece.In short, The Wolf of Wall Street is without a doubt a late must-see and contender for "best of the year". Of the last batch of movies to be released this year, this sure drew the year to a satisfying close, and we can only hope that this will get the academy awards it deserves. Do yourselves a favour too and see this on the big screen, with a packed audience. I saw it this afternoon, and the packed crowd was one of the best audiences I've experienced- much like my first time seeing The Departed. It certainly benefits from the big screen experience. And just one more thing: Academy, if you're reading this review, do us all a favour and give Leo his Oscar NOW! He's truly earned it with this film.
summary: Certainly NOT all bark and no bite

reviewText: This is probably one of Scorsece's worst movies I have seen and I have seen them all.  The story has too many holes and things that don't follow the plot line.  Basically, it is a story of a corrupt wall street broker who gets caught.  Duhh!.  No tension in the movie.  Time is spend way too much with the partying and crazy acting.  The main character is way over the top in emotional responses and is more of a caricature than a believable person.Holes in the plot, like at the end, main character goes against his agreement with the Feds, so naturally they arrest him, then next scene he is at the trial saying how he gave up his people.  Well I thought he was going to jail because he broke his agreement, but all of a sudden the agreement is intact and off to jail he goes with a reduced sentence.  No connection here.Another one is showing his wife pregnant at one point and then next scene she is not?  The movie never mentions this 2nd child and when the main character says he wants his kids, he only grabs one?  Where is the 2nd one?  Really stupid editing and direction in this movie.So 3/4 of the movie is about his partying, not tension or conflicts.  Then the last 1/4 is really weak with him finally getting caught, goes plays tennis in jail and then he is out.There are many many more of these inconsistencies and poor direction and editing.  I gave it two stars for some great acting even though it was way over the top.

reviewText: I decided to watch this lengthy flick after I learned that Scorsese and DiCaprio were invited to the White House on Wednesday, December 18. Learning of it, I imagined idyllic picture of the President showing to them his trophies from Columbia, the First Lady serving homemade preserves from her organic backyard, the girls showing pictures of their spring break in Mexico, and all having great time discussing the importance of family values from Chicago's South Side.With the above in mind I purchased my ticket and sat in anticipation of unfolding masterpiece before my eager eyes. The film starts with an anal application of powdered crack to a hooker's bare behind; it's what Leo DiCaprio does, using plastic straw. And to make long story short, the rest of the movie doesn't get any better. Big let down.This great DiCaprio, who shared a piece of driftwood with Winslet to make her heart go on, and save her from drowning in icy seas, whose goodness of heart made tens of millions of teenage girls cry, is now blowing crack to hookers' bottoms though a straw. This would make the young ladies cry all over again.It's a filth-fest.
