reviewText: As an amateur moralist but avid movie buff; at times I will give extra leeway to a creative film that utilizes the portrayed gratuity of sex, violence, and drug use in the production. First examples that come to mind are The Piano, Trainspotting, and the Godfather. I feel that the directors of these films were evenhanded in showing the audience scenes that were not "over the top"; giving us details that we needed to see in order to tell the story that is worth telling. The story worth telling in The Wolf was already told quite well in Wall Street with Charlie Sheen and Michael Douglas. This is simply an updated version minus proper character  and plot development with an hour to spare and a few extra million laying around. One final analogy: If the producers of Dawn of the Dead suddenly gave George Romero another $5 million preproduction,  what would be best thing to do: add another 1000 zombies?After all is said and done, Leonardo Dicaprio is a fine actor and Martin Scorcese is a fine director that lost focus on this one.

reviewText: I'm a HUGE fan of  Martin Scorsese, but THE WOLF OF WALL STREET is nothing near his best work.  In fact, it feels a bit like lazy filmmaking to me in that it basically strikes the same note over and over again (to the point of becoming totally tiresome).  What do I mean by that?  Well, the DiCaprio character basically drones on and on through voiceover about how great he is, then proclaims it to others (usually the traders who work for him), then celebrates his greatness through excessive use of drugs (or hookers combined with excessive use of drugs), and after he's come down from his high he involves himself in some sort of shady business endeavor, after which he gets high again, cohorts with hookers again, etc. etc.  It seems as if the entire film is basically constant repetition of the same plot template.  There's no in-depth examination of DiCaprio's character of the world he occupies - we just get the same tired repetition of the same shallow plot drivers over and over again.  And I'm not one to go on about misogyny in film, but the demeaning characterization of women in this concoction, without any interrogation of why they're presented that way, or any complexity whatsoever in the female characters, is way over the top!  After a while, even I became uncomfortable with how women were depicted as receptacles designed solely for the insertion of penises.  I couldn't get behind this one.

reviewText: THE WOLF OF WALL STREET is insanely hyper-kinetic, wall-to-wall with sex and drug-taking, and the most energetic Scorsese has been since CASINO and GOODFELLAS. While this doesn't quite live up to those previous films, it is nevertheless quite entertaining. The story follows the rise and fall of Jordan Belfort, who ran a brokerage firm, Stratton Oakmont, in the late 80's/early 90's. Along the way, he makes a ton of money and indulges his every whim, which was mostly a lot of drugs. A smaller part of the story is how he was taken down by the FBI, but the main draw is obviously Jordan. In his previous gangster/crime films, Scorsese provided the viewer with a window into how those criminal enterprises operate, and he does the same here with white collar crime. One thing which was extremely effective, yet detracts from the experience a little bit, was how Scorsese used cinematic technique and a frenetic editing style to convey the themes of excess, over-indulgence and greed. It makes logical sense that a film about a person like Jordan Belfort would be this stuffed, even if it does start to wear on the viewer after a while (as it certainly did me). Fortunately, there were some quieter moments, and scenes where a voice of reason could be heard, even if it was ultimately ignored. However, there should be something said about the end result. Unlike previous characters who were reduced to shells of their former selves, Jordan Belfort gets off fairly lightly. Sure, he goes to prison, but it's a cushy prison and he only has to serve a few years. Perhaps this is cynicism on Scorsese's part, and maybe it's emblematic of where our society has gone. Instead of the ultimately good-natured criminal who looks out for the interests of a family-like organization, we have greedy vultures who only look out for themselves, and by and large we let them take advantage of us in ways that are truly despicable. The film makes a point about not showing the victims of Jordan's crimes, but I didn't find this too disheartening. The movie is meant to revolve around Jordan and to give the viewer an experience which approaches what his life was like. Sure, parts of it are extremely funny, but underneath all of the humor lies a rather masochistic current. Excess will ruin you, and by the end of this you should feel disgusted at how people are treated (especially the women) and exhausted from the whirlwind ride you've just been taken on. Even though the film does become repetitive after a while, I wouldn't have wanted to be taken on this journey with anyone but Scorsese. It's not quite a masterpiece, or even top-tier Scorsese, but it's a film worth watching even if only once.
summary: My review of "The Wolf of Wall Street" (potential spoilers)

reviewText: Martin Scorsese's "The Wolf of Wall Street" is loosely based on a memoir of the same name by Jordan BelfortThe Wolf of Wall Street (Movie Tie-in Edition), the main protagonist and the anti-hero of this movie portrayed by Leonardo DiCaprio. Terrence Winter turned Belfort's book into a highly effective screenplay. "The Wolf of Wall Street" focuses upon the hard elements of American life, as do most Scorsese films. The cinematography is  stunning, and the movie holds the viewers attention through its three-hour length.As portrayed in the film, Belfort would be a wolf on any American or Scorsese street, including Wall Street. The movie focuses on raw greed, lust for power, sex, and drugs.  Belfort's unscrupulous greed has no bounds.  As the film opens, he is hired by a Wall Street brokerage firm, receives instructions in hustling from a colleague over a drug, alcohol filled lunch and must seek new employment when his firm closes on Wall Street's Black Friday. He soon secures a job hustling penny stocks and excels with his high pressure salesmanship. Then, with some marijuana -trading buddies, he opens his own brokerage house, with the establishment-sounding name of Stratton Oakmont. The fun and fraud truly begin, as Belfort attracts a crew of greedy salespeople, pursues many scams, and quickly becomes unconscionably rich. A hard-working, unpretentious FBI agent played by Kyle Chandler is soon on Belfort's case and ultimately brings about conviction, bar from the securities industry, large fine, and relatively short prison sentence.Besides the scenes of financial fraud, the movie is laced with profanity (including over 600 use of the --word, a record for a feature film), sex orgies, paid and otherwise, and drug use.  Belfort lived, to say the least, a high life of excess with a mansion, fancy cars, a large yacht, and money that required extensive laundering in a questionable Swiss bank. The film is sharply and sardonically funny.  It draws the viewer in to an immoral and hedonistic lifestyle, both in its portrayal of Belfort and its portrayal of his associates and his victims who are looking to get rich quick.The movie includes stunning scenes of a ship sinking at sea, of Belfort rousing his staff with charismatic sales speeches, and of Belfort in a drug-induced stupor driving and wrecking an expensive car on a short ride to his home. These are all separate from the many explicit scenes of sexuality, drinking, and carousing.The movie portrays a callow, vicious way of life shown by a man in a suit and tie in the United States' financial center. The portrayal is sharp.  Some viewers have complained that it glamorizes the life it shows, but I did not find it so.Many Scorsese films have religious overtones in that they hint of redemption for their deeply flawed protagonists. Belfort gets caught, but does not repent over the course of the movie. At the end, unchastened, he is shown pursuing a hustle similar to what he might have pursued at the beginning. He rejects opportunities to come clean and cooperate until literally forced to do so. There is no redemption in this movie. Rather, we have a raw, unchanged character who somehow attains an unwelcome and anti-heroic stature at the end for continuing to be who he is.Robin Friedman

reviewText: Wow. I'm not shocked often and I'd even heard the rumors about this movie, but still, I was surprised at the amount of porn-quality sex, F-bombs (sometimes 3x in 1 sentence!) and, mostly, the rampant usage of drugs. Lots and lots of drugs. No, not just an occasional joint but tons of coke everywhere (including being blown up a butt-hole) and even as boldly used in a crowded restaurant at the table. Hard to imagine millionaire success when everyone is so stoned all the time. Really? All in all, it WAS entertaining for all 3 hours (yes, a full 3-hour movie!). Matthew McC. does a great job for his scene-stealing restaurant ad-lib. Jonah Hill is priceless as DiCaprio's number one guy. This is NOT a movie to watch with your parents or your kids. Watch it with your friends or significant others. Some of the sex is definitely close to porn level (like Jonah Hill masturbating at a big party in front of everyone, including his wife, when a pretty girl walks in). Not much shocks me but I was definitely a bit surprised at some of the scenes in this one....wow. Just wow.

reviewText: Like many others, I found this film to be way too long at almost 3 hours exactly, but along the way there are some truly brilliant scenes with a performance of a lifetime by DiCaprio as Jordan Belfort! Although there is almost non stop swearing, drug use, and nudity, you eventually become numb to it, just as the characters become numb to what reprehensible things they are doing. This is perhaps the finest cautionary tale of greed ever filmed, making "Wall Street" with Michael Douglas look tame in comparison!If you stick with this film, you'll be rewarded with some incredibly funny scenes as well.....the scene with Jordan trying to get to his car while overdosing on quaaludes and a subsequent stoned encounter with Jonah Hill's character is hilarious!This is NOT for everyone, so be forewarned!

reviewText: I would watch anything by Scorsese, and he doesn't disappoint-ever.  He is a true artist, a mastercraftsman.  DiCaprio has really come into his own.  I used to dislike his acting, but I think he has really honed has craft.  I thought he was excellent playing Jordan Belfort.I have warned my friends and family about this movie.  I told them it contains many explicit scenes, including nudity, strong sexual content, language, drug use, etc.  I don't know how "Wolf" pulled an "R" rating.  Having said that, however, I also informed them I really enjoyed this film.  I didn't think that any aspect of the film was excessive.  First of all, the story began in the 80's, and everything was bigger back then.  Secondly, it was based on the true account of a real person, including his actual life events.  How can the portrayal of any life event be unnecessary?I have no ethical critique on this film.  DiCaprio stated the story was a cautionary tale.  I guess it can be looked at from a number of different angles.  Is it cautionary in the respect that excess and greed lead to a downfall?  I think that's what he meant.  To me though, it could also be a warning about the mediocracy of mediocracy.  The last scene with Special Agent Gregory Coleman on the subway comes immediately to mind.  Do you want to make a name and drive in the fast lane for (blank), or sit anonymously in bumper to bumper forever?  "I've been a rich man, and I've been a poor man, and I choose rich every time!!" -Jordan Belfort

reviewText: Cinematic bravura at its most delirious. Director Martin Scorsese aims for Cecil B. DeMille decadence and hits the bull's eye - perfectly matched by Leonardo DiCaprio's tour de force as the outrageously excessive Jordan Belfort. "The Wolf of Wall Street" runs a whopping three hours yet never loses momentum. (By contrast, the 91-minute "Gravity" moves slower than molasses.) Excellent character portrayals from Jonah Hill, Rob Reiner and the all-too-brief Matthew McConaughey. A cautionary tale emerges from Scorsese's epic black comedy, but the denouement is pure W.C. Fields. This masterpiece will be remembered long after other Best Picture winners have been forgotten.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I didn't expect to like it, and I really don't to be honest, so why three stars? Well to put it simply, this film like two others I have recently watched over the last year or so which I won't name, is essentially a criticism of the materialism and hedonism of the American Elite, and how many lower class Americans aspire to be like them, rich, comfortable, and secure yet at the same time vapid, soulless, and empty. They think that they're better than everyone else because they have more money and thus more access to a luxurious lifestyle, but as the characters in this film, especially Jordan Belfort, played with a wonderful intensity by Leonardo DiCaprio, soon find out, they're just as human as everyone else, and no amount of wealth can change them into anything more.By the end of the film, the cold hard reality hits them right where it hurts, and there's no going back. I'll admit, I did laugh a few times, but it wasn't nearly as funny as it tried to be. Mostly it was just cruel, vulgar, and offensive, and many of the characters actions are just as, if not more pathetic than those from the lower class of American society. We shouldn't be aspiring to be like these people, we should aspire to be more like those who change the world for the better and make society a better place, not idiots like these. Thank you, and have a nice day.

reviewText: An absolute blast from start to finish filled with hilarious comedic moments, some very good human moments,and enough rankness to make your grandparents have a heart attack. It's a film so immoral, disgusting, and hilarious that people like me will consider it an instant classic of down and dirty cinema, while others will cringe and hide their eyes. Leonardo DiCaprio's performance is...well, a DiCaprio performance. He's stunted and wooden as usual, though he executes the role pretty well nonetheless. Jonah Hill is a riot and I thought that the cinematography was pretty fantastic.That said, the run time is a bit too excessive, much like the characters of the film, and there are some drier portions. But overall, it has one of the best drug scenes in film, a large majority of memorable scenes, and it was the second best film I saw last year (next to Dallas Buyer's Club).
summary: I'll Use an F Word to Describe This Movie: Fun

reviewText: Terrence Winter adapted Belfort's novel with a clear vision in mind-- making the film a companion piece to Goodfellas. In a way it is, but in a way it is something completely different.This is Scorsese's funniest film, and the funniest film of 2013. It has the wackiness of Scorsese's (massively underrated) After Hours, on a much larger scale, and the remorseless characters from other Scorsese films such as Goodfellas and The Departed. As a huge fan of Scorsese, I'd put this somewhere near the bottom of his top ten films (which is big for me).I also have to mention, this is Leonardo DiCaprio's best performance ever. He goes off the rails and gives a performance unlike anything that I've seen from him in the last 20 years. He also shows that he's a naturally gifted comedic actor, providing some of the funniest moments I've ever seen on a screen. The rest of the cast is fantastic as well, most notably Matthew McConaughey in an incredible 10 minutes. Jonah Hill further proves his acting chops, and showed great chemistry again with another mega-movie-star after his turn in Moneyball.Another thing I feel the need to mention, this film might not be for everyone. It's full of drugs, nudity, and foul language. It pushes the limits of an R-rating and doesn't look back. And another thing, it's 3 hours long. The length is no problem to me, and I think that the film flew by, but I've heard some people complain about it. Calling a film too long is the laziest criticism in the book in my opinion. Would you rather enjoy a very good movie for 2 hours, or 3 hours? I'll end my rant there, and tell you to go see The Wolf of Wall Street in theaters, buy the DVD, rent it, just find any way to watch it.The mere fact that the legendary Martin Scorsese, in 2013, at the age of 71 (!) can make a film like this is incredible, and it cannot be missed.
summary: Will be mentioned among Scorsese's best.

reviewText: I suppose The Wolf of Wall Street is the culmination of years of Martin Scorsese losing his style, themes and actors to the Hollywood machine he helped create - his films becoming a cheap copy of their original selves.With contributions like Mean Streets, Raging Bull, Goodfellas, etc. - he doesn't need to apologize. I can accept that he did his thing, it was great and it ended long ago. Gangs of NY, The Departed, and Boardwalk Empire are thankful anomalies to what has been a steady decline since Leonardo became the new DeNiro...as if...In fact, it was Gangs of New York, where I thought that Daniel Day-Lewis was taking over that role - of Marty's N.1. Shocked that he chose little Leo, who for all his talent - and he has some - has never been able to make me believe he was any of the things he played on screen...except in the lighter roles that suited him - pre-scorsese...Gone from Scorsese are the flawed yet heroic archetypes of the sort of men we wanted to become when we grew up...or at least hang out with...themes of brotherhood, opposition to authority (both criminal and Govn't), racism, beauty, love and the noble nature of man - even when he's being naughty - are all but gone. So is that subtle yet incredible cinematography that blew your mind...Now it's Casino with the soul cut-out - replaced by the true villain of our age - Capitalism / Money...the 1%...who are out to eat our brains...except that...um...like...the people making this stuff are the very people they're criticizing - morally corrupt rich folks who will sell you anything to make a buck...welcome to your own club Marty.The Wolf is a disjointed, hedonistic mess of what is almost a comedy, if it wasn't so depressing - and nauseating - and amusing in the sort of way that makes you ashamed for being amused. Imagine if that sheepdog and coyote trying to kill each other were real...Good morning Sam...It's really a film which has no message other than..."I have nothing left to say"..."so f-everything", so to speak.Scorsese was never king of the gangster films...he was King of New York...of the New York experience...of the heroes and villains of the greatest city in the West...and that's all gone now...The Wolf is mean, cynical, boring and a sometimes beautiful mess...with all the toys that keep today's mental infants happy - drugs, sex, violence and excess...and silly stereotypes of fat, rich, closeted gay Jews screwing people over...For those of us that remember Who's That Knocking at My Door...or ask ourselves "what's a mook"? or recall the real DeNiro's gf/actress waiting for a Charlie that was never going to show up...we wait patiently and pray that Marty will indeed paint one more house for us with that man that used to be our favorite actor...and maybe his little buddy that knows how to use a pen...

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is contemporary-classic Martin Scorsese, rich with graphic obscenity that would make even a Taxi Driver fan squirm, telling a vibrant story in the spirit of GoodFellas.Leonardo DiCaprio gives a knockout turn as a Jordan Belfort, young man who is seduced by the power and possibility of the financial market, and learns how to dupe those naive enough to believe in it. Wolf inverts the basic rags-to-riches narrative with an antihero like Belfort, who is self-made as far as driving his own success while exploiting those around him.The screenplay by Terence Winter is noteworthy for its ability to explain complicated financial scenarios, like pump & dump and the concept of penny stocks, among others, in a clear, engaging way without feeling preachy or too informative. If you can’t keep up, it doesn’t really matter, but it makes the film a hell of a lot more interesting.This film rises above mere goodness and becomes great, however, through its handling of this story. Belfort is not evil or exceptionally privileged; he knows how to make a sale, and how to make people believe in the power of the American market. The ending is so exciting and chilling, implying that we all have the potential to become a Jordan Belfort, and deep down a life of excess and exploitation is our American Dream.The Wolf of Wall Street is exciting and unapologetic, less about exposing the inner workings of Wall Street than presenting the ultimate American fantasy…if only we could get away with it.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***.From the previews the movie looked promising enough. The way Scorsese's Goodfellas delved into the world of organized crime Wolf would do the same for corporate crime. A movie which would give us a point of view of the criminal activity in Wall street with some depravity in between. But instead we get the opposite. The sex and drug-use is the focus with barely a semblance of a story wedged in between. There is a fine line between cautionary tale and glorification of bad behavior and Scorsese crosses it.As it appears in a desperate attempt to combine every R-rated movie trope into one movie he has made a movie with nothing new to offer. Are you looking for offensive comedy that crosses the line and actually makes you laugh watch Ted, Or a movie with strong language that serves the plot watch Django Unchained. Maybe closer to your taste is a movie that deals with drug-use and a diabolical maniac watch Scarface or Clockwork Orange. How about gratuitous sex and nudity with at least a half-decent script watch HBO. In Scorsese's attempt to produce the most controversial, shocking movie of the decade, he has missed the essence of what makes these movies good. Characters that appear every bit as human as the viewer except for their perversions. Even Tony Montana bears more humanity than Belfort. You know the people he kills are shady characters to begin with and towards the end he calls off an attack that would have endangered a target's wife and child. This doesn't serve to make us sympathize with him but to ground the character in the real world.In Wolf, we are fed the same drug and sex fueled debauchery over and over again until it becomes dizzying so that any message the movie is trying to send drifts over your head. What Scorsese could have easily achieved with a hammer he opts for a Wrecking ball leaving any meaning obliterated and untraceable. If I wanted to binge on 3 hours of porn with one-dimensional characters I would stay at home and watch it free, not pay upwards of $7 to watch it in the midst of 50 strangers in a darkened theater. A caricature of a caricature. This same movie directed by Michael Bay would have been panned by the critics. But the "Scorsese knows no wrong" crowd is more that willing to dole out praise. They will criticize Bay for cartoonish characters and crass humor but no not this movie.The movie attempts to be a reflection of Western society today and it's obsession with wealth. Instead, it is more accurately a reflection of the director. Just like Belfort we lured into the promise of a something of value - here a dramatic piece - and we're left reeling from the aftermath not unlike Belfort's victims. He pockets millions of dollars regardless of whether the movie bombs or not. I fashion to guess that the reality is the work of art itself and was his plan from the beginning - his grandest piece of all. Except I would have to admit that he was capable of such a grandiose scheme. Most likely he is oblivious he is the very image of the what he tries to satires in this movie.I wanted to love this movie so bad. From DiCaprios over the top acting - he doesn't let any chance to scream at the top of his lungs slip - to the sex and drug-use which I have no qualms with except for it being excruciatingly slammed into you head until you've become as mindless as the plot I can't pretend I enjoyed this nauseating experience. By the end, I was left feeling Scorsese's was desperate with this horrible script he went "over the top to save this BAD movie" - a Rare BiG-Mis from a Master......
summary: Scorsese's Desperate - Rare BiG-Mis from a Master......

reviewText: This movie is sensationalized fiction that is so over-the-top and excessively long that watching it was the biggest waste of time in my entire week.  It is pure fiction that is so vulgar and implausible that only the truly gullible will find it even entertaining.  (to the comment trolls out there, yes, I am aware that this book is based on a book that claims to be non-fiction)If you want to learn something about the greed and perversions that can come with money, I recommendThe Buy Side: A Wall Street Trader's Tale of Spectacular Excessinstead of this movie.  It is much more factual than this dribble.  Despite being fact, instead of this fiction, it is just as entertaining.  If that isn't enough for you, the book that this movie is based onThe Wolf of Wall Streetisn't bad either.  It is more entertaining than this terrible waste of talented actors.

reviewText: This is the first film by Scorsese that I have ever finished and been like "oof" -- and not because it isn't true to the book, which it is. But much as it was with the book the problem is that Jordan Belfort is, in the end and in reality, a horrible person with no remorse.Whereas Ray Liotta was the conscience, as it were, of Goodfellas , the problem with TWOWS is that there isn't any conscience. Further, there isn't even a character in the entire film that you want to root for. Add to that this film clocks in at over 3 hours and it's hard to not be asking youself "when is this going to end" which I can't believe I'm saying about one of the best directors that has ever lived - but there it is.

cheating on their wives, who are scumbag liars out to rob unsuspecting working class people, and who are drug fiends. extremely unappealing. why give me characters I cannot like, respect, identify with or care about and who I'd avoid in real life? am I supposed to be entertained by or learn something from their antics? is this anti-wall street propaganda?greedy, dumb anti-hero. it's not just that he's a liar, a thief and a junkie, he's a stereotypical liar, thief and junkie. he wants to make money, okay; he's not ethical and will do whatever he feels he needs to to make a buck, fine, if that's the character you want to present. but there is nothing interesting about him, and I mean nothing. the writer brings nothing new to this type of character. writer softens him abit by presenting his parents though you don't get to know his mother. the character respects his father alittle, at least he tries to hide some of his worse lies and excesses from him, and he doesn't do drugs with his parents or in front of them, thank god, but if I had a son like him, I'd have read him the riot act. his father tries to but the character is apparently so rich he will listen to or respect no one.this young guy wants what he wants and doesn't care who he hurts to get it. the writer shows him cheating and divorcing his first wife and marrying the slender, pretty, young blond. the writer protects him somewhat by largely not showing the pain he inflicts on others: we see his first wife's anger as she hits him, but the story doesn't linger on her pain and we really don't see her suffering. additionally, the people he cheats and lies to in business are not shown. by not showing his victims the writer makes him tolerable, barely.he demonstrates his stupidity by dumping his ethical, caring, though apparently sexually boring (in his opinion) first wife (he has plenty of comparisons as he spends his free time cheating on her with as many sex workers as he can). he leaves her for the beautiful blond who invites him to have sex with her though she knows he's married and whose invitation he accepts, believably (given his history in the film). he also proves his stupidity by smoking crack for no reason except that some guy he barely knew invited him to. basically, he's a risk taker and seems nearly out of control, caring only about making money and sex. again, why we are saddled with such an extreme character, or why we should care about him or what we are to learn from him, is beyond me.the main character routinely says that what he is doing in business is illegal and yet seems to have no concern at all that he will get busted or go to prison, which may say something about how our policing system is viewed by a certain class of society.the lead male characters seem to be at one long frat party, though they're pushing 40. the amount of drugs they take should've had them down for a sting within the first hour. they are so over the top, the film resembles a cartoon and becomes very difficult to take seriously; I started laughing, their behavior is so unbelievable. it's not that this behavior couldn't happen in real life, I know there are some very rich, very indulged people: the problem is the writer didn't know how to present them believably.when researching excesses of wealthy, young businessmen, it doesn't work story-wise to take examples of bizarre behavior, say for example, launching midgets at a bulls eye, and simply plop that behavior into a film. average people won't be able to identify and therefore won't accept it, no matter how many staff meetings the lying, crooks take to discuss it. after all, we've already learned not to trust them. instead show something like the midgets coming to work that day, show them grumbling about these rich jerks paying them to do such degrading work, show one having a conversation with a wife saying he got a well paying gig and will be able to pay the mortgage tomorrow - anything that will help the audience believe that there is a business where the workers throw midgets at a bulls eye. to help us accept outrageous behavior, the writer needs to show us the world that surrounds these louts, how they in fact live, survive, and thrive in their crazy reality. we need to see the real world surrounding them, a world of getting kids up in the morning for pre-school or elementary school, getting pulled over by a traffic cop, i.e., mundane, real world events. the writer focuses so much on the wall street world that he/she forgets to create a believable reality in which these businessmen exist and apparently thrive, a reality the audience can recognize, as most of us cannot relate to the rich, drug-fueled world the leads live in.predictable, very American type of film as the bad guys get their comeuppance, but real villains escape justice all the time so not really believable these guys are taken down, though very believable that the lead serves so little time and keeps his money. surprising though given that he keeps his money that he loses his pretty wife. she's written as not much better than he so more believable that she'd have stayed with the money: kind of fake Hollywoody punishment that she left him.what I didn't understand is, how does a junkie like this character hold on to his wealth with so many other predators running around? I know some alcoholics can function in business but this guy was into most everything except heroin. in real life wouldn't he have crashed and burned from all the drugs and excesses and people taking advantage of his many stupors? I know very little about drugs, but this character was taking alot of stuff, nothing prescribed, and though young, it would've been more believable had he overdosed.the actors look to be having a good time playing such out of control, high risk taking characters, but they seem more like stereotypes than fully realized characters, more like rutting buffoons, so not really possible to learn anything from their misadventures. acting is okay. men might enjoy this story more than women, can't really see much here for women. his first wife is only in maybe 20 or so minutes of this very long seeming film, and the story doesn't focus on having audience connect with her, so when her ex-husband goes to prison, it's not like women are saying "it great he got arrested." I kept thinking he must have had constant STDs and his first and second wives must have had continuing yeast infections, and worse.being generous, I'd assess the film as worth a view (though it is overly long) if you like the actors/director, which I do.Hollywood continues to revisit this type of character but I've yet to see it done to my satisfaction: a wall streeter who is greedy and amoral, but who you understand and care about, despite yourself. a character who makes mistakes, pays for them, but the writing is so fine that it is a believable comeuppance that is of value to the character, and to the audience. in other words, a character who is of actual use to the audience, instead of a mere parody.P.S. This story could be read as a cautionary tale but a facsimile of the wall street as presented here might have existed in the 20th century. now, my feeling is, though I could be wrong, with so much world economic difficulty, harder to imagine stock brokers of the type presented here are common. maybe in the 1970s, 80s, maybe even up to the 2008 recession, but not now, and not for some time. also, this excess may have been in the entertainment industry. there are of course still very rich people, but I think even rich people are more cautious and poor people, well, we're poorer.
summary: raunchy and excessive sex scenes do not satisfactorily update this story of an amoral wall streeter  (SPOILERS)...

reviewText: Martin Scorsese's last movie was the family-friendly Hugo, so I guess he felt the need to make something a little more controversial this time around. The Wolf of Wall Street is bold, loud, and a totally wild ride for three hours. There are more than 500 F-bombs, sex, plenty of nudity, drugs everywhere, and even a little violence.Like Goodfellas, the movie uses voice-overs to give the audience an insight into how the characters think. We learn that Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) made $49 million when he was 26-years-old, but he's annoyed that it was $3 million short of a million per week. The story is non-linear, so we can also see how Belfort started in the business as a stockbroker, and the events that led to him owning his own company.Belfort's initial job is terminated, and for a short while he's desperate for work. But then he takes a chance on a small local firm which claims to be in the same business as his previous company. When he arrives, the employees are sitting around in jeans. There are no computers of any kind. The stocks being traded are only worth a few cents, but the rate of commission is 50 percent. In a very convincing scene, Belfort's character makes a $4,000 sale, earning him $2,000 on the spot. The other employees can't believe what they are seeing.This initial success enables Belfort to buy a fancy car and he attracts the attention of his neighbor, Donnie (Jonah Hill). After learning that Belfort made $72,000 the previous month, Donnie begs him for a job and quits his own immediately. Belfort is gifted at sales and convincing people to do things his way, He hires a collection of apparent losers, writes sales scripts, and teaches them how to sell. These scenes are very funny, and the whole venture succeeds brilliantly. Belfort is beginning to think anything is possible.The movie will appeal to a large number of people because Belfort essentially has the life that others dream about. He does and says what he wants, marries a beautiful woman, lives in a huge house, and buys just about anything his heart desires. He speculates to his employees that we all want such wealth, and let's face it, the vast majority of people dream of that kind of life.Some of the dialogue is excellent. For instance, one scene shows Belfort taking advice on dwarf tossing. He has a perfectly serious conversation about the legality of the idea, and wants to know the extent of his liabilities. Because it's serious, it's funny. One of the biggest laughs comes when we see a scene from Belfort's persepective and later learn the truth about what really happened. If you see the movie, you'll know which one I am talking about. The heavy drug use does cast some doubts about the accuracy of what we are seeing as it's mostly from Belfort's perspective.In rather predictable fashion, these largely illegal practices eventually catch up with him. However, I won't spoil the outcome by talking about how he deals with his problems.DiCaprio is outrageous for much of the movie. At times I thought I was watching Jack Nicholson around 40 years ago. If you recall Nicholson's performances in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest or The Shining, the manic quality is similar to DiCaprio's turn as Belfort. If you aren't squeamish about nudity and bad language, The Wolf of Wall Street is a lot of fun. It felt as if 90 minutes had gone by when the credits rolled, but it was three hours. I can imagine watching this one over and over.Overall score 4.5/5

reviewText: There are, occasionally, those movies that come along where the best response I can generate for them is, "Well, that was interesting." The Wolf of Wall Street is one of those movies.It's not a bad movie--certainly, the performances are great--but I can't say that it was a good movie, either. It... well, it just was.I suppose the main issue I have with it is that I'm not sure what the movie was trying to say. What it was about. Sure, the movie is about Jordan Belfort, but, usually, when you make a movie about someone's life, it's because you think there is a message people can take away from the story about that person's life. For instance:12 Years a Slave: Survive. Plus, you know, slavery is bad.Dallas Buyers Club: Don't succumb to the system if the system is wrong. Plus, you know, rich, white men don't care about anything other than taking your money from you.Saving Mr. Banks: Creation is a personal act and the creation remains a part of the creator. As Walt said about Mickey, "He's family."Those are just some of the ones from this year. But I don't get a sense that there is any real message in Wolf. No underlying theme. Maybe the movie is just too chaotic for that. At any rate, I didn't feel like I came away with anything at the end of the movie other than Belfort was really screwed up.All of the characters are screwed up. Or too flat to be screwed up. Like Belfort's first wife; she's not screwed up, not in the movie, anyway, but we never see her as anything other than this background character that is mistreated. And the FBI guy doesn't seem to be screwed up, but he's "FBI Guy" and can't be screwed up, because that's his cutout. The rest of the characters are just screwed up.Also, I'm pretty sure it's not just me that has an issue with discerning a meaning in this movie. Well, my wife didn't see one, either. But! In doing my research, I found a reviewer who went to see this in a theater full of the kind of financial guys that Belfort was. They certainly saw the movie differently from me as the reviewer said they cheered "in all the wrong places." When Belfort would do something bad (like when, after he's sober, he rips up his couch to get at his hidden stash of drugs), the guys in the theater would cheer for him. I take that to mean that there is no clear message in the movie, because, if there was, those people would not be cheering.But maybe Scorsese did it that way on purpose? Maybe he's just presenting the story of the man's life and letting people come away with their own message? Certainly, the actors (DiCaprio and Hill) have taken a lot of flak over their portrayals (which I just don't get; why is Scorsese not taking any heat over it? He's the one that presented it the way it is), that they were glorifying the drug use and partying and, well, everything that they do in the movie. I can understand why some people might think that the movie is an endorsement of that behavior. The problem is that you just can't tell.Not to mention that the movie resorts to that starting in the middle of the action thing and then jumps back to the beginning. For no purpose, evidently, other than to start with dwarf tossing. Why? It doesn't make the story better. It serves no purpose within the story. Why does everyone and their dog feel like you have to start somewhere in the middle and then go back to the beginning to explain whatever weirdness you're seeing? It's a cheap trick, and I'm so tired of it.There's also that the movie is three hours long. Three hours long of wondering what the point is to get to the end to find out that there was no point. Granted, it was a quick three hours due to the frenetic pace of the movie, but not really a satisfying three hours. And it was three hours after being cut down for being too long. It makes me wonder what they took out.Anyway... I'm actually disappointed that this movie has received a best picture nomination and that Scorsese has received a best director nomination. I suppose I can't fault them for the best actor and supporting actor nominations, because they did deliver great performances, although, as my wife pointed out, the character of Belfort has become DiCaprio's norm, so it wasn't a stretch for him. There's not a great chance he'll win, anyway, so I can live with the nomination.In the end, I think what's happening with this movie is what happens with any movie like this that critics can't figure out: Instead of just saying they don't know, they say it's great. That way they mask their ignorance. Personally, I think Scorsese missed with this one and everyone is too afraid to say so.

reviewText: Golden Globe winner Leonardo DiCaprio stars in the title role of Jordan Belfort. Belfort works his way up the ladder making money in penny stocks, i.e. "selling garbage to garbage men." His scheme is to sell these garbage stocks to rich investors due to the high commissions. Along the way he does some illegal transactions as he runs his corporation like a frat party in "Animal House." Having not known money, he and his crew are ill equipped to handle it.I thought that Jonah Hill gave one of his best performances. The production is awfully long, not wanting to miss out on any details. The film goes into detail to explain to the audience things like IPO and the history and effects of quaaludes. If you note the ludes he took early in the film were crumbly. Those were non-prescription ludes made from a pill press in uncle Vinnie's garage and not too potent. Later they score some real ludes. Having taken the fake ones for so long, they didn't know how to handle them causing them to crash, like the money it was too much too fast.The main criticism of the film is that it featured over 500 F-bombs. It really didn't seem like that many due to the length of the production. Besides you get numb to it after the first few hundred or so.

reviewText: “The Wolf of Wall Street” is a major studio film with an A-list star and an A-list director. It also contains some exceptional supporting performances and an ambitious screenplay. Its positioning as a late- December, 2013 release indicates that the industry regards it as an Important Film. Yet its very sense of self-importance and a bloated running time make it an example of the excess it depicts.Jordan Belfort (Leonardo Di Caprio) works his way up to become a stockbroker on Wall Street. His first day in that position coincides with the 1987 crash of the market and he’s soon out of a job. When he finally gets another, it’s in a strip mall office staffed by guys who look more like bookies than stockbrokers. They sell junk stocks that pay huge commissions, often as high as 50% of the sale price. Jordan quickly makes a fortune in commissions by talking average, middle-class folks into buying crummy stocks, all perfectly legal.But Jordan is not satisfied. He covets as clients the rich, who have far more money to invest but are not as easy to sell. So Jordan develops a system to gradually build up their confidence by making them some money with blue chip stocks before pushing the junk. Along the way, he meets Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill), a guy eager to get rich no matter the means, and together they create a mini-empire of brokers all determined to reap financial rewards with little concern for their clients’ interests.Director Martin Scorsese and Di Caprio team up for the fifth time in this movie, based on the memoir of Long Island penny stockbroker Jordan Belfort. Di Caprio has always shone in pictures helmed by Scorsese and this is no exception. Belfort is the smooth-talking, good-looking fellow who is so rich he lights cigars with hundred dollar bills. As in his previous role in “The Great Gatsby,” DiCaprio embodies the charm that is the cornerstone to his character’s building a fortune, first legally and then in shadier fashion. Belfort and his crew are making money so fast that there need be no limit to their hedonsim, whether it involves call girls, cocaine, exotic sports cars, or yachts. They can have whatever money can buy.As Donnie, Jonah Hill continues to rack up an impressive series of sidekick roles, including the statistics expert in “Moneyball” and Chaning Tatum’s undercover partner in “21 Jump Street.” Hill started in broad comedies and while he uses his comic talents to advantage in the role of Donnie, his performance is a true characterization, transcending caricature, and makes for an interesting contrast to DiCaprio’s Belfort.The supporting cast adds to the film’s luster. Matthew McConaughey has a brief scene as Belfort’s mentor, a man with a rather distinctive playbook for success. Rod Reiner plays Belfort’s father, Jean Dujardin (“The Artist”) plays a crooked Swiss banker, Kyle Chandler is a persistent FBI agent who sets his sights on nailing Belfort, and Joanna Lumley takes on the key role of Aunt Emma, who becomes crucial in hiding huge sums of money from the government.There is a major problem with the film, however, and it is that Scorsese goes overboard in illustrating Belfort and company’s unbridled lifestyle, to the point of repetition. Long after we get the point, the director is hitting us over the head with yet another example of moral decay. Scorsese may have intended to underscore his characters’ growing decadence, but the ultimate effect is to make us impatient with all this extravagance. There are moments when it even seems as if the actors are awaiting the “Cut” cue and are nervously carrying on with a scene that should have ended far sooner. It’s surprising that these scenes weren’t trimmed in the editing process, when a movie is given its final shape and pace.The atmosphere of Scorsese’s films is always significant, and the director does an excellent job recreating the excitement of Wall Street in the 80’s and 90’s with its conspicuous consumption, disdain of moderation, and feeling of invulnerability. The Bernie Madoff case comes to mind, since both Madoff and Belfort became hugely wealthy at the expense of those they duped by winning their confidence.Rated R, “The Wolf of Wall Street” is a cautionary tale of the power of money to corrupt and the ability of the corrupted to rationalize their immoral and illegal activities. Despite its excesses, it keeps us involved as we accompany Jordan Belfort on his drug-fueled roller-coaster ride.Bonus extras on the 2-Disc Blu-ray/DVD Combo Pack includes the special feature “The Wolf Pack” and a Digital HD Ultraviolet copy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In 1986, a young People’s Critic was playing with his Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles action figures, reading Spiderman comics, and watching Knight Rider; meanwhile The Wolf of Wall Street suggests that there was an entirely different story of the 1980s to tell.  Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio collaborate for the fifth time and the result is their most polarizing effort by far, but also DiCaprio’s greatest performance of his career.Last year at this exact time, I made quite a bit of noise about Leonardo DiCaprio’s sneaky but brilliant performance as Calvin Candie in Quentin Tarantino’s Django Unchained.  This year, I will make even more noise about his turn as Wall Street stockbroker, Jordan Belfort.  The film depicts the rise and inevitable fall of Belfort after he gets a taste of what the high life is like and never stops wanting more.That “taste” comes in the form of an early scene in the film.  In it, Belfort the nave intern meets the senior partner of his firm (Matthew McConaughey) for lunch.  Here Belfort is seemingly learning the ropes from a guy who’s been around for a while, but on second look Belfort is actually staring his future self right in the face.  McConaughey fiercely and skillfully poisons and corrupts Belfort but leaves him dazzled and impressed.  He sells Belfort just like another client, setting the wheels in motion for the “wolf” to rear its head.  When his brokerage closes after Black Monday in 1987, Belfort recruits a band of like-minded sleezeballs and opens his own brokerage firm called Stratton-Oakmont.  With consciences checked at the door and a script of Belfort’s own design, Stratton Oakmont prays on the rich and the poor, selling worthless “penny stocks” and reaping commissions hand over fist.  Belfort’s partner in crime, Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill), represents the “Greed is good” adage from Wall Street to precision.  Together the two cut a swath through the financial market and find themselves absurdly wealthy and yet impossibly insatiable. Balfort symbolically leaves stability behind when he leaves his  kind and caring wife, Teresa (Cristin Milioti) for sexpot, Naomi (Margot Robbie).While clearly a Scorsese film, the director’s presence from a technical standpoint is rather restrained.  He fills the frame with decadence, debauchery, and dishonesty, but never has he relied on his actors to make a film work as much as he does here.  Fortunately, they are up to the task, but this circumstance is why The Wolf of Wall Street is not the classic Scorsese film that it could have been.  Nonetheless, like all other Scorsese films, the plot is nothing but a mode at which to create a commentary on a deeper subtext.  Belfort’s story is used as a way for the filmmaker to tell a story about intoxication, greed, and the destruction of the American fabric.  He does all of this with a playful tone however, which is what gives the film such energy!  The irreverence of this film is impossible to capture into words and that’s exactly what Scorsese intended.  With a running time of three hours, it is clear that Scorsese did not want to shy away from the bacchanalian excess that plays such a large part in the film.  At the risk of hitting the audience over the head with this fact, the drug of choice for most characters is the “lude” (short for Quaalude), which tenaciously reflects the conduct of everyone in this film.  In one scene, high on ludes, DiCaprio has lost all sense of mobility and yet must crawl, writhe, and tumble his way to his Ferrari in the hopes to then drive home and stop Donnie from revealing money laundering evidence into a tapped phone.  This scene is one of only a few characteristically Scorsese scenes, and for DiCaprio it is particularly impressive.  Never has DiCaprio been more physical, comedic, energetic, and kinetically charged than he is in this film.  Jay Gatsby would literally implode after one second in Jordan Belfort’s shoes.In a montage towards the end set to the Lemonheads cover of Simon and Garfunkel’s “Mrs. Robinson,” the line “Every way you look at it, you lose,” critically suggests that the intoxication of the previous 150 minutes is beginning to ware off.  We have a moment to finally catch our breaths after the yachts, the mansions, the sex, the money, and the helicopters are all out of sight and we are amazed at what we’ve witnessed.After an Academy member premier of the film, a screenwriter very publicly shouted, “Shame on you!” at the legendary director.  Accordingly, I witnessed several people walk out of the screening that I was in. Certainly, the world DiCaprio and Scorsese explore this time around is fearlessly audacious.  Nonetheless, the film is based on Belfort’s own memoir, and the screenplay is co-written by the man who wrote and produced The Sopranos and Boardwalk Empire, Terence Winter.  Those shows and this film all have the united goal of exploring morally bankrupt people who fill that void with the greatest drug of all, money.  Our society is badly hooked on this drug and as good as we are at hiding the evidence of what greed has done to us, stories like The Wolf of Wall Street serve as reminders, reminders that make some filmgoers uncomfortable.  Still, as much of a fan as I am of this film, I submit that The Wolf of Wall Street is Goodfellas-Lite: Henry Hill enters stock market.  I think a 5 and  hour American nightmare double feature is in my future!  A-The Wolf of Wall Street is rated R and has a running time of 3 hours.  Look out for many recognizable faces in supporting roles including the real life Jordan Belfort.  This film is packed to the brim – there is so much to discuss and mention, but this review is long enough!Also, prepare yourself for that ‘ludes’ Ferrari scene, it’s phenomenal!

reviewText: "The are going to need a wrecking ball to get me out of here. This is my house!" Jordan Belfort (DiCaprio) is a stock broker at one of Wall Streets biggest firms. When the crash of '87 hit his firm went under and he lost his job. Desperate, he takes a job selling penny stocks, after finding out the commission he can make on these stocks he goes into business for himself. When he turns to duping rich people into buying these stocks him and his partner Donnie Azoff (Hill) become rich beyond their wildest dreams, but everything comes with a price. I am a huge Scorsese fan and am becoming a big DiCaprio one as well so I was really looking forward to seeing this. While the movie is 3 hours long it doesn't feel slow or drawn out and never actually felt like a 3 hour movie. If that is your reason to hesitate on it don't worry. While there is a ton of drug use and nudity in this it doesn't distract from the flow. All that said this is a real must see. There is drama, comedy, action, everything that makes a movie great. I can't say enough about this movie. The fact that this is based on a true story makes it even better. Do yourself a favor and watch this, you won't be sorry. Overall, a great experience and one that I will watch over and over. I give it an A+.
summary: This is a real must see. There is drama, comedy, action, everything that makes a movie great. I can't say enough about it.

reviewText: I worked for a "bulge bracket", white shoe (think Harvard, Stanford, Wharton, Chicago) grads, and I saw no fewer than ten people go to jail for corruption - Dennis Kozlowski (Tyco), the head of investment banking at Merrill Lynch (Enron Scandal), a 26 year old for insider trading in a railroad merger.  Do I think this really happened?  Yep!!!  Do I think it was as extreme as the movie says it was?  Yep!!!  Steve Madden?  The shoe guy?  Yep, I remember the IPO, and the scandal.  I grew up on a farm in Illinois, and my first day on Wall Street (I was 21), I could hear the banker in the restroom stall next to me snorting cocaine.I think this movie is a pretty accurate portrayal of Strattford Oakmont....and of greed in America.  See it!!!

reviewText: “The Wolf of Wall Street” is the fifth DiCaprio/Scorsese collaboration (following “Gangs of New York” “The Aviator” “The Departed” and “Shutter Island”). Perhaps without this fact the film would not have received critical accolades including five Oscar nominations. The film runs almost three hours, but I am not sure if the film is really worth that time of your life.Based on the memoir of Jordan Belfort (played by Leonardo DiCaprio) or the “Wolf” of Wall Street, the film starts with the days of his wild lifestyles back in the 90s as the founder of New York brokerage firm Stratton Oakmont. Unfortunately Scorsese seems too much interested how wild it could be, taking 90 minutes to tell us what could be told in 45 minutes. Except a few scenes (one including too brief Matthew McConnaughey as the protagonist’s mentor-like figure) the result is pretty boring, with sex, drug, sex, drug going on and on.What the company does is, Jordan says, illegal. In the second half the film gets interesting with the law slowly but steadily catching up with the “Wolf,” even though what is revealed here is only a little better than routine. Despite the immediate subject matter and first-rate director, “The Wolf of Wall Street” is a missed opportunity.

reviewText: I confess I did not sit through the entire film.  I found the film's relentless vulgarity nauseating.  I'm sure the film's portrayal of the materialism that motivates some professional investors is cogent, but I believe the film unjustly downplays the important contributions that many financiers make to the arts, the sciences, education, infrastructure, and overall quality of life.  Formulations that blame Wall Street alone for America's struggling economy are I believe at best simplistic.  I was unable to find in WOLF a sophisticated analysis of ways in which a modern economy might be cultivated on behalf of the greater good.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***Rating: 2.5 out of 5.0I like to think of 'The Wolf of Wall Street' as a poor man's 'Good Fellas'. They're both based on a true story about a character who is a moral failure and they both rely quite a bit on a narrator as well as improvised dialogue. 'Good Fellas' was primarily successful due to the strong, believable performances of Ray Liotta and Joe Pesci; both those actors were of Italian descent and they were playing characters that also were supposed to be Italian. But here Leonardo DiCaprio is supposed to play Jordan Belfort, a Jewish guy from Queens. I watched clips of the real Belfort and I just felt DiCaprio doesn't come close to capturing the essence of the 'Wolf of Wall Street' (maybe I associate DiCaprio with too many other characters in films that he's been in before or maybe he simply is unable to move beyond his own persona). One other problem is that the stakes in 'Good Fellas' were much higher: there was that enormous Lufthansa heist and people being whacked all over the place; but here it's just a matter of investors being conned (who you never get to see on screen) and an anti-hero who's prone to a life of extraordinary excess.Still, Belfort's antics are mildly interesting, especially in the first half hour, where in a series of flashbacks, we see how he lost his stock broker job on his very first day on Wall Street due to the stock market crash of 1987. Matthew McConaughey is highly entertaining as Belfort's sleazy supervisor who imparts his 'greed is good' philosophy to the fledging shyster, while they dine together in a high-end restaurant. Probably the highlight of the first half hour is when Belfort employs a new phone script at the low class 'boiler room' where he's recently been hired--Belfort proves to be much polished than his fellow employees, who rely more on intimidation than finesse. Way less successful is Jonah Hill's character, Donnie Azoff (Danny Porush in real life). There's really nothing distinctive about Azoff (unlike a Joe Pesci in 'Good Fellas) except for the fact that he's married to his first cousin; Hill basically has no memorable scenes (unless you consider the ridiculous fight between Donnie and one of Belfort's drug couriers later in the film).Once Belfort is locked and loaded as CEO of the newly minted (and seemingly respectable) 'Oakmont Stratton', Scorsese's strategy is to highlight most of Belfort's reported true-life escapades. We're asked to laugh at the morally corrupt Belfort as Scorsese blasts us with Belfort's outrages piled on one after another. Not all of it essential to the plot. Take for example the scene where his wife's gay butler throws a party for his friends and some of Belfort's cash in the apartment ends up missing. The whole point of the scene is to show how ruthless and greedy Belfort is, with the butler ending up being held by his legs over a balcony. It's an interesting scene but again, not essential; cutting it could have contributed to the necessary shortening of the entire film, to a much more manageable two hour fest, as opposed to three.Another problem is Scorsese's penchant for stretching things out beyond any modicum of good direction (as well as plain good aesthetics). I'm thinking of the scene where Belfort is wasted after downing the Lemmon- 714 Quaaludes; after taking too many, Belfort finds himself at a country club where he's no longer able to work, so he has to crawl to his car. Yes it's supposed to be funny but the long 'crawl' just goes on for too long and dilutes whatever humor Scorsese is attempting to extract from the situation. Another drawn out scene which loses its comic effect is the yacht being tossed in the storm. After about a minute we get the idea but Scorsese doubles down on the slapstick, with Belfort and crew being tossed around ad infinitum.The dialogue here is very inconsistent. One very good scene is the cat and mouse conversation Belfort has with the FBI agent on his yacht. But often, Scorsese insists that his actors improvise, sacrificing verisimilitude (one example that sounded improvised to me, was the early Belfort-Donnie exchange where they discuss Donnie's incestuous relationship with his wife).While many people will find it hard to believe, most of the scenes in the movie actually happened (if we are to believe Belfort's book--same name as the film). One scene that didn't happen were the dwarfs being tossed around at the office party (at the beginning of the film). A critical scene that did not happen in real life is when Belfort slips the note to Donnie that he's wearing a wire. I understand that Belfort did this with another one of his employees but not Donnie. I think it was a mistake for Scorsese to take liberties here since the implication is Belfort is not such a bad guy after all, since he's not willing to betray his best friend (but in reality, he did).Ultimately, 'The Wolf of Wall Street' would have been a much better if it was shorter. Not all of Belforts' machinations are that interesting; after a while the greed simply becomes grating. Scorsese wants us to laugh at some of the outrageous things Belfort does and occasionally we end up amused. But 'Wolf' is also a cautionary tale about not following a good path in life. Scorcese and DiCaprio are critical of the 'old' Belfort but seem to have forgiven the 'new' (note that the real-life Belfort gets a cameo at film's end). Is Belfort really a new man? Prosecutors have recently alleged that Belfort only paid a fraction of the restitution he owes, detailed in the original plea agreement. Perhaps it's time for a new accounting. That's one important point I would have liked to have seen highlighted at end of 'The Wolf of Wall Street'.
summary: Occasionally interesting chronicle of Wall Street scam artist's life ends up as a poor man's 'Good Fellas'

reviewText: The Wolf of Wall Street is a black comedy film directed by Martin Scorsese, based on Jordan Belfort's memoir of the same name. The film stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Belfort, a New York stockbroker who runs a firm that engages in securities fraud and corruption on Wall Street in the 1990s. The film also features Jonah Hill, Margot Robbie, Matthew McConaughey and Jean Dujardin. It is the fifth collaboration between Scorsese and DiCaprio, and the second between Scorsese and Winter following Boardwalk Empire.Scorsese, DiCaprio, and Belfort belive-it-or-not tale is delivered in such a larger-than-life way that its difficult to believe that it could have actually happened.Self-referential and irreverent to a fault, The Wolf of Wall Street finds Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio re-imagining "Ferris Bueller" as a grown up, drug-induced "Fear and Loathing" stock-broker. The story wants its audience to be interested in characters who are uninteresting people, made unbearable by their delusions of being interesting because they are intoxicated.The movie comes off more as an glorification of rather than a satire of the excessive lifestyle it depicts.

reviewText: "I just seen The Wolf of Wall Street and without regret, I had a mixed reaction. While the satire and twisted, witty humour kept the film alive from it treading into Margin Call or Wall Street (Oliver Stone film) territory, it does lag in many corners.It is far too long for a film with this subject at 3 hours rendering it self-indulgent and smug and it relied more on sensationalism than story itself. It reminded a bit too much of Casino, another 3-hour long Scorsese film that manages to make you scratch your head but only differences is that Wall St. did not have Sharon Stone and lacked the humour like this film.The film is neither terrible nor great as it does make use of a tempo that is unfathomable in films with this length and manages to make humour and some very provocative speeches and commentary about vice through the halls of economic, plutocratic power in the same way that Aaron Sorkin managed to do some heavy-handed commentary in the TV show, The Newsroom. Matthew McConaughey, despite a small screen presence, steals the show as a smug forefather to Belfort (played by DiCaprio) and his future infamy.However, if you like your over-the-top, sensational (extreme depictions of sex, drugs, and strong language), crass, mean-spirited, and anti-Oscar friendly, you might like to check this one out."
summary: Drug and sex-fuelled madness in an overwhelming 3-hour long bottle! Instead of the title, call it: THE VICE IS RIGHT!

reviewText: It took me about three or more tries to get all the way through The Wolf of Wall Street.  That's how repulsive I found it.  Let their be no mistake: DiCaprio is terrific as Jordan Belfort, The Wolf himself. That was the ONLY reason I kept trying to make it through and stick with it to the bitter end.  But the movie as a whole....ugh!  I just found every character in it completely despicable, including, of course, DiCaprio's own character.  When all is said and done, "The Wolf.." is about a bunch of annoying, amoral, greedy, drug addict con artist blowhards who eventually get what they deserve.There is some undeniably great acting from several other members of the cast as well, most notably from Jonah Hill playing the part of Donnie, the rather pathetic true love of Belfort.  Sure, "The Wolf..." does have a terrific script at times which actually has some pretty funny dialogue. Some have referred to "The Wolf.." as a "black comedy".  I don't see it that way.  I like a good black comedy, especially the movies of Quentin Tarantino, such as Inglorious Basterds or, for that matter, Django Unchained.  "The Wolf of Wall Street" was not even close to being in the same league as Tarantino's works.  The primary problem with "Wolf.." for me is that I couldn't stand any of the characters in it. As I've already said, this movie as a whole was simply a long, slow slog just to get all the way through.  I could almost give it a 3 star pass because of DiCaprio's dynamic acting--perhaps his best ever--but I simply could not bring myself to bump it up from 2 stars because of the inherent ugliness of this film and it's characters.  I didn't even like any of the "good guys" (the FBI guys).The sad fact is that I have known a few people like this in the corporate world in which I live. I try to stay as far away from them as possible. These types are the very epitome of greed and debauchery. Look, I'm anything but a prude.  My dislike of this film has nothing at all to do with the nudity or the language, although most of the women depicted were largely a rather large collection of stereotypical whores. Even the supposed "better" women in the movie are primarily driven by the same greed that their spouses possess and use their sexuality to gain entrance into this insane world of ill-gotten booty built on the backs of the Belfort flunkies.  This brings me to another major flaw with this film:  the absolute one-dimensionality of almost all of the characters.  Most characters in "The Wolf.." have no depth.  They are almost all stereotypes rather than fully fleshed out real people. They are almost all reduced to cartoon character status; mindless robots controlled by Belfort's constant line of bull-slinging "motivational" speeches.  His entire empire is comprised of these mindless sycophantic whores: willing to do whatever their Belfort god says as long as it makes them rich.  And once rich, what do they do with their outrageous earnings? To a man and woman:  party, do drugs and have sex with each other as well as a large group of eager prostitutes. They chronically cheat on their spouses, lie, steal, and whatever else it takes to keep themselves rich and entertained because they are so fundamentally flawed and shallow, they seem to lack any imagination at all.  Being filthy rich is inevitably never enough to fill the holes in their worthless souls.  The fact that Jordan Belfort ratted on all of his friends and colleagues in order to save his own ass and, as a result of his "cooperation", received only 36 months in jail is a testament as well to our deeply flawed and broken justice system. I never want to watch this film again in spite of DiCaprio's brilliant performance.  It was neither "fun" or entertaining enough for me to ever go back to it again.
summary: Could not get myself to like "The Wolf.." in spite of DiCaprio's amazing performance

reviewerName: W. Green "Author of Time Travel Twins Series"
reviewText: Actually, the movie starts with great promise as if there was a story to be told. But alas, there is no story (or at least none that is worthy of a three-hour presentation). The main character (DiCaprio) starts out relatively naive and cuddly. Then within 10 minutes he is converted into a drug addled, super-aggressive, born stockbroker-salesman who becomes incredibly successful by Wall Street standards. He finds he likes drugs, sex, parties and power and for the next 169 minutes he explains and demonstrates his new and continuing super-charged, debauched lifestyle...ad nauseam. After about 30 minutes of this, it's pretty clear that he is a loveable, but incurable degenerate.He maintains this persona and worldview to the bitter end. All of his business associates, his friends, his wife, and girlfriends also stubbornly resist change. Even Wall Street remains the same.  It's a non-stop 2.99333 hours of continuous drug use, sex acts, shady business practices and stupid macho behavior coming from nowhere and leading to nowhere. If the movie was tightened-up and given a Dragnet-type, prep-epilogue ending, this baby would come in at about 45 minutes. Then I could give it a 3-star review. Too long, too boring, and a waste of talent.
summary: There's a Movie in Here Someplace

reviewText: The outrages.  The horrors.  The sheer decadence.  Have these gentlemen no shame?  No they do not.  Mr Scorsese and DiCaprio et al have no capacity for shame.From midgets to quaaludes no topic is safe from the devious minds these men allegedly have to thrust their twisted demented dabblings of immorality mindsets onto.  Nothing is safe.  Even the once highly respectable Rob Reiner sinks shoulder deep down into the mud with these wretched villains.I sat in the theater for the entirety of it's 180minute running time in utter dismay at the proceedings being shined on the silver screen in front of me.  That is 10800 seconds for anyone counting.  And that's not the only thing I for one was counting.  There were innumerable moments of nudity, cocaine, alcohol, hookers and an overall general terrible attitude on display by these men.  And the curse words!  I lost track trying to count up all the flagrant usage of a particular F word that was said not once if not for 547 times at least.I don't mind being shocked for the sake of being shocked.  That Calendar Girls movie had plenty of wild debauchery to last me for an evening (or two counting the fact I watched it again before the on demand expired.)  But this Wolf of Wall Street is further than just beyond the pale.And to think that this movie would even be emanating from the mind of Mr. Scorsese. The same man that made that lovely movie about Buddha and The Age of Innocence.  Well sir you have fallen a long way since you made that wonderfully adorable buddy movie with Paul Newman and Tom Cruise.  And Leonardo Dicaprio?  Et tu?  For shame, young man.  For shame.  It wasn't that long ago I remember you on Growing Pains.  If you would have only followed in the footsteps of that admirable gentleman Kirk Cameron than you would be making more Titantics and Catch Me if you Cans and a whole lot less of these things.  And Jonah Hill, yeah I've seen Superbad so you I'm not shocked with.Not to beat this dead horse's drum anymore but how much sin did you really need up there?  I could swear that one hooker in particular may have been a man that has not completed the transition to a woman if my eyes are correct.Either way this was one of the best movies I've seen all year.  I got it on pre-order.  Unbelievably awesome flick.  I'm gonna be wearing a groove in the blu ray when I get this in the mail.  Seriously, the only regret I had watching this was not studying harder in college and getting a degree in Finance back before the freewheeling days ended.  If this had come out instead of Wall Street I woulda had a goal in my life.
summary: Sin.  This movie is nothing but 3 Hours of Vile Disgusting Sin
